I

Cedric]140-lord fauntleroy by frances hodgson burnett contents i ii iii iv v vi vii viii ix x xi xii xiii xiv xv i cedric [himself]141-his knew nothing whatever about it . It had never been even mentioned to [him]141-his . [He]141-his knew that [[his]141-his papa]142-his papa had been [an Englishman]143-an englishman , because [[his]141-his mamma]144-his mamma had told [him]141-his so ; but then [[his]141-his papa]142-his papa had died when [he]141-his was [so little a boy]146-so little a boy that [he]141-his could not remember very much about [him]142-his papa , except that [he]142-his papa was big , and had blue eyes and a long mustache , and that it was a splendid thing to be carried around [the room]147-the room on [his]142-his papa shoulder . Since [[his]141-his papa]142-his papa 's death , [Cedric]39-cedric had found out that it was best not to talk to [[his]141-his mamma]144-his mamma about [him]142-his papa . When [[his]141-his father]150-his father was ill , [Cedric]39-cedric had been sent away , and when [he]39-cedric had returned , everything was over ; and [[his]141-his mother]151-his mother , who had been very ill , too , was only just beginning to sit in [her]151-his mother chair by the window . [She]151-his mother was pale and thin , and all the dimples had gone from [her]151-his mother pretty face , and [her]151-his mother eyes looked large and mournful , and [she]151-his mother was dressed in black . " Dearest , "[39-cedric] said [Cedric]39-cedric [[his]141-his papa]142-his papa had called [her]151-his mother that always , and so [the little boy]153-the little boy had learned to say it , " dearest , is [[my]39-cedric papa]2410-my papa better ? "[39-cedric] [He]39-cedric felt [her]151-his mother arms tremble , and so [he]39-cedric turned [his]39-cedric curly head and looked in [her]151-his mother face . There was something in it that made [him]39-cedric feel that [he]39-cedric was going to cry . " [Dearest]2411-dearest , "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said , " is [he]2410-my papa well ? "[39-cedric] Then suddenly [his]39-cedric loving little heart told [him]39-cedric that [he]39-cedric 'd better put both [his]39-cedric arms around [her]151-his mother neck and kiss [her]151-his mother again and again , and keep [his]39-cedric soft cheek close to [hers]151-his mother ; and [he]39-cedric did so , and [she]151-his mother laid [her]151-his mother face on [his]39-cedric shoulder and cried bitterly , holding [him]39-cedric as if [she]151-his mother could never let [him]39-cedric go again . " Yes , [he]2410-my papa is well , "[151-his mother] [she]151-his mother sobbed ; " [he]2410-my papa is quite , quite well , but [we]2412-we [we]2412-we have [no one]2413-no one left but [each other]2414-each other . [No one]2413-no one at all . "[151-his mother] Then , little as [he]39-cedric was , [he]39-cedric understood that [[his]39-cedric big , handsome young papa]154-his big , handsome young papa would not come back any more ; that [he]154-his big , handsome young papa was dead , as [he]39-cedric had heard of [other people]155-other people being , although [he]39-cedric could not comprehend exactly what strange thing had brought all this sadness about . It was because [[his]39-cedric mamma]144-his mamma always cried when [he]39-cedric spoke of [[his]39-cedric papa]142-his papa that [he]39-cedric secretly made up [his]39-cedric mind it was better not to speak of [him]142-his papa very often to [her]144-his mamma , and [he]39-cedric found out , too , that it was better not to let [her]144-his mamma sit still and look into the fire or out of the window without moving or talking . [He]39-cedric and [[his]39-cedric mamma]144-his mamma knew [very few people]159-very few people , and lived what might have been thought very lonely lives , although [Cedric]39-cedric did not know it was lonely until [he]39-cedric grew older and heard why it was [they]160-they had [no visitors]161-no visitors . Then [he]39-cedric was told that [[his]39-cedric mamma]144-his mamma was [an orphan]163-an orphan , and quite alone in [the world]164-the world when [[his]39-cedric papa]142-his papa had married [her]144-his mamma . [She]144-his mamma was very pretty , and had been living as companion to [a rich old lady who was not kind to [her]144-his mamma]166-a rich old lady who was not kind to her , and one day [Captain Cedric Errol]39-cedric , who was calling at [the house]167-the house , saw [her]144-his mamma run up the stairs with tears on [her]144-his mamma eyelashes ; and [she]144-his mamma looked so sweet and innocent and sorrowful that [the Captain]168-the captain could not forget [her]144-his mamma . And after many strange things had happened , [they]160-they knew [each other]2414-each other well and loved [each other]2414-each other dearly , and were married , although [their]160-they marriage brought [them]160-they the ill - will of [several persons]171-several persons . The one who was most angry of all , however , was [[the Captain]168-the captain 's father , who lived in [England]1-england , and was [a very rich and important old nobleman]174-a very rich and important old nobleman , with a very bad temper and a very violent dislike to [America]2-america and [Americans]3-americans]173-the captain 's father , who lived in england , and was a very rich and important old nobleman , with a very bad temper and a very violent dislike to america and americans . [He]173-the captain 's father , who lived in england , and was a very rich and important old nobleman , with a very bad temper and a very violent dislike to america and americans had [two sons older than [Captain Cedric]39-cedric]175-two sons older than captain cedric ; and it was the law that [the elder of these sons]176-the elder of these sons should inherit the family title and estates , which were very rich and splendid ; if [the eldest son]177-the eldest son died , [the next one]178-the next one would be [heir]179-heir ; so , though [he]178-the next one was [a member of such a great family]180-a member of such a great family , there was little chance that [Captain Cedric]39-cedric would be very rich [himself]39-cedric . But it so happened that [Nature]40-nature had given to [the youngest son]181-the youngest son gifts which [she]40-nature had not bestowed upon [[his]181-the youngest son elder brothers]182-his elder brothers . [He]178-the next one had a beautiful face and a fine , strong , graceful figure ; [he]178-the next one had a bright smile and a sweet , gay voice ; [he]178-the next one was brave and generous , and had the kindest heart in [the world]164-the world , and seemed to have the power to make [every one]184-every one love [him]178-the next one . And it was not so with [[his]178-the next one elder brothers]182-his elder brothers ; neither of [them]182-his elder brothers was handsome , or very kind , or clever . When [they]182-his elder brothers were [boys at Eton]186-boys at eton , [they]182-his elder brothers were not popular ; when [they]182-his elder brothers were at college , [they]182-his elder brothers cared nothing for study , and wasted both time and money , and made [few real friends]187-few real friends . [The old Earl]41-dorincourt , [[their]182-his elder brothers father]188-their father , was constantly disappointed and humiliated by [them]182-his elder brothers ; [[his]41-dorincourt heir]189-his heir was no honor to [his]41-dorincourt noble name , and did not promise to end in being anything but [a selfish , wasteful , insignificant man , with no manly or noble qualities]190-a selfish , wasteful , insignificant man , with no manly or noble qualities . It was very bitter , [the old Earl]191-the old earl thought , that [the son who was only third]192-the son who was only third , and would have only a very small fortune , should be [the one who had all the gifts , and all the charms , and all the strength and beauty]193-the one who had all the gifts , and all the charms , and all the strength and beauty . Sometimes [he]191-the old earl almost hated [the handsome young man]194-the handsome young man because [he]194-the handsome young man seemed to have the good things which should have gone with the stately title and [the magnificent estates]195-the magnificent estates ; and yet , in the depths of [his]191-the old earl proud , stubborn old heart , [he]191-the old earl could not help caring very much for [[his]191-the old earl youngest son]196-his youngest son . It was in one of [his]191-the old earl fits of petulance that [he]191-the old earl sent [him]196-his youngest son off to travel in [America]2-america ; [he]191-the old earl thought [he]191-the old earl would send [him]196-his youngest son away for a while , so that [he]191-the old earl should not be made angry by constantly contrasting [him]196-his youngest son with [[his]191-the old earl brothers]197-his brothers , who were at that time giving [him]196-his youngest son a great deal of trouble by [their]197-his brothers wild ways . But , after about six months , [he]191-the old earl began to feel lonely , and longed in secret to see [[his]191-the old earl son]198-his son again , so [he]191-the old earl wrote to [Captain Cedric]39-cedric and ordered [him]39-cedric [home]199-home . The letter [he]191-the old earl wrote crossed on its way a letter [the Captain]168-the captain had just written to [[his]191-the old earl father]150-his father , telling of [his]191-the old earl love for [the pretty American girl]202-the pretty american girl , and of [his]191-the old earl intended marriage ; and when [the Earl]203-the earl received that letter [he]203-the earl was furiously angry . Bad as [his]203-the earl temper was , [he]203-the earl had never given way to it in [his]203-the earl life as [he]203-the earl gave way to it when [he]203-the earl read [the Captain]168-the captain 's letter . [[His]191-the old earl valet]205-his valet , who was in [the room]147-the room when it came , thought [[his]191-the old earl lordship]207-his lordship would have a fit of apoplexy , [he]191-the old earl was so wild with anger . For an hour [he]191-the old earl raged like a tiger , and then [he]191-the old earl sat down and wrote to [[his]191-the old earl son]198-his son , and ordered [him]198-his son never to come near [[his]203-the earl old home]209-his old home , nor to write to [[his]198-his son father]150-his father or [brothers]211-brothers again . [He]191-the old earl told [him]198-his son [he]198-his son might live as [he]198-his son pleased , and die where [he]198-his son pleased , that [he]198-his son should be cut off from [[his]198-his son family]212-his family forever , and that [he]198-his son need never expect help from [[his]198-his son father]150-his father as long as [he]198-his son lived . [The Captain]168-the captain was very sad when [he]168-the captain read the letter ; [he]168-the captain was very fond of [England]1-england , and [he]168-the captain dearly loved [the beautiful home where [he]168-the captain had been born]215-the beautiful home where he had been born ; [he]168-the captain had even loved [[his]198-his son ill - tempered old father]216-his ill - tempered old father , and had sympathized with [him]216-his ill - tempered old father in [his]216-his ill - tempered old father disappointments ; but [he]168-the captain knew [he]168-the captain need expect no kindness from [him]216-his ill - tempered old father in the future . At first [he]168-the captain scarcely knew what to do ; [he]168-the captain had not been brought up to work , and had no business experience , but [he]168-the captain had courage and plenty of determination . So [he]168-the captain sold [his]168-the captain commission in [the English army]217-the english army , and after some trouble found a situation in [New York]4-new york , and married . The change from [his]168-the captain old life in [England]1-england was very great , but [he]168-the captain was young and happy , and [he]168-the captain hoped that hard work would do great things for [him]168-the captain in the future . [He]168-the captain had [a small house on [a quiet street]219-a quiet street]218-a small house on a quiet street , and [[his]168-the captain little boy]220-his little boy was born [there]221-there , and everything was so gay and cheerful , in a simple way , that [he]168-the captain was never sorry for a moment that [he]168-the captain had married [[the rich old lady]222-the rich old lady 's pretty companion]223-the rich old lady 's pretty companion just because [she]223-the rich old lady 's pretty companion was so sweet and [he]168-the captain loved [her]223-the rich old lady 's pretty companion and [she]223-the rich old lady 's pretty companion loved [him]168-the captain . [She]223-the rich old lady 's pretty companion was very sweet , indeed , and [[her]223-the rich old lady 's pretty companion little boy]224-her little boy was like both [her]223-the rich old lady 's pretty companion and [[his]224-her little boy father]150-his father . Though [he]224-her little boy was born in so quiet and cheap [a little home]226-a little home , it seemed as if there never had been [a more fortunate baby]227-a more fortunate baby . In the first place , [he]224-her little boy was always well , and so [he]224-her little boy never gave any one trouble ; in the second place , [he]224-her little boy had so sweet a temper and ways so charming that [he]224-her little boy was a pleasure to [every one]184-every one ; and in the third place , [he]224-her little boy was so beautiful to look at that [he]224-her little boy was quite a picture . Instead of being [a bald - headed baby]229-a bald - headed baby , [he]224-her little boy started in life with a quantity of soft , fine , gold - colored hair , which curled up at the ends , and went into loose rings by the time [he]224-her little boy was six months old ; [he]224-her little boy had big brown eyes and long eyelashes and a darling little face ; [he]224-her little boy had so strong a back and such splendid sturdy legs , that at nine months [he]224-her little boy learned suddenly to walk ; [his]224-her little boy manners were so good , for [a baby]230-a baby , that it was delightful to make [his]224-her little boy acquaintance . [He]224-her little boy seemed to feel that [every one]184-every one was [[his]224-her little boy friend]232-his friend , and when [any one]233-any one spoke to [him]224-her little boy , when [he]224-her little boy was in [[his]224-her little boy carriage]234-his carriage in [the street]235-the street , [he]224-her little boy would give [the stranger]236-the stranger one sweet , serious look with the brown eyes , and then follow it with a lovely , friendly smile ; and the consequence was , that there was not [a person in [the neighborhood of the quiet street where [he]224-her little boy lived]238-the neighborhood of the quiet street where he lived even to [the groceryman at the corner]239-the groceryman at the corner , who was considered [the crossest creature alive who was not pleased to see [him]224-her little boy and speak to [him]224-her little boy]240-the crossest creature alive who was not pleased to see him and speak to him]237-a person in the neighborhood of the quiet street where he lived even to the groceryman at the corner , who was considered the crossest creature alive who was not pleased to see him and speak to him . And every month of [his]224-her little boy life [he]224-her little boy grew handsomer and more interesting . When [he]224-her little boy was old enough to walk out with [[his]224-her little boy nurse]241-his nurse , dragging [a small wagon]242-a small wagon and wearing a short white kilt skirt , and a big white hat set back on [his]224-her little boy curly yellow hair , [he]224-her little boy was so handsome and strong and rosy that [he]224-her little boy attracted [every one]184-every one 's attention , and [[his]224-her little boy nurse]241-his nurse would come [home]199-home and tell [[his]224-her little boy mamma]144-his mamma stories of [the ladies who had stopped [their]247-the ladies who had stopped their carriages carriages]247-the ladies who had stopped their carriages to look at and speak to [him]224-her little boy , and of how pleased [they]247-the ladies who had stopped their carriages were when [he]224-her little boy talked to [them]247-the ladies who had stopped their carriages in [his]224-her little boy cheerful little way , as if [he]224-her little boy had known [them]247-the ladies who had stopped their carriages always . [His]224-her little boy greatest charm was this cheerful , fearless , quaint little way of making friends with [people]248-people . [I]0-i think it arose from [his]224-her little boy having a very confiding nature , and a kind little heart that sympathized with [every one]184-every one , and wished to make every one as comfortable as [he]224-her little boy liked to be [himself]224-her little boy . It made [him]224-her little boy very quick to understand the feelings of those about [him]224-her little boy . Perhaps this had grown on [him]224-her little boy , too , because [he]224-her little boy had lived so much with [[his]224-her little boy father]150-his father and [mother]251-mother , who were always loving and considerate and tender and well - bred . [He]224-her little boy had never heard an unkind or uncourteous word spoken at [home]199-home ; [he]224-her little boy had always been loved and caressed and treated tenderly , and so [his]224-her little boy childish soul was full of kindness and innocent warm feeling . [He]224-her little boy had always heard [[his]224-her little boy mamma]144-his mamma called by pretty , loving names , and so [he]224-her little boy used them [himself]224-her little boy when [he]224-her little boy spoke to [her]144-his mamma ; [he]224-her little boy had always seen that [[his]224-her little boy papa]142-his papa watched over [her]144-his mamma and took great care of [her]144-his mamma , and so [he]224-her little boy learned , too , to be careful of [her]144-his mamma . So when [he]224-her little boy knew [[his]224-her little boy papa]142-his papa would come back no more , and saw how very sad [[his]224-her little boy mamma]144-his mamma was , there gradually came into [his]224-her little boy kind little heart the thought that [he]224-her little boy must do what [he]224-her little boy could to make [her]144-his mamma happy . [He]224-her little boy was not much more than [a baby]230-a baby , but that thought was in [his]224-her little boy mind whenever [he]224-her little boy climbed upon [her]144-his mamma knee and kissed [her]144-his mamma and put [his]224-her little boy curly head on [her]144-his mamma neck , and when [he]224-her little boy brought [his]224-her little boy toys and picture - books to show [her]144-his mamma , and when [he]224-her little boy curled up quietly by [her]144-his mamma side as [she]144-his mamma used to lie on the sofa . [He]224-her little boy was not old enough to know of anything else to do , so [he]224-her little boy did what [he]224-her little boy could , and was more of a comfort to [her]144-his mamma than [he]224-her little boy could have understood . " Oh , [Mary]42-mary ! "[144-his mamma] [he]224-her little boy heard [her]144-his mamma say once to [[her]144-his mamma old servant]258-her old servant ; " [I]144-his mamma am sure [he]224-her little boy is trying to help [me]144-his mamma in [his]224-her little boy innocent way [I]144-his mamma know [he]224-her little boy is . [He]224-her little boy looks at [me]144-his mamma sometimes with a loving , wondering little look , as if [he]224-her little boy were sorry for [me]144-his mamma , and then [he]224-her little boy will come and pet [me]144-his mamma or show [me]144-his mamma something . [He]258-her old servant is such [a little man]2416-a little man , [I]144-his mamma really think [he]258-her old servant knows . "[144-his mamma] As [he]258-her old servant grew older , [he]258-her old servant had a great many quaint little ways which amused and interested [people]248-people greatly . [He]258-her old servant was so much of [a companion for [[his]258-her old servant mother]151-his mother]260-a companion for his mother that [she]151-his mother scarcely cared for any other . [They]262-they used to walk together and talk together and play together . When [he]258-her old servant was quite [a little fellow]263-a little fellow , [he]258-her old servant learned to read ; and after that [he]258-her old servant used to lie on the hearth - rug , in the evening , and read aloud sometimes stories , and sometimes big books such as [older people]264-older people read , and sometimes even the newspaper ; and often at such times [Mary]42-mary , in [the kitchen]265-the kitchen , would hear [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol laughing with delight at the quaint things [he]258-her old servant said . " And , indade , "[42-mary] said [Mary]42-mary to [the groceryman]266-the groceryman , " [nobody]2417-nobody cud help laughin ' at the quare little ways of [him]258-her old servant and [his]258-her old servant ould - fashioned sayin 's ! Did n't [he]258-her old servant come into [[my]42-mary kitchen]2418-my kitchen the noight [the new Prisident]2419-the new prisident was nominated and shtand afore the fire , lookin ' loike a pictur ' , wid [his]258-her old servant hands in [his]258-her old servant shmall pockets , an ' [his]258-her old servant innocent bit of a face as sayrious as [a jedge]2420-a jedge ? An ' sez [he]258-her old servant to [me]42-mary : ' [Mary]42-mary , ' sez [he]258-her old servant , ' [I]42-mary 'm very much int'rusted in the ' lection , ' sez [he]258-her old servant . ' [I]42-mary 'm [a ' publican]2421-a ' publican , an ' so is [Dearest]2411-dearest . Are [you]258-her old servant [a ' publican]2421-a ' publican , [Mary]42-mary ? ' ' Sorra a bit , ' sez [I]42-mary ; ' [I]42-mary 'm [the bist o ' dimmycrats]2424-the bist o ' dimmycrats ! ' An ' [he]258-her old servant looks up at [me]42-mary wid a look that ud go to [yer]42-mary heart , an ' sez [he]258-her old servant : ' [Mary]42-mary , ' sez [he]258-her old servant , ' [the country]2425-the country will go to ruin . ' An ' nivver a day since thin has [he]258-her old servant let go by widout argyin ' wid [me]42-mary to change [me]42-mary polytics . "[42-mary] [Mary]42-mary was very fond of [him]267-his , and very proud of [him]267-his , too . [She]42-mary had been with [[his]267-his mother]151-his mother ever since [he]267-his was born ; and , after [[his]267-his father]150-his father 's death , had been [cook]270-cook and [housemaid]271-housemaid and [nurse]272-nurse and everything else . [She]42-mary was proud of [his]267-his graceful , strong little body and [his]267-his pretty manners , and especially proud of the bright curly hair which waved over [his]267-his forehead and fell in charming love - locks on [his]267-his shoulders . [She]42-mary was willing to work early and late to help [[his]267-his mamma]144-his mamma make [his]267-his small suits and keep them in order . " ' [Ristycratic]44-ristycratic , is it ? "[42-mary] [she]42-mary would say . " [Faith]45-faith , an ' [I]42-mary 'd loike to see the choild on [Fifth Avey - NOO]5-fifth avey - noo as looks loike [him]267-his an ' shteps out as handsome as [himself]267-his . An ' [ivvery man]2426-ivvery man , [woman]2427-woman , and choild lookin ' afther [him]267-his in [his]267-his bit of a black velvet skirt made out of the misthress 's ould gownd ; an ' [his]267-his little head up , an ' [his]267-his curly hair flyin ' an ' shinin ' . It 's loike [a young lord]2428-a young lord [he]267-his looks . "[42-mary] [Cedric]39-cedric did not know that [he]267-his looked like [a young lord]2428-a young lord ; [he]39-cedric did not know what [a lord]275-a lord was . [[His]39-cedric greatest friend]276-his greatest friend was [the groceryman at the corner [the cross groceryman , who was never cross to [him]39-cedric]278-the cross groceryman , who was never cross to him]277-the groceryman at the corner the cross groceryman , who was never cross to him . [His]276-his greatest friend name was [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , and [Cedric]39-cedric admired and respected [him]276-his greatest friend very much . [He]39-cedric thought [him]276-his greatest friend [a very rich and powerful person]279-a very rich and powerful person , [he]276-his greatest friend had so many things in [[his]276-his greatest friend store]280-his store , prunes and figs and oranges and biscuits , and [he]276-his greatest friend had [a horse and wagon]281-a horse and wagon . [Cedric]39-cedric was fond of [the milkman]282-the milkman and [the baker]283-the baker and [the apple - woman]284-the apple - woman , but [he]39-cedric liked [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs best of all , and was on terms of such intimacy with [him]46-mr. hobbs that [he]39-cedric went to see [him]46-mr. hobbs every day , and often sat with [him]46-mr. hobbs quite a long time , discussing the topics of the hour . It was quite surprising how many things [they]285-they found to talk about the Fourth of July , for instance . When [they]285-they began to talk about the Fourth of July there really seemed no end to it . [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs had a very bad opinion of " [the British]47-the british , "[46-mr. hobbs] and [he]46-mr. hobbs told the whole story of the Revolution , relating very wonderful and patriotic stories about the villainy of [the enemy]286-the enemy and the bravery of [the Revolutionary heroes]287-the revolutionary heroes , and [he]46-mr. hobbs even generously repeated part of the Declaration of Independence . [Cedric]39-cedric was so excited that [his]39-cedric eyes shone and [his]39-cedric cheeks were red and [his]39-cedric curls were all rubbed and tumbled into a yellow mop . [He]39-cedric could hardly wait to eat [his]39-cedric dinner after [he]39-cedric went [home]199-home , [he]39-cedric was so anxious to tell [[his]39-cedric mamma]144-his mamma . It was , perhaps , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs who gave [him]39-cedric [his]39-cedric first interest in politics . [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs was fond of reading the newspapers , and so [Cedric]39-cedric heard a great deal about what was going on in [Washington]6-washington ; and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs would tell [him]39-cedric whether [the President]290-the president was doing [his]290-the president duty or not . And once , when there was an election , [he]39-cedric found it all quite grand , and probably but for [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs and [Cedric]39-cedric [the country]2425-the country might have been wrecked . [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs took [him]39-cedric to see a great torchlight procession , and [many of [the men who carried torches]293-the men who carried torches]292-many of the men who carried torches remembered afterward [a stout man who stood near a lamp - post and held on [his]294-a stout man who stood near a lamp - post and held on his shoulder a handsome little shouting boy , who waved his cap in the air shoulder [a handsome little shouting boy , who waved [his]294-a stout man who stood near a lamp - post and held on his shoulder a handsome little shouting boy , who waved his cap in the air cap in the air]295-a handsome little shouting boy , who waved his cap in the air]294-a stout man who stood near a lamp - post and held on his shoulder a handsome little shouting boy , who waved his cap in the air . It was not long after this election , when [Cedric]39-cedric was between seven and eight years old , that the very strange thing happened which made so wonderful a change in [his]39-cedric life . It was quite curious , too , that the day it happened [he]39-cedric had been talking to [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs about [England]1-england and [the Queen]296-the queen , and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs had said some very severe things about [the aristocracy]297-the aristocracy , being specially indignant against [earls]298-earls and [marquises]299-marquises . It had been a hot morning ; and after playing [soldiers]300-soldiers with [some friends of]301-some friends of [his]39-cedric , [Cedric]39-cedric had gone into [the store]302-the store to rest , and had found [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs looking very fierce over a piece of the Illustrated [London]7-london News , which contained a picture of some court ceremony . " Ah , "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said , " that 's the way [they]297-the aristocracy go on now ; but [they]297-the aristocracy 'll get enough of it some day , when those [they]297-the aristocracy 've trod on rise and blow 'em up sky - high , [earls and marquises]2429-earls and marquises and all ! It 's coming , and [they]297-the aristocracy may look out for it ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [Cedric]39-cedric had perched [himself]39-cedric as usual on the high stool and pushed [his]39-cedric hat back , and put [his]39-cedric hands in [his]39-cedric pockets in delicate compliment to [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . " Did [you]46-mr. hobbs ever know [many marquises]2430-many marquises , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs ? "[39-cedric] [Cedric]39-cedric inquired , " or [earls]298-earls ? "[39-cedric] " No , "[46-mr. hobbs] answered [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , with indignation ; " [I]46-mr. hobbs guess not . [I]46-mr. hobbs 'd like to catch one of ['em]2432-'em inside [here]2433-here ; that 's all ! [I]46-mr. hobbs 'll have no grasping tyrants sittin ' ' round on [my]46-mr. hobbs cracker - barrels ! "[46-mr. hobbs] And [he]46-mr. hobbs was so proud of the sentiment that [he]46-mr. hobbs looked around proudly and mopped [his]46-mr. hobbs forehead . " Perhaps [they]303-they would n't be [earls]298-earls if [they]303-they knew any better , "[39-cedric] said [Cedric]39-cedric , feeling some vague sympathy for [their]303-they unhappy condition . " Would n't [they]303-they ! "[46-mr. hobbs] said [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . " [They]303-they just glory in it ! [It]2435-it 's in 'em . [They]303-they 're a bad lot . "[46-mr. hobbs] [They]304-they were in the midst of [their]304-they conversation , when [Mary]42-mary appeared . [Cedric]39-cedric thought [she]42-mary had come to buy some sugar , perhaps , but [she]42-mary had not . [She]42-mary looked almost pale and as if [she]42-mary were excited about something . " Come [home]199-home , [darlint]2437-darlint , "[42-mary] [she]42-mary said ; " [the misthress]2438-the misthress is wantin ' yez . "[42-mary] [Cedric]39-cedric slipped down from [his]39-cedric stool . " Does [she]42-mary want [me]39-cedric to go out with [her]42-mary , [Mary]42-mary ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric asked . " Good - morning , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . [I]39-cedric 'll see [you]46-mr. hobbs again . "[39-cedric] [He]39-cedric was surprised to see [Mary]42-mary staring at [him]39-cedric in a dumfounded fashion , and [he]39-cedric wondered why [she]42-mary kept shaking [her]42-mary head . " What 's the matter , [Mary]42-mary ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said . " Is it the hot weather ? "[39-cedric] " No , "[42-mary] said [Mary]42-mary ; " but there 's strange things happenin ' to [us]2439-us . "[42-mary] " Has the sun given [Dearest]48-dearest a headache ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric inquired anxiously . But it was not that . When [he]39-cedric reached [[his]39-cedric own house]305-his own house there was [a coupe standing before the door]306-a coupe standing before the door and [some one]307-some one was in [the little parlor]308-the little parlor talking to [[his]39-cedric mamma]144-his mamma . [Mary]42-mary hurried [him]39-cedric [upstairs]310-upstairs and put on [his]39-cedric best summer suit of cream - colored flannel , with the red scarf around [his]39-cedric waist , and combed out [his]39-cedric curly locks . " [Lords]2440-lords , is it ? "[42-mary] [he]39-cedric heard [her]42-mary say . " An ' [the nobility]2441-the nobility an ' gintry . Och ! bad cess to [them]2440-lords ! [Lords]2440-lords , indade worse luck . "[42-mary] It was really very puzzling , but [he]39-cedric felt sure [[his]39-cedric mamma]144-his mamma would tell [him]39-cedric what all the excitement meant , so [he]39-cedric allowed [Mary]42-mary to bemoan [herself]42-mary without asking many questions . When [he]39-cedric was dressed , [he]39-cedric ran [downstairs]312-downstairs and went into [the parlor]313-the parlor . [A tall , thin old gentleman with a sharp face]314-a tall , thin old gentleman with a sharp face was sitting in an arm - chair . [[His]39-cedric mother]151-his mother was standing near by with a pale face , and [he]39-cedric saw that there were tears in [her]151-his mother eyes . " Oh ! [Ceddie]49-ceddie ! "[151-his mother] [she]151-his mother cried out , and ran to [[her]151-his mother little boy]224-her little boy and caught [him]224-her little boy in [her]151-his mother arms and kissed [him]224-her little boy in a frightened , troubled way . " Oh ! [Ceddie]49-ceddie , [darling]2443-darling ! "[317-the tall old gentleman] [The tall old gentleman]317-the tall old gentleman rose from [his]317-the tall old gentleman chair and looked at [Cedric]39-cedric with [his]317-the tall old gentleman sharp eyes . [He]317-the tall old gentleman rubbed [his]317-the tall old gentleman thin chin with [his]317-the tall old gentleman bony hand as [he]317-the tall old gentleman looked . [He]317-the tall old gentleman seemed not at all displeased . " And so , "[317-the tall old gentleman] [he]317-the tall old gentleman said at last , slowly , " and so this is [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . "[317-the tall old gentleman]

II

There was never [a more amazed little boy]318-a more amazed little boy than [Cedric]39-cedric during the week that followed ; there was never so strange or so unreal a week . In the first place , the story [[his]39-cedric mamma]144-his mamma told [him]39-cedric was a very curious one . [He]39-cedric was obliged to hear it two or three times before [he]39-cedric could understand it . [He]39-cedric could not imagine what [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs would think of it . It began with [earls]298-earls : [[his]39-cedric grandpapa , whom [he]39-cedric had never seen]321-his grandpapa , whom he had never seen , was [an earl]322-an earl ; and [[his]39-cedric eldest uncle]323-his eldest uncle , if [he]323-his eldest uncle had not been killed by a fall from [his]323-his eldest uncle horse , would have been [an earl]322-an earl , too , in time ; and after [his]323-his eldest uncle death , [[his]39-cedric other uncle]325-his other uncle would have been [an earl]322-an earl , if [he]325-his other uncle had not died suddenly , in [Rome]8-rome , of a fever . After that , [[his]39-cedric own papa]327-his own papa , if [he]327-his own papa had lived , would have been [an earl]322-an earl , but , since [they]329-they all had died and only [Cedric]39-cedric was left , it appeared that [HE]39-cedric was to be [an earl]322-an earl after [[his]39-cedric grandpapa]331-his grandpapa 's death and for the present [he]39-cedric was [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . [He]39-cedric turned quite pale when [he]39-cedric was first told of it . " Oh ! [Dearest]2411-dearest ! "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said , " [I]39-cedric should rather not be [an earl]322-an earl . [None of [the boys]2447-the boys]2446-none of the boys are [earls]298-earls . Ca n't [I]39-cedric NOT be [one]2449-one ? "[39-cedric] But it seemed to be unavoidable . And when , that evening , [they]332-they sat together by the open window looking out into [the shabby street]333-the shabby street , [he]39-cedric and [[his]39-cedric mother]151-his mother had a long talk about it . [Cedric]39-cedric sat on [his]39-cedric footstool , clasping one knee in [his]39-cedric favorite attitude and wearing a bewildered little face rather red from the exertion of thinking . [[His]39-cedric grandfather]335-his grandfather had sent for [him]39-cedric to come to [England]1-england , and [[his]39-cedric mamma]144-his mamma thought [he]39-cedric must go . " Because , "[144-his mamma] [she]144-his mamma said , looking out of the window with sorrowful eyes , " [I]144-his mamma know [[your]39-cedric papa]2450-your papa would wish it to be so , [Ceddie]49-ceddie . [He]2450-your papa loved [[his]2450-your papa home]2451-his home very much ; and there are many things to be thought of that [a little boy]2452-a little boy ca n't quite understand . [I]144-his mamma should be [a selfish little mother]2453-a selfish little mother if [I]144-his mamma did not send [you]39-cedric . When [you]39-cedric are [a man]2454-a man , [you]39-cedric will see why . "[144-his mamma] [Ceddie]49-ceddie shook [his]49-ceddie head mournfully . " [I]49-ceddie shall be very sorry to leave [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , "[49-ceddie] [he]49-ceddie said . " [I]49-ceddie 'm afraid [he]46-mr. hobbs 'll miss [me]49-ceddie , and [I]49-ceddie shall miss [him]46-mr. hobbs . And [I]49-ceddie shall miss [them]2455-them all . "[49-ceddie] When [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham who was [the family lawyer of [the Earl of Dorincourt]41-dorincourt , and who had been sent by [him]51-mr. havisham to bring [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy to [England]1-england]337-the family lawyer of the earl of dorincourt , and who had been sent by him to bring lord fauntleroy to england came the next day , [Cedric]39-cedric heard many things . But , somehow , it did not console [him]39-cedric to hear that [he]39-cedric was to be [a very rich man]338-a very rich man when [he]39-cedric grew up , and that [he]39-cedric would have [castles]339-castles [here]2433-here and [castles]339-castles [there]221-there , and [great parks]343-great parks and [deep mines]344-deep mines and [grand estates and tenantry]345-grand estates and tenantry . [He]39-cedric was troubled about [[his]39-cedric friend]232-his friend , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , and [he]39-cedric went to see [him]46-mr. hobbs at [the store]302-the store soon after breakfast , in great anxiety of mind . [He]39-cedric found [him]46-mr. hobbs reading the morning paper , and [he]39-cedric approached [him]46-mr. hobbs with a grave demeanor . [He]39-cedric really felt it would be a great shock to [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs to hear what had befallen [him]39-cedric , and on [his]39-cedric way to [the store]302-the store [he]39-cedric had been thinking how it would be best to break the news . " Hello ! "[46-mr. hobbs] said [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . " Mornin ' ! "[46-mr. hobbs] " Good - morning , "[39-cedric] said [Cedric]39-cedric . [He]39-cedric did not climb up on the high stool as usual , but sat down on a cracker - box and clasped [his]39-cedric knee , and was so silent for a few moments that [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs finally looked up inquiringly over the top of [his]46-mr. hobbs newspaper . " Hello ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said again . [Cedric]39-cedric gathered all [his]39-cedric strength of mind together . " [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said , " do [you]46-mr. hobbs remember what [we]349-we were talking about yesterday morning ? "[39-cedric] " Well , "[46-mr. hobbs] replied [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , ' seems to [me]0-i it was [England]1-england . " "[39-cedric] Yes , " said [Cedric]39-cedric ; "[39-cedric] but just when [Mary]42-mary came for [me]0-i , [you]46-mr. hobbs know ? " [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs rubbed the back of [his]46-mr. hobbs head . "[42-mary] [We]349-we WAS mentioning [Queen Victoria]52-queen victoria and [the aristocracy]297-the aristocracy . " "[52-queen victoria] Yes , " said [Cedric]39-cedric , rather hesitatingly , "[52-queen victoria] and and earls ; do n't [you]46-mr. hobbs know ? " "[46-mr. hobbs] Why , yes , " returned [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs ; "[349-we] [we]349-we DID touch 'em up a little ; that 's so ! " [Cedric]39-cedric flushed up to the curly bang on [his]39-cedric forehead . Nothing so embarrassing as this had ever happened to [him]39-cedric in [his]39-cedric life . [He]39-cedric was a little afraid that it might be a trifle embarrassing to [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , too . "[46-mr. hobbs] [You]46-mr. hobbs said , " [he]39-cedric proceeded , "[46-mr. hobbs] that [you]46-mr. hobbs would n't have [them]351-them sitting ' round on [your]46-mr. hobbs cracker - barrels . " "[46-mr. hobbs] So [I]0-i did ! " returned [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , stoutly . "[0-i] And [I]0-i meant it . Let 'em try it that 's all ! " "[46-mr. hobbs] [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , " said [Cedric]39-cedric , "[46-mr. hobbs] one is sitting on this box now ! " [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs almost jumped out of [his]46-mr. hobbs chair . "[46-mr. hobbs] What ! " [he]46-mr. hobbs exclaimed . "[46-mr. hobbs] Yes , " [Cedric]39-cedric announced , with due modesty ; "[46-mr. hobbs] [I]0-i am one or [I]0-i am going to be . [I]0-i wo n't deceive [you]46-mr. hobbs . " [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs looked agitated . [He]46-mr. hobbs rose up suddenly and went to look at the thermometer . "[0-i] The mercury 's got into [your]46-mr. hobbs head ! " [he]46-mr. hobbs exclaimed , turning back to examine [[his]46-mr. hobbs young friend]2456-his young friend 's countenance . "[0-i] It IS a hot day ! How do [you]46-mr. hobbs feel ? Got any pain ? When did [you]46-mr. hobbs begin to feel that way ? " [He]46-mr. hobbs put [his]46-mr. hobbs big hand on [the little boy]153-the little boy 's hair . This was more embarrassing than ever . "[46-mr. hobbs] Thank [you]46-mr. hobbs , " said [Ceddie]49-ceddie ; "[46-mr. hobbs] [I]0-i 'm all right . There is nothing the matter with [my]0-i head . [I]0-i 'm sorry to say it 's true , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . That was what [Mary]42-mary came to take [me]0-i [home]199-home for . [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham was telling [[my]0-i mamma]353-my mamma , and [he]51-mr. havisham is [a lawyer]354-a lawyer . " [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs sank into [his]46-mr. hobbs chair and mopped [his]46-mr. hobbs forehead with [his]46-mr. hobbs handkerchief . "[51-mr. havisham] [ONE of [us]356-us]355-one of us has got a sunstroke ! " [he]46-mr. hobbs exclaimed . "[51-mr. havisham] No , " returned [Cedric]39-cedric , "[51-mr. havisham] [we]356-us have n't . [We]356-us shall have to make the best of it , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham came all the way from [England]1-england to tell [us]356-us about it . [[My]0-i grandpapa]357-my grandpapa sent [him]51-mr. havisham . " [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs stared wildly at the innocent , serious little face before [him]46-mr. hobbs . "[51-mr. havisham] Who is [[your]46-mr. hobbs grandfather]358-your grandfather ? " [he]46-mr. hobbs asked . [Cedric]39-cedric put [his]39-cedric hand in [his]39-cedric pocket and carefully drew out a piece of paper , on which something was written in [his]39-cedric own round , irregular hand . "[0-i] [I]0-i could n't easily remember it , so [I]0-i wrote it down on this , " [he]0-i said . And [he]0-i read aloud slowly : "[0-i] ' [John Arthur Molyneux Errol]53-molyneux , [Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]359-earl of dorincourt . ' That is [his]358-your grandfather name , and [he]358-your grandfather lives in [a castle in [two or three castles]361-two or three castles]360-a castle in two or three castles , [I]0-i think . And [[my]0-i papa]2410-my papa , who died , was [[his]358-your grandfather youngest son]196-his youngest son ; and [I]0-i should n't have been [a lord]275-a lord or [an earl]322-an earl if [[my]0-i papa]2410-my papa had n't died ; and [[my]0-i papa]2410-my papa would n't have been [an earl]322-an earl if [[his]2410-my papa two brothers]369-his two brothers had n't died . But [they]369-his two brothers all died , and there is [no one]2413-no one but [me]0-i , [no boy]371-no boy , and so [I]0-i have to be [one]2449-one ; and [[my]0-i grandpapa]357-my grandpapa has sent for [me]0-i to come to [England]1-england . " [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs seemed to grow hotter and hotter . [He]46-mr. hobbs mopped [his]46-mr. hobbs forehead and [his]46-mr. hobbs bald spot and breathed hard . " Remembering the glimpse [he]426-ma'am had caught of [the store]302-the store as [he]426-ma'am passed [it]302-the store , and having a recollection of the barrels of potatoes and apples and the various odds and ends , [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham felt [his]51-mr. havisham doubts arise again . [He]426-ma'am was thinking uneasily about this as [he]426-ma'am talked to [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol until [the child]2539-the child came into [the room]147-the room . When the door opened , [he]426-ma'am actually hesitated a moment before looking at [Cedric]39-cedric . It would , perhaps , have seemed very queer to [a great many people who knew [him]39-cedric]2548-a great many people who knew him , if [they]2548-a great many people who knew him could have known the curious sensations that passed through [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham when [he]51-mr. havisham looked down at [the boy]2518-the boy , who ran into [[his]2544-this boy mother]151-his mother 's arms . [He]51-mr. havisham experienced a revulsion of feeling which was quite exciting . [He]51-mr. havisham recognized in an instant that here was one of [the finest and handsomest little fellows [he]51-mr. havisham had ever seen]2551-the finest and handsomest little fellows he had ever seen . [His]39-cedric beauty was something unusual . [He]39-cedric had a strong , lithe , graceful little body and a manly little face ; [he]39-cedric held [his]39-cedric childish head up , and carried [himself]39-cedric with a brave air ; [he]39-cedric was so like [[his]2544-this boy father]150-his father that it was really startling ; [he]39-cedric had [[his]2544-this boy father]150-his father 's golden hair and [[his]2544-this boy mother]151-his mother 's brown eyes , but there was nothing sorrowful or timid in them . [They]2555-they were innocently fearless eyes ; [he]39-cedric looked as if [he]39-cedric had never feared or doubted anything in [his]39-cedric life . "[431-he] [He]431-he is [the best - bred - looking and handsomest little fellow [I]0-i ever saw]432-the best - bred - looking and handsomest little fellow i ever saw , " was what [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham thought . What [he]51-mr. havisham said aloud was simply , "[431-he] And so this is [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . [Dick]59-dick says so . [He]59-dick is n't a credit to the business , and [he]59-dick is n't square . [He]59-dick cheats , and that makes [Dick]59-dick mad . It would make [you]512-you mad , [you]512-you know , if [you]512-you were blacking boots as hard as [you]512-you could , and being square all the time , and [[your]512-you partner]513-your partner was n't square at all . [People]248-people like [Dick]59-dick , but [they]248-people do n't like [Jake]60-jake , and so sometimes [they]248-people do n't come twice . So if [I]0-i were rich , [I]0-i 'd buy [Jake]60-jake out and get [Dick]59-dick a ' [boss]515-boss ' sign [he]59-dick says a ' boss ' sign goes a long way ; and [I]0-i 'd get [him]59-dick some new clothes and new brushes , and start [him]59-dick out fair . [He]59-dick says all [he]59-dick wants is to start out fair . " There could have been nothing more confiding and innocent than the way in which [[his]59-dick small lordship]2614-his small lordship told [his]59-dick little story , quoting [[his]59-dick friend]232-his friend [Dick]59-dick 's bits of slang in the most candid good faith . [He]59-dick seemed to feel not a shade of a doubt that [[his]59-dick elderly companion]2616-his elderly companion would be just as interested as [he]59-dick was [himself]59-dick . [He]51-mr. havisham went to the window and stood looking out into [the street]235-the street reflectively . [He]51-mr. havisham was thinking of [the old Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]41-dorincourt , sitting in [[his]41-dorincourt great , splendid , gloomy library at [the castle]402-the castle]2646-his great , splendid , gloomy library at the castle , gouty and lonely , surrounded by grandeur and luxury , but not really loved by [any one]233-any one , because in all [his]41-dorincourt long life [he]41-dorincourt had never really loved [any one]233-any one but [himself]41-dorincourt ; [he]41-dorincourt had been selfish and self - indulgent and arrogant and passionate ; [he]41-dorincourt had cared so much for [the Earl of Dorincourt]41-dorincourt and [his]41-dorincourt pleasures that there had been no time for [him]41-dorincourt to think of [other people]155-other people ; all [his]41-dorincourt wealth and power , all the benefits from [his]41-dorincourt noble name and high rank , had seemed to [him]41-dorincourt to be things only to be used to amuse and give pleasure to [the Earl of Dorincourt]41-dorincourt ; and now that [he]41-dorincourt was [an old man]393-an old man , all this excitement and self - indulgence had only brought [him]41-dorincourt ill health and irritability and a dislike of [the world]164-the world , which certainly disliked [him]41-dorincourt . In spite of all [his]41-dorincourt splendor , there was never [a more unpopular old nobleman]2653-a more unpopular old nobleman than [the Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]2471-the earl of dorincourt , and there could scarcely have been [a more lonely one]2655-a more lonely one . [He]41-dorincourt could fill [[his]41-dorincourt castle]2656-his castle with [guests]2657-guests if [he]41-dorincourt chose . [He]41-dorincourt could give great dinners and splendid hunting parties ; but [he]41-dorincourt knew that in secret [the people who would accept [his]41-dorincourt invitations]2658-the people who would accept his invitations were afraid of [his]41-dorincourt frowning old face and sarcastic , biting speeches . [He]41-dorincourt had a cruel tongue and a bitter nature , and [he]41-dorincourt took pleasure in sneering at [people]248-people and making [them]248-people feel uncomfortable , when [he]41-dorincourt had the power to do so , because [they]248-people were sensitive or proud or timid . [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham knew [his]41-dorincourt hard , fierce ways by heart , and [he]51-mr. havisham was thinking of [him]41-dorincourt as [he]51-mr. havisham looked out of the window into [the narrow , quiet street]2660-the narrow , quiet street . And there rose in [his]51-mr. havisham mind , in sharp contrast , the picture of [the cheery , handsome little fellow]2661-the cheery , handsome little fellow sitting in the big chair and telling [his]41-dorincourt story of [[his]41-dorincourt friends]2619-his friends , [Dick]59-dick and [the apple - woman]284-the apple - woman , in [his]41-dorincourt generous , innocent , honest way . And [he]51-mr. havisham thought of the immense income , [the beautiful , majestic estates]2664-the beautiful , majestic estates , the wealth , and power for good or evil , which in the course of time would lie in the small , chubby hands [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy thrust so deep into [his]41-dorincourt pockets . "[0-i] It will make a great difference , " [he]51-mr. havisham said to [himself]51-mr. havisham . "[0-i] It will make a great difference . " [Cedric]39-cedric and [[his]39-cedric mother]151-his mother came back soon after . [Cedric]39-cedric was in high spirits . "[572-she] [She]572-she said [she]572-she was crying for joy ! [I]0-i never saw [any one]233-any one cry for joy before . [[My]0-i grandpapa]357-my grandpapa must be [a very good man]575-a very good man . [I]0-i did n't know [he]357-my grandpapa was [so good a man]576-so good a man . [III

Cedric]65-cedric 's good opinion of the advantages of being [an earl]322-an earl increased greatly during the next week . It seemed almost impossible for [him]357-my grandpapa to realize that there was scarcely anything [he]357-my grandpapa might wish to do which [he]357-my grandpapa could not do easily ; in fact , [I]0-i think it may be said that [he]357-my grandpapa did not fully realize it at all . But at least [he]357-my grandpapa understood , after a few conversations with [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham , that [he]357-my grandpapa could gratify all [his]357-my grandpapa nearest wishes , and [he]357-my grandpapa proceeded to gratify them with a simplicity and delight which caused [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham much diversion . In the week before [they]579-they sailed for [England]1-england [he]357-my grandpapa did many curious things . [The lawyer]2506-the lawyer long after remembered the morning [they]579-they went down - [town]509-town together to pay a visit to [Dick]59-dick , and the afternoon [they]579-they so amazed [the apple - woman of ancient lineage]582-the apple - woman of ancient lineage by stopping before [her]582-the apple - woman of ancient lineage stall and telling [her]582-the apple - woman of ancient lineage [she]582-the apple - woman of ancient lineage was to have [a tent]583-a tent , and a stove , and a shawl , and a sum of money which seemed to [her]582-the apple - woman of ancient lineage quite wonderful . " For [I]65-cedric have to go to [England]1-england and be [a lord]275-a lord , "[65-cedric] explained [Cedric]65-cedric , sweet - temperedly . " And [I]65-cedric should n't like to have [your]2669-you bones on [my]65-cedric mind every time it rained . [My]65-cedric own bones never hurt , so [I]65-cedric think [I]65-cedric do n't know how painful [a person]492-a person 's bones can be , but [I]65-cedric 've sympathized with [you]2669-you a great deal , and [I]65-cedric hope [you]2669-you 'll be better . "[65-cedric] " [She]585-the proprietress of the stall 's [a very good apple - woman]2671-a very good apple - woman , "[65-cedric] [he]65-cedric said to [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham , as [they]584-they walked away , leaving [the proprietress of the stall]585-the proprietress of the stall almost gasping for breath , and not at all believing in [her]585-the proprietress of the stall great fortune . " Once , when [I]65-cedric fell down and cut [my]65-cedric knee , [she]585-the proprietress of the stall gave [me]65-cedric an apple for nothing . [I]65-cedric 've always remembered [her]585-the proprietress of the stall for it . [You]65-cedric know [you]65-cedric always remember [people who are kind to [you]65-cedric]2672-people who are kind to you . "[65-cedric] It had never occurred to [his]65-cedric honest , simple little mind that there were [people who could forget kindnesses]586-people who could forget kindnesses . The interview with [Dick]59-dick was quite exciting . [Dick]59-dick had just been having a great deal of trouble with [Jake]60-jake , and was in low spirits when [they]584-they saw [him]59-dick . [His]59-dick amazement when [Cedric]65-cedric calmly announced that [they]584-they had come to give [him]59-dick what seemed a very great thing to [him]59-dick , and would set all [his]59-dick troubles right , almost struck [him]59-dick dumb . [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's manner of announcing the object of [his]50-fauntleroy visit was very simple and unceremonious . [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham was much impressed by its directness as [he]51-mr. havisham stood by and listened . The statement that [[his]51-mr. havisham old friend]587-his old friend had become [a lord]275-a lord , and was in danger of being [an earl]322-an earl if [he]50-fauntleroy lived long enough , caused [Dick]59-dick to so open [his]59-dick eyes and mouth , and start , that [his]59-dick cap fell off . When [he]59-dick picked it up , [he]59-dick uttered a rather singular exclamation . [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham thought it singular , but [Cedric]65-cedric had heard it before . " [I]59-dick soy ! "[59-dick] [he]59-dick said , " what 're [yer]207-his lordship givin ' [us]2673-us ? "[59-dick] This plainly embarrassed [[his]51-mr. havisham lordship]207-his lordship a little , but [he]51-mr. havisham bore [himself]51-mr. havisham bravely . " [Everybody]452-everybody thinks it not true at first , "[51-mr. havisham] [he]51-mr. havisham said . " [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs thought [I]51-mr. havisham 'd had a sunstroke . [I]51-mr. havisham did n't think [I]51-mr. havisham was going to like it [myself]51-mr. havisham , but [I]51-mr. havisham like it better now [I]51-mr. havisham 'm used to it . "[51-mr. havisham] And the end of the matter was that [Dick]59-dick actually bought [Jake]60-jake out , and found [himself]59-dick the possessor of the business and some new brushes and a most astonishing sign and outfit . At last all the preparations were complete ; the day came when the trunks were taken to [the steamer]601-the steamer , and the hour arrived when [the carriage]602-the carriage stood at the door . Then a curious feeling of loneliness came upon [the little boy]153-the little boy . [[His]153-the little boy mamma]144-his mamma had been shut up in [[her]144-his mamma room]605-her room for some time ; when [she]144-his mamma came down [the stairs]606-the stairs , [her]144-his mamma eyes looked large and wet , and [her]144-his mamma sweet mouth was trembling . [Cedric]39-cedric went to [her]144-his mamma , and [she]144-his mamma bent down to [him]39-cedric , and [he]39-cedric put [his]39-cedric arms around [her]144-his mamma , and [they]607-we kissed [each other]2414-each other . [He]39-cedric knew something made [them]607-we both sorry , though [he]39-cedric scarcely knew what it was ; but one tender little thought rose to [his]39-cedric lips . " [We]607-we liked [this little house]2690-this little house , [Dearest]48-dearest , did n't [we]607-we ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said . " [We]607-we always will like it , wo n't [we]607-we ? "[39-cedric] " Yes yes , "[144-his mamma] [she]144-his mamma answered , in a low , sweet voice . " Yes , [darling]2443-darling . "[144-his mamma] And then [they]607-we went into [the carriage]602-the carriage and [Cedric]39-cedric sat very close to [her]144-his mamma , and as [she]144-his mamma looked back out of the window , [he]39-cedric looked at [her]144-his mamma and stroked [her]144-his mamma hand and held it close . And then , it seemed almost directly , [they]607-we were on [the steamer]601-the steamer in the midst of the wildest bustle and confusion ; [carriages]611-carriages were driving down and leaving [passengers]612-passengers ; [passengers]612-passengers were getting into a state of excitement about baggage which had not arrived and threatened to be too late ; big trunks and cases were being bumped down and dragged about ; [sailors]614-sailors were uncoiling ropes and hurrying to and fro ; [officers]615-officers were giving orders ; [ladies]2464-ladies and [gentlemen]2465-gentlemen and [children]2556-children and [nurses]619-nurses were coming on board , [some]620-some were laughing and looked gay , [some]620-some were silent and sad , here and there [two or three]622-two or three were crying and touching [their]622-two or three eyes with [their]622-two or three handkerchiefs . [Cedric]39-cedric found something to interest [him]39-cedric on every side ; [he]39-cedric looked at the piles of rope , at the furled sails , at the tall , tall masts which seemed almost to touch the hot blue sky ; [he]39-cedric began to make plans for conversing with [the sailors]623-the sailors and gaining some information on the subject of [pirates]624-pirates . It was just at the very last , when [he]39-cedric was standing leaning on the railing of [the upper deck]625-the upper deck and watching the final preparations , enjoying the excitement and the shouts of [the sailors]623-the sailors and [wharfmen]627-wharfmen , that [his]39-cedric attention was called to a slight bustle in one of [the groups not far from [him]39-cedric]628-the groups not far from him . [Some one]307-some one was hurriedly forcing [his]307-some one way through [this group]630-this group and coming toward [him]39-cedric . [It]307-some one was [a boy]441-a boy , with something red in [his]441-a boy hand . It was [Dick]59-dick . [He]441-a boy came up to [Cedric]39-cedric quite breathless . " [I]441-a boy 've run all the way , "[441-a boy] [he]441-a boy said . " [I]441-a boy 've come down to see [ye]39-cedric off . Trade 's been prime ! [I]441-a boy bought this for [ye]39-cedric out o ' what [I]441-a boy made yesterday . [Ye]39-cedric kin wear it when [ye]39-cedric get among the swells . [I]441-a boy lost the paper when [I]441-a boy was tryin ' to get through [them]632-they fellers [downstairs]312-downstairs . [They]632-they did n't want to let [me]441-a boy up . It 's a hankercher . "[441-a boy] [He]441-a boy poured it all forth as if in one sentence . A bell rang , and [he]441-a boy made a leap away before [Cedric]39-cedric had time to speak . " Good - bye ! "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric panted . " Wear it when [ye]39-cedric get among the swells . "[39-cedric] And [he]441-a boy darted off and was gone . [He]39-cedric stood on [the wharf]636-the wharf and waved [his]39-cedric cap . [Cedric]39-cedric held the handkerchief in [his]39-cedric hand . "[50-fauntleroy] as [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy steamed slowly away from [the home of [his]50-fauntleroy birth]647-the home of his birth to [the unknown land of [[his]50-fauntleroy ancestors]649-his ancestors]648-the unknown land of his ancestors .

[IV]67-iv

It was during the voyage that [[Cedric]39-cedric 's mother]2508-cedric 's mother told [him]39-cedric that [[his]39-cedric home]2451-his home was not to be [hers]2508-cedric 's mother ; and when [he]39-cedric first understood it , [his]39-cedric grief was so great that [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham saw that [the Earl]203-the earl had been wise in making the arrangements that [[his]39-cedric mother]151-his mother should be quite near [him]39-cedric , and see [him]39-cedric often ; for it was very plain [he]39-cedric could not have borne the separation otherwise . But [[his]39-cedric mother]151-his mother managed [the little fellow]655-the little fellow so sweetly and lovingly , and made [him]39-cedric feel that [she]151-his mother would be so near [him]39-cedric , that , after a while , [he]39-cedric ceased to be oppressed by the fear of any real parting . " [[My]151-his mother house]2695-my house is not far from [the Castle]402-the castle , [Ceddie]64-ceddie , "[151-his mother] [she]151-his mother repeated each time the subject was referred to " a very little way from [yours]64-ceddie , and [you]64-ceddie can always run in and see [me]151-his mother every day , and [you]64-ceddie will have so many things to tell [me]151-his mother ! and [we]2697-we shall be so happy together ! It is [a beautiful place]2698-a beautiful place . [[Your]64-ceddie papa]2450-your papa has often told [me]151-his mother about it . [He]2450-your papa loved it very much ; and [you]64-ceddie will love it too . "[151-his mother] " [I]2614-his small lordship should love it better if [you]43-mrs. errol were there , "[2614-his small lordship] [[his]39-cedric small lordship]2614-his small lordship said , with a heavy little sigh . [He]39-cedric could not but feel puzzled by so strange a state of affairs , which could put [his]39-cedric " Dearest "[43-mrs. errol] in [one house]657-one house and [himself]39-cedric in another . The fact was that [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol had thought it better not to tell [him]39-cedric why this plan had been made . " [I]43-mrs. errol should prefer [he]39-cedric should not be told , "[43-mrs. errol] [she]43-mrs. errol said to [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham . " [He]39-cedric would not really understand ; [he]39-cedric would only be shocked and hurt ; and [I]43-mrs. errol feel sure that [his]39-cedric feeling for [the Earl]203-the earl will be a more natural and affectionate one if [he]39-cedric does not know that [[his]39-cedric grandfather]335-his grandfather dislikes [me]43-mrs. errol so bitterly . [He]39-cedric has never seen hatred or hardness , and it would be a great blow to [him]39-cedric to find out that [any one]233-any one could hate [me]43-mrs. errol . [He]39-cedric is so loving [himself]39-cedric , and [I]43-mrs. errol am so dear to [him]39-cedric ! It is better for [him]39-cedric that [he]39-cedric should not be told until [he]39-cedric is much older , and it is far better for [the Earl]203-the earl . It would make a barrier between [them]2704-them , even though [Ceddie]64-ceddie is such [a child]2490-a child . "[43-mrs. errol] [So Cedric]39-cedric only knew that there was some mysterious reason for the arrangement , some reason which [he]658-he was not old enough to understand , but which would be explained when [he]658-he was older . [He]658-he was puzzled ; but , after all , it was not the reason [he]658-he cared about so much ; and after many talks with [[his]658-he mother]151-his mother , in which [she]151-his mother comforted [him]658-he and placed before [him]658-he the bright side of the picture , the dark side of it gradually began to fade out , though now and then [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham saw [him]658-he sitting in some queer little old - fashioned attitude , watching [the sea]660-the sea , with a very grave face , and more than once [he]51-mr. havisham heard an unchildish sigh rise to [his]51-mr. havisham lips . " [I]51-mr. havisham do n't like it , "[51-mr. havisham] [he]51-mr. havisham said once as [he]51-mr. havisham was having one of [his]51-mr. havisham almost venerable talks with [the lawyer]2506-the lawyer . " [You]2506-the lawyer do n't know how much [I]51-mr. havisham do n't like it ; but there are a great many troubles in [this world]2706-this world , and [you]2506-the lawyer have to bear them . [Mary]42-mary says so , and [I]51-mr. havisham 've heard [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs say it too . And [Dearest]48-dearest wants [me]51-mr. havisham to like to live with [[my]51-mr. havisham grandpapa]357-my grandpapa , because , [you]2506-the lawyer see , [all [his]357-my grandpapa children]2708-all his children are dead , and that 's very mournful . It makes [you]2506-the lawyer sorry for [a man]2454-a man , when all [[his]357-my grandpapa children]2710-his children have died and [one was killed suddenly]2711-one was killed suddenly . "[51-mr. havisham] One of the things which always delighted [the people who made the acquaintance of [[his]663-his young lordship]2570-his young lordship]662-the people who made the acquaintance of his young lordship was the sage little air [he]663-his wore at times when [he]663-his gave [himself]663-his up to conversation ; combined with [his]663-his occasionally elderly remarks and the extreme innocence and seriousness of [his]663-his round childish face , it was irresistible . [He]663-his was such [a handsome , blooming , curly - headed little fellow]665-a handsome , blooming , curly - headed little fellow , that , when [he]663-his sat down and nursed [his]663-his knee with [his]663-his chubby hands , and conversed with much gravity , [he]663-his was a source of great entertainment to [[his]663-his hearers]666-his hearers . [Gradually Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham had begun to derive a great deal of private pleasure and amusement from [[his]663-his society]667-his society . " And so [you]2712-you are going to try to like [the Earl]203-the earl , "[663-his] [he]663-his said . " Yes , "[663-his] answered [[his]663-his lordship]207-his lordship . " [He]203-the earl 's [[my]663-his relation]2714-my relation , and of course [you]2712-you have to like [[your]2712-you relations]2715-your relations ; and besides , [he]203-the earl 's been very kind to [me]663-his . "[663-his] " Do [you]51-mr. havisham think , "[51-mr. havisham] suggested [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham , " that [he]203-the earl will be fond of [you]51-mr. havisham ? "[51-mr. havisham] " Well , "[39-cedric] said [Cedric]39-cedric , " [I]39-cedric think [he]203-the earl will , because , [you]51-mr. havisham see , [I]39-cedric 'm [[his]203-the earl relation]2719-his relation , too , and [I]39-cedric 'm [[his]203-the earl boy 's little boy]2720-his boy 's little boy besides , and , well , do n't [you]51-mr. havisham see of course [he]203-the earl must be fond of [me]39-cedric now , or [he]203-the earl would n't want [me]39-cedric to have everything that [I]39-cedric like , and [he]203-the earl would n't have sent [you]51-mr. havisham for [me]39-cedric . "[39-cedric] " Oh ! "[2506-the lawyer] remarked [the lawyer]2506-the lawyer , " that 's it , is it ? "[2506-the lawyer] " Yes , "[39-cedric] said [Cedric]39-cedric , " that 's it . Do n't [you]51-mr. havisham think that 's it , too ? Of course [a man]2454-a man would be fond of [[his]2454-a man grandson]538-his grandson . "[39-cedric] [The people who had been seasick]670-the people who had been seasick had no sooner recovered from [their]670-the people who had been seasick seasickness , and come on [deck]671-deck to recline in [their]670-the people who had been seasick steamer - chairs and enjoy [themselves]670-the people who had been seasick , than [every one]184-every one seemed to know the romantic story of [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , and [every one]184-every one took an interest in [the little fellow]655-the little fellow , who ran about [the ship]675-the ship or walked with [[his]655-the little fellow mother]151-his mother or [the tall , thin old lawyer]677-the tall , thin old lawyer , or talked to [the sailors]623-the sailors . [Every one]184-every one liked [him]655-the little fellow ; [he]655-the little fellow made [friends]378-friends everywhere . [He]655-the little fellow was ever ready to make [friends]378-friends . When [the gentlemen]682-the gentlemen walked up and down [the deck]683-the deck , and let [him]655-the little fellow walk with [them]682-the gentlemen , [he]655-the little fellow stepped out with [a manly , sturdy little tramp]684-a manly , sturdy little tramp , and answered all [their]682-the gentlemen jokes with much gay enjoyment ; when [the ladies]685-the ladies talked to [him]655-the little fellow , there was always laughter in the group of which [he]655-the little fellow was the center ; when [he]655-the little fellow played with [the children]686-the children , there was always magnificent fun on hand . Among [the sailors]623-the sailors [he]655-the little fellow had [the heartiest friends]688-the heartiest friends ; [he]655-the little fellow heard miraculous stories about [pirates]624-pirates and shipwrecks and [desert islands]690-desert islands ; [he]655-the little fellow learned to splice ropes and rig [toy ships]691-toy ships , and gained an amount of information concerning " tops'ls "[655-the little fellow] and " mains'ls , "[655-the little fellow] quite surprising . [His]655-the little fellow conversation had , indeed , quite a nautical flavor at times , and on one occasion [he]655-the little fellow raised a shout of laughter in [a group of [ladies]2464-ladies]692-a group of ladies and [gentlemen who were sitting on deck , wrapped in shawls and overcoats]694-gentlemen who were sitting on deck , wrapped in shawls and overcoats , by saying sweetly , and with a very engaging expression : " Shiver [my]655-the little fellow timbers , but it 's a cold day ! "[655-the little fellow] It surprised [him]655-the little fellow when [they]692-a group of ladies laughed . [He]655-the little fellow had picked up this sea - faring remark from [an " elderly naval man]2723-an " elderly naval man "[655-the little fellow] of the name of [Jerry]68-jerry , who told [him]655-the little fellow stories in which it occurred frequently . To judge from [his]655-the little fellow stories of [his]655-the little fellow own adventures , [Jerry]68-jerry had made some two or three thousand voyages , and had been invariably shipwrecked on each occasion on [an island densely populated with [bloodthirsty cannibals]696-bloodthirsty cannibals]695-an island densely populated with bloodthirsty cannibals . Judging , also , by these same exciting adventures , [he]655-the little fellow had been partially roasted and eaten frequently and had been scalped some fifteen or twenty times . " That is why [he]655-the little fellow is so bald , "[50-fauntleroy] explained [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy to [[his]50-fauntleroy mamma]144-his mamma . " After [you]2724-you have been scalped several times the hair never grows again . [Jerry]68-jerry 's never grew again after that last time , when [the King of [the Parromachaweekins]69-the parromachaweekins]2725-the king of the parromachaweekins did it with the knife made out of the skull of [the Chief of [the Wopslemumpkies]70-the wopslemumpkies]2726-the chief of the wopslemumpkies . [He]655-the little fellow says it was one of the most serious times [he]655-the little fellow ever had . [He]655-the little fellow was so frightened that [his]655-the little fellow hair stood right straight up when [the king]2727-the king flourished [his]2727-the king knife , and it never would lie down , and [the king]2727-the king wears it that way now , and it looks something like a hair - brush . [I]50-fauntleroy never heard anything like the asperiences [Jerry]68-jerry has had ! [I]50-fauntleroy should so like to tell [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs about [them]2729-them ! "[50-fauntleroy] Sometimes , when the weather was very disagreeable and [people]248-people were kept below [decks]699-decks in [the saloon]700-the saloon , [a party of [[his]702-his grown - up friends]703-his grown - up friends]701-a party of his grown - up friends would persuade [him]702-his to tell [them]703-his grown - up friends some of these " asperiences "[68-jerry] of [Jerry]68-jerry 's , and as [he]702-his sat relating them with great delight and fervor , there was certainly no more popular voyager on [any ocean steamer crossing [the Atlantic]15-the atlantic]704-any ocean steamer crossing the atlantic than [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . [He]702-his was always innocently and good - naturedly ready to do [his]702-his small best to add to the general entertainment , and there was a charm in the very unconsciousness of [his]702-his own childish importance . " [Jerry]68-jerry 's stories int'rust [them]703-his grown - up friends very much , "[702-his] [he]702-his said to [[his]702-his mamma]144-his mamma . " For [my]702-his part [you]144-his mamma must excuse [me]702-his , [Dearest]2411-dearest but sometimes [I]702-his should have thought [they]703-his grown - up friends could n't be all quite true , if [they]703-his grown - up friends had n't happened to [Jerry]68-jerry [himself]68-jerry ; but as [they]703-his grown - up friends all happened to [Jerry]68-jerry well , it 's very strange , [you]144-his mamma know , and perhaps sometimes [he]68-jerry may forget and be a little mistaken , as [he]68-jerry 's been scalped so often . Being scalped a great many times might make [a person]492-a person forgetful . "[702-his] It was eleven days after [he]702-his had said good - bye to [[his]702-his friend]232-his friend [Dick]59-dick before [he]702-his reached [Liverpool]14-liverpool ; and it was on the night of the twelfth day that [the carriage]602-the carriage in which [he]702-his and [[his]702-his mother]151-his mother and [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham had driven from [the station]709-the station stopped before the gates of [Court Lodge]16-court lodge . [They]710-them could not see much of [the house]167-the house in the darkness . [Cedric]39-cedric only saw that there was a drive - way under great arching trees , and after [the carriage]602-the carriage had rolled down [this drive - way]713-this drive - way a short distance , [he]39-cedric saw an open door and a stream of bright light coming through it . [Mary]42-mary had come with [them]710-them to attend [[her]42-mary mistress]714-her mistress , and [she]42-mary had reached [the house]167-the house before [them]710-them . [He]51-mr. havisham seldom argued with [[his]51-mr. havisham lordly patron]2779-his lordly patron , never when [[his]51-mr. havisham lordly patron]2779-his lordly patron 's noble leg was inflamed by gout .
