" "[43-mrs. errol] No , " said [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham . "[43-mrs. errol] [I]0-i have another message , which will prove to [you]785-you that [she]43-mrs. errol has not done that . " "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't want to hear it ! " panted [the Earl]203-the earl , out of breath with anger and excitement and gout . But [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham delivered it . "[43-mrs. errol] [She]43-mrs. errol asks [you]785-you not to let [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy hear anything which would lead [him]50-fauntleroy to understand that [you]785-you separate [him]50-fauntleroy from [her]43-mrs. errol because of [your]785-you prejudice against [her]43-mrs. errol . [He]50-fauntleroy is very fond of [her]43-mrs. errol , and [she]43-mrs. errol is convinced that it would cause a barrier to exist between [you]785-you . [She]43-mrs. errol says [he]50-fauntleroy would not comprehend it , and it might make [him]50-fauntleroy fear [you]785-you in some measure , or at least cause [him]50-fauntleroy to feel less affection for [you]785-you . [She]43-mrs. errol has told [him]50-fauntleroy that [he]50-fauntleroy is too young to understand the reason , but shall hear it when [he]50-fauntleroy is older . [She]43-mrs. errol wishes that there should be no shadow on [your]785-you first meeting . " [The Earl]203-the earl sank back into [his]203-the earl chair . [His]203-the earl deep - set fierce old eyes gleamed under [his]203-the earl beetling brows . "[43-mrs. errol] Come , now ! " [he]203-the earl said , still breathlessly . "[43-mrs. errol] Come , now ! [You]786-you do n't mean [the mother]2567-the mother has n't told [him]50-fauntleroy ? " "[2567-the mother] Not one word , [[my]0-i lord]762-my lord , " replied [the lawyer]2506-the lawyer coolly . "[2567-the mother] That [I]0-i can assure [you]785-you . [The child]2539-the child is prepared to believe [you]785-you the most amiable and affectionate of [grandparents]790-grandparents . Nothing absolutely nothing has been said to [him]50-fauntleroy to give [him]50-fauntleroy the slightest doubt of [your]785-you perfection . And as [I]0-i carried out [your]785-you commands in every detail , while in [New York]4-new york , [he]50-fauntleroy certainly regards [you]785-you as a wonder of generosity . " "[50-fauntleroy] [He]50-fauntleroy does , eh ? " said [the Earl]203-the earl . "[50-fauntleroy] [I]0-i give [you]785-you [my]0-i word of honor , " said [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham , "[0-i] that [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's impressions of [you]785-you will depend entirely upon [yourself]785-you . And if [you]785-you will pardon the liberty [I]0-i take in making the suggestion , [I]0-i think [you]785-you will succeed better with [him]50-fauntleroy if [you]785-you take the precaution not to speak slightingly of [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother . " "[785-you] Pooh , pooh ! " said [the Earl]203-the earl . "[785-you] [The youngster]792-the youngster is only seven years old ! " "[50-fauntleroy] [He]50-fauntleroy has spent those seven years at [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother 's side , " returned [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham ; "[151-his mother] and [she]151-his mother has all [his]50-fauntleroy affection . "[151-his mother]

V

It was late in the afternoon when [the carriage]602-the carriage containing [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy and [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham drove up [the long avenue]795-the long avenue which led to [the castle]402-the castle . [The Earl]203-the earl had given orders that [[his]203-the earl grandson]538-his grandson should arrive in time to dine with [him]203-the earl ; and for some reason best known to [himself]203-the earl , [he]203-the earl had also ordered that [the child]2539-the child should be sent alone into [the room in which [he]203-the earl intended to receive [him]2539-the child]800-the room in which he intended to receive him . As [the carriage]602-the carriage rolled up [the avenue]802-the avenue , [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy sat leaning comfortably against the luxurious cushions , and regarded the prospect with great interest . [He]50-fauntleroy was , in fact , interested in everything [he]50-fauntleroy saw . [He]50-fauntleroy had been interested in [the carriage]602-the carriage , with [its]602-the carriage large , splendid horses and [their]602-the carriage glittering harness ; [he]50-fauntleroy had been interested in [the tall coachman]804-the tall coachman and footman , with [their]602-the carriage resplendent livery ; and [he]50-fauntleroy had been especially interested in the coronet on the panels , and had struck up an acquaintance with [the footman]805-the footman for the purpose of inquiring what it meant . When [the carriage]602-the carriage reached the great gates of [the park]403-the park , [he]50-fauntleroy looked out of the window to get a good view of the huge stone lions ornamenting the entrance . The gates were opened by [a motherly , rosy - looking woman]808-a motherly , rosy - looking woman , who came out of [a pretty , ivy - covered lodge]809-a pretty , ivy - covered lodge . [Two children]810-two children ran out of the door of [the house]167-the house and stood looking with round , wide - open eyes at [the little boy in [the carriage]602-the carriage , who looked at [them]810-two children also]812-the little boy in the carriage , who looked at them also . [[Their]810-two children mother]814-their mother stood courtesying and smiling , and [the children]686-the children , on receiving a sign from [her]808-a motherly , rosy - looking woman , made bobbing little courtesies too . " Does [she]808-a motherly , rosy - looking woman know [me]50-fauntleroy ? "[50-fauntleroy] asked [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . " [I]50-fauntleroy think [she]808-a motherly , rosy - looking woman must think [she]808-a motherly , rosy - looking woman knows [me]50-fauntleroy . "[50-fauntleroy] And [he]50-fauntleroy took off [his]50-fauntleroy black velvet cap to [her]808-a motherly , rosy - looking woman and smiled . " How do [you]808-a motherly , rosy - looking woman do ? "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy said brightly . " Good - afternoon ! "[50-fauntleroy] [The woman]816-the woman seemed pleased , [he]50-fauntleroy thought . The smile broadened on [her]816-the woman rosy face and a kind look came into [her]816-the woman blue eyes . " God bless [[your]50-fauntleroy lordship]2792-your lordship ! "[816-the woman] [she]816-the woman said . " God bless [your]50-fauntleroy pretty face ! Good luck and happiness to [[your]50-fauntleroy lordship]2792-your lordship ! Welcome to [you]50-fauntleroy ! "[816-the woman] [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy waved [his]50-fauntleroy cap and nodded to [her]816-the woman again as [the carriage]602-the carriage rolled by [her]816-the woman . " [I]50-fauntleroy like [that woman]2794-that woman , "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy said . " [She]2794-that woman looks as if [she]2794-that woman liked [boys]2558-boys . [I]50-fauntleroy should like to come here and play with [[her]2794-that woman children]2796-her children . [I]50-fauntleroy wonder if [she]2794-that woman has enough to make up [a company]522-a company ? "[50-fauntleroy] [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham did not tell [him]50-fauntleroy that [he]51-mr. havisham would scarcely be allowed to make [playmates of [the gate - keeper]819-the gate - keeper 's children]818-playmates of the gate - keeper 's children . [The lawyer]2506-the lawyer thought there was time enough for giving [him]50-fauntleroy that information . [The carriage]602-the carriage rolled on and on between the great , beautiful trees which grew on each side of [the avenue]802-the avenue and stretched [their]823-their broad , swaying branches in an arch across it . [Cedric]39-cedric had never seen such trees , they were so grand and stately , and their branches grew so low down on their huge trunks . [He]39-cedric did not then know that [Dorincourt Castle]11-dorincourt castle was one of [the most beautiful in [all England]825-all england]824-the most beautiful in all england ; that [[its]11-dorincourt castle park]826-its park was one of the broadest and finest , and [its]11-dorincourt castle trees and [avenue]827-avenue almost without rivals . But [he]39-cedric did know that it was all very beautiful . [He]39-cedric liked the big , broad - branched trees , with the late afternoon sunlight striking golden lances through them . [He]39-cedric liked the perfect stillness which rested on everything . [He]39-cedric felt a great , strange pleasure in the beauty of which [he]39-cedric caught glimpses under and between the sweeping boughs the great , beautiful spaces of [the park]403-the park , with still other trees standing sometimes stately and alone , and sometimes in groups . Now and then [they]829-they passed places where tall ferns grew in masses , and again and again [the ground]830-the ground was azure with the bluebells swaying in the soft breeze . Several times [he]39-cedric started up with a laugh of delight as a rabbit leaped up from under the greenery and scudded away with a twinkle of short white tail behind it . Once a covey of partridges rose with a sudden whir and flew away , and then [he]39-cedric shouted and clapped [his]39-cedric hands . " It 's [a beautiful place]2698-a beautiful place , is n't [it]2698-a beautiful place ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said to [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham . " [I]39-cedric never saw such [a beautiful place]2698-a beautiful place . [It]2698-a beautiful place 's prettier even than [Central Park]17-central park . "[39-cedric] [He]39-cedric was rather puzzled by the length of time [they]829-they were on [their]829-they way . " How far is it , "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said , at length , " from the gate to the front door ? "[39-cedric] " [It]2698-a beautiful place is between three and four miles , "[2506-the lawyer] answered [the lawyer]2506-the lawyer . " That 's a long way for [a person]492-a person to live from [his]492-a person gate , "[207-his lordship] remarked [[his]39-cedric lordship]207-his lordship . Every few minutes [he]39-cedric saw something new to wonder at and admire . When [he]39-cedric caught sight of the deer , some couched in the grass , some standing with [their]833-their pretty antlered heads turned with a half - startled air toward [the avenue]802-the avenue as the carriage wheels disturbed [them]833-their , [he]39-cedric was enchanted . " Has there been [a circus]2801-a circus ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric cried ; " or do [they]2801-a circus live [here]2433-here always ? Whose are [they]2801-a circus ? "[51-mr. havisham] It was not long after this that [they]835-they saw [the castle]402-the castle . [It]402-the castle rose up before [them]835-they stately and beautiful and gray , the last rays of the sun casting dazzling lights on [its]402-the castle many windows . [It]402-the castle had turrets and battlements and towers ; a great deal of ivy grew upon [its]402-the castle walls ; all the broad , open space about [it]402-the castle was laid out in terraces and lawns and beds of brilliant flowers . " [It]402-the castle 's [the most beautiful place [I]39-cedric ever saw]2805-the most beautiful place i ever saw ! " [It]402-the castle reminds [any one of [[a king]443-a king 's palace]2808-a king 's palace]2806-any one of a king 's palace . [I]39-cedric saw a picture of one once in a fairy - book . "[39-cedric] [He]39-cedric saw the great entrance - door thrown open and [many servants]837-many servants standing in two lines looking at [him]39-cedric . [He]39-cedric wondered why [they]837-many servants were standing [there]221-there , and admired [their]837-many servants liveries very much . [He]39-cedric did not know that [they]837-many servants were there to do honor to [the little boy to whom all this splendor]839-the little boy to whom all this splendor would one day belong , [the beautiful castle like [the fairy king]841-the fairy king 's palace]840-the beautiful castle like the fairy king 's palace , [the magnificent park]842-the magnificent park , the grand old trees , [the dells full of ferns]843-the dells full of ferns and bluebells where the hares and rabbits played , the dappled , large - eyed deer couching in the deep grass . It was only a couple of weeks since [he]39-cedric had sat with [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs among the potatoes and canned peaches , with [his]39-cedric legs dangling from the high stool ; it would not have been possible for [him]39-cedric to realize that [he]39-cedric had very much to do with all this grandeur . "[72-mrs. mellon] A few minutes later , [the very tall footman in livery]851-the very tall footman in livery , who had escorted [Cedric]39-cedric to [the library]2817-the library door , opened it and announced : " [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , [[my]851-the very tall footman in livery lord]762-my lord , "[851-the very tall footman in livery] in quite a majestic tone . [Cedric]39-cedric crossed the threshold into [the room]147-the room . It was [a very large and splendid room]859-a very large and splendid room , with massive carven furniture in [it]859-a very large and splendid room , and shelves upon shelves of books ; the furniture was so dark , and the draperies so heavy , the diamond - paned windows were so deep , and it seemed such a distance from one end of [it]859-a very large and splendid room to the other , that , since the sun had gone down , the effect of it all was rather gloomy . For a moment [Cedric]39-cedric thought there was [nobody]2417-nobody in [the room]147-the room , but soon [he]39-cedric saw that by the fire burning on the wide hearth there was a large easy - chair and that in [that chair]862-that chair [some one]307-some one was sitting [some one who did not at first turn to look at [him]39-cedric]864-some one who did not at first turn to look at him . But [he]39-cedric had attracted attention in one quarter at least . On the floor , by the arm - chair , lay a dog , a huge tawny mastiff , with body and limbs almost as big as a lion 's ; and [this great creature]865-this great creature rose majestically and slowly , and marched toward [the little fellow]655-the little fellow with a heavy step . Then [the person in the chair]867-the person in the chair spoke . " [Dougal]73-dougal , "[867-the person in the chair] [he]867-the person in the chair called , " come back , [sir]2681-sir . "[867-the person in the chair] But there was no more fear in [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's heart than there was unkindness [he]655-the little fellow had been [a brave little fellow]868-a brave little fellow all [his]655-the little fellow life . [He]39-cedric put [his]39-cedric hand on the big dog 's collar in the most natural way in [the world]164-the world , and [they]870-they strayed forward together , [Dougal]73-dougal sniffing as [he]73-dougal went . And then [the Earl]203-the earl looked up . "[39-cedric] " Ha ! "[207-his lordship] ejaculated [[his]203-the earl lordship]207-his lordship . " That 's it , is it ? "[203-the earl] [He]203-the earl drew [his]203-the earl shaggy eyebrows together and looked at [the child]2539-the child sharply . And [you]897-the old nobleman see [Michael]62-michael had the fever "[50-fauntleroy] " Who 's [Michael]62-michael ? "[203-the earl] asked [the Earl]203-the earl . " [Michael]62-michael is [[Bridget]61-bridget 's husband]2838-bridget 's husband , and [they]2836-they were in great trouble . When [a man]2454-a man is sick and ca n't work and has [twelve children]519-twelve children , [you]897-the old nobleman know how it is . And [Michael]62-michael has always been [a sober man]2841-a sober man . And [Bridget]61-bridget used to come to [[our]2842-our house]2843-our house and cry . And the evening [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham was [there]221-there , [she]61-bridget was in [the kitchen]265-the kitchen crying , because [they]2836-they had almost nothing to eat and could n't pay the rent ; and [I]203-the earl went in to see [her]61-bridget , and [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham sent for [me]203-the earl and [he]51-mr. havisham said [you]897-the old nobleman had given [him]51-mr. havisham some money for [me]203-the earl . "[203-the earl] [Dougal]73-dougal had been sitting by the tall chair ; the great dog had taken its place there when [Cedric]39-cedric sat down . Several times [it]73-dougal had turned and looked up at [the boy]2518-the boy as if interested in the conversation . [Dougal]73-dougal was a solemn dog , who seemed to feel altogether too big to take life 's responsibilities lightly . [The old Earl , who knew the dog well , had watched [it]73-dougal with secret interest]41-dorincourt . [Dougal]73-dougal was not a dog whose habit it was to make acquaintances rashly , and [the Earl]203-the earl wondered somewhat to see how quietly [the brute]906-the brute sat under the touch of the childish hand . And , just at this moment , the big dog gave [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy one more look of dignified scrutiny , and deliberately laid [its]73-dougal huge , lion - like head on [the boy]2518-the boy 's black - velvet knee . The small hand went on stroking [this new friend]908-this new friend as [Cedric]39-cedric answered : " Well , there was [Dick]59-dick , "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said . " [You]2518-the boy 'd like [Dick]59-dick , [he]59-dick 's so square . "[39-cedric] This was an Americanism [the Earl]203-the earl was not prepared for . " What does that mean ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric inquired . [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy paused a moment to reflect . [He]39-cedric was not very sure [himself]39-cedric what it meant . [He]39-cedric had taken it for granted as meaning something very creditable because [Dick]59-dick had been fond of using it . "[2570-his young lordship] The sensations of [the Right Honorable [the Earl of Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]913-the right honorable the earl of dorincourt could scarcely be described . [He]41-dorincourt was not [an old nobleman who was very easily bewildered , because [he]41-dorincourt had seen a great deal of [the world]164-the world]914-an old nobleman who was very easily bewildered , because he had seen a great deal of the world ; but here was something [he]41-dorincourt found so novel that it almost took [his]41-dorincourt lordly breath away , and caused [him]41-dorincourt some singular emotions . [He]41-dorincourt had never cared for [children]2556-children ; [he]41-dorincourt had been so occupied with [his]41-dorincourt own pleasures that [he]41-dorincourt had never had time to care for [them]2556-children . [[His]41-dorincourt own sons]917-his own sons had not interested [him]41-dorincourt when [they]917-his own sons were very young though sometimes [he]41-dorincourt remembered having thought [[Cedric]39-cedric 's father]918-cedric 's father [a handsome and strong little fellow]919-a handsome and strong little fellow . [He]41-dorincourt had been so selfish [himself]41-dorincourt that [he]41-dorincourt had missed the pleasure of seeing unselfishness in [others]436-others , and [he]41-dorincourt had not known how tender and faithful and affectionate [a kind - hearted little child]921-a kind - hearted little child can be , and how innocent and unconscious are its simple , generous impulses . [A boy]441-a boy had always seemed to [him]41-dorincourt a most objectionable little animal , selfish and greedy and boisterous when not under strict restraint ; [[his]41-dorincourt own two eldest sons]923-his own two eldest sons had given [[their]923-his own two eldest sons tutors]2560-their tutors constant trouble and annoyance , and of the younger one [he]41-dorincourt fancied [he]41-dorincourt had heard few complaints because [the boy]2518-the boy was of no particular importance . It had never once occurred to [him]41-dorincourt that [he]41-dorincourt should like [[his]41-dorincourt grandson]538-his grandson ; [he]41-dorincourt had sent for [the little Cedric]927-the little cedric because [his]41-dorincourt pride impelled [him]41-dorincourt to do so . If [the boy]2518-the boy was to take [his]2518-the boy place in the future , [he]41-dorincourt did not wish [his]2518-the boy name to be made ridiculous by descending to [an uneducated boor]929-an uneducated boor . [He]41-dorincourt had been convinced [the boy]2518-the boy would be [a clownish fellow]931-a clownish fellow if [he]2518-the boy were brought up in [America]2-america . [He]41-dorincourt had no feeling of affection for [the lad]545-the lad ; [his]41-dorincourt only hope was that [he]41-dorincourt should find [him]545-the lad decently well - featured , and with a respectable share of sense ; [he]41-dorincourt had been so disappointed in [[his]41-dorincourt other sons]933-his other sons , and had been made so furious by [Captain Errol]39-cedric 's American marriage , that [he]41-dorincourt had never once thought that anything creditable could come of it . When [the footman]805-the footman had announced [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , [he]805-the footman had almost dreaded to look at [the boy]2518-the boy lest [he]805-the footman should find [him]2518-the boy all that [he]805-the footman had feared . It was because of this feeling that [he]805-the footman had ordered that [the child]2539-the child should be sent to [him]805-the footman alone . [His]41-dorincourt pride could not endure that [others]436-others should see [his]41-dorincourt disappointment if [he]41-dorincourt was to be disappointed . [His]41-dorincourt proud , stubborn old heart therefore had leaped within [him]41-dorincourt when [the boy]2518-the boy came forward with [his]2518-the boy graceful , easy carriage , [his]2518-the boy fearless hand on the big dog 's neck . Even in the moments when [he]41-dorincourt had hoped the most , [the Earl]203-the earl had never hoped that [[his]41-dorincourt grandson]538-his grandson would look like that . It seemed almost too good to be true that this should be [the boy [he]41-dorincourt had dreaded to see the child of [the woman [he]41-dorincourt so disliked [this little fellow with so much beauty and such a brave , childish grace]943-this little fellow with so much beauty and such a brave , childish grace]942-the woman he so disliked this little fellow with so much beauty and such a brave , childish grace]941-the boy he had dreaded to see the child of the woman he so disliked this little fellow with so much beauty and such a brave , childish grace ! [The Earl]203-the earl 's stern composure was quite shaken by this startling surprise . And then [their]945-their talk began ; and [he]41-dorincourt was still more curiously moved , and more and more puzzled . In the first place , [he]41-dorincourt was so used to seeing [people]248-people rather afraid and embarrassed before [him]41-dorincourt , that [he]41-dorincourt had expected nothing else but that [[his]41-dorincourt grandson]538-his grandson would be timid or shy . But [Cedric]39-cedric was no more afraid of [the Earl]203-the earl than [he]39-cedric had been of [Dougal]73-dougal . [He]39-cedric was not bold ; [he]39-cedric was only innocently friendly , and [he]39-cedric was not conscious that there could be any reason why [he]39-cedric should be awkward or afraid . [The Earl]41-dorincourt could not help seeing that [the little boy]153-the little boy took [him]153-the little boy for [a friend]950-a friend and treated [him]153-the little boy as [one]2449-one , without having any doubt of [him]153-the little boy at all . It was quite plain as [the little fellow]655-the little fellow sat there in [his]655-the little fellow tall chair and talked in [his]655-the little fellow friendly way that it had never occurred to [him]41-dorincourt that [this large , fierce - looking old man]953-this large , fierce - looking old man could be anything but kind to [him]41-dorincourt , and rather pleased to see [him]41-dorincourt [there]221-there . And it was plain , too , that , in [his]41-dorincourt childish way , [he]41-dorincourt wished to please and interest [[his]41-dorincourt grandfather]335-his grandfather . [Cross]74-cross , and hard - hearted , and worldly as [the old Earl]191-the old earl was , [he]41-dorincourt could not help feeling a secret and novel pleasure in this very confidence . After all , it was not disagreeable to meet [some one who did not distrust [him]41-dorincourt or shrink from [him]41-dorincourt , or seem to detect the ugly part of [his]41-dorincourt nature]957-some one who did not distrust him or shrink from him , or seem to detect the ugly part of his nature ; [some one who looked at [him]41-dorincourt with clear , unsuspecting eyes , if it was only [a little boy in a black velvet suit]959-a little boy in a black velvet suit . So [the old man]960-the old man leaned back in [his]960-the old man chair , and led [[his]960-the old man young companion]961-his young companion]958-some one who looked at him with clear , unsuspecting eyes , if it was only a little boy in a black velvet suit . so the old man leaned back in his chair , and led his young companion on to telling [him]961-his young companion still more of [himself]960-the old man , and with that odd gleam in [his]960-the old man eyes watched [the little fellow]655-the little fellow as [he]960-the old man talked . [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy was quite willing to answer all [his]50-fauntleroy questions and chatted on in [his]50-fauntleroy genial little way quite composedly . [He]50-fauntleroy told [him]50-fauntleroy all about [Dick]59-dick and [Jake]60-jake , and [the apple - woman]284-the apple - woman , and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs ; [he]50-fauntleroy described the Republican Rally in all the glory of [its]964-its banners and transparencies , torches and rockets . In the course of the conversation , [he]50-fauntleroy reached [the Fourth of July and the Revolution]965-the fourth of july and the revolution , and was just becoming enthusiastic , when [he]50-fauntleroy suddenly recollected something and stopped very abruptly . " What is the matter ? "[50-fauntleroy] demanded [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather . " Why do n't [you]203-the earl go on ? [He]41-dorincourt hated [America]2-america and [Americans]394-americans , but it amused [him]41-dorincourt to see how serious and interested [this small patriot]972-this small patriot was . "[39-cedric] [The big footman]978-the big footman almost periled [his]39-cedric reputation and [his]39-cedric situation by smiling . But [he]978-the big footman had a very narrow escape . [He]978-the big footman only just saved [himself]978-the big footman by staring straight over [the Earl]41-dorincourt 's head at a very ugly picture . [The Earl]203-the earl looked [[his]203-the earl valiant young relative]983-his valiant young relative over from head to foot . " Do [you]39-cedric think [you]39-cedric could do it ? "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl asked gruffly . " [I]39-cedric THINK [I]39-cedric could , "[39-cedric] said [Cedric]39-cedric . " [I]39-cedric 'm strong . [I]39-cedric 'm seven , [you]203-the earl know . [You]203-the earl could lean on [your]203-the earl stick on one side , and on [me]39-cedric on the other . "[39-cedric] [He]39-cedric shut [his]39-cedric hand and moved it upward to [his]39-cedric shoulder , so that [the Earl]203-the earl might see the muscle [Dick]59-dick had kindly approved of , and [his]39-cedric face was so grave and earnest that [the footman]805-the footman found it necessary to look very hard indeed at the ugly picture . " Well , "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl , " [you]39-cedric may try . "[203-the earl] [Cedric]39-cedric gave [him]39-cedric [his]39-cedric stick and began to assist [him]39-cedric to rise . Usually , [the footman]805-the footman did this , and was violently sworn at when [[his]805-the footman lordship]207-his lordship had an extra twinge of gout . [The Earl]41-dorincourt was not [a very polite person]989-a very polite person as a rule , and many a time [the huge footmen]990-the huge footmen about [him]41-dorincourt quaked inside [their]990-the huge footmen imposing liveries . But this evening [he]41-dorincourt did not swear , though [his]41-dorincourt gouty foot gave [him]41-dorincourt more twinges than one . [He]41-dorincourt chose to try an experiment . [He]41-dorincourt got up slowly and put [his]41-dorincourt hand on the small shoulder presented to [him]41-dorincourt with so much courage . [Little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy made a careful step forward , looking down at the gouty foot . " Just lean on [me]50-fauntleroy , "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy said , with encouraging good cheer . " [I]50-fauntleroy 'll walk very slowly . "[50-fauntleroy] If [the Earl]203-the earl had been supported by [the footman]805-the footman [he]203-the earl would have rested less on [his]203-the earl stick and more on [[his]203-the earl assistant]993-his assistant 's arm . And yet it was part of [his]203-the earl experiment to let [[his]203-the earl grandson]538-his grandson feel [his]538-his grandson burden as no light weight . It was quite a heavy weight indeed , and after a few steps [[his]203-the earl young lordship]2570-his young lordship 's face grew quite hot , and [his]203-the earl heart beat rather fast , but [he]203-the earl braced [himself]203-the earl sturdily , remembering [his]203-the earl muscle and [Dick]59-dick 's approval of it . " Do n't be afraid of leaning on [me]203-the earl , "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl panted . " [I]203-the earl 'm all right if if it is n't a very long way . "[203-the earl] It was not really very far to [the dining - room]996-the dining - room , but it seemed rather a long way to [Cedric]39-cedric , before [they]997-they reached the chair at the head of the table . The hand on [his]39-cedric shoulder seemed to grow heavier at every step , and [his]39-cedric face grew redder and hotter , and [his]39-cedric breath shorter , but [he]39-cedric never thought of giving up ; [he]39-cedric stiffened [his]39-cedric childish muscles , held [his]39-cedric head erect , and encouraged [the Earl]203-the earl as [he]39-cedric limped along . " Does [your]203-the earl foot hurt [you]203-the earl very much when [you]203-the earl stand on it ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric asked . " Did [you]203-the earl ever put it in hot water and mustard ? [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs used to put [his]46-mr. hobbs in hot water . [Arnica]75-arnica is a very nice thing , [they]2867-they tell [me]39-cedric . "[39-cedric] The big dog stalked slowly beside [them]997-they , and [the big footman]978-the big footman followed ; several times [he]978-the big footman looked very queer as [he]978-the big footman watched the little figure making the very most of all its strength , and bearing [its]1000-its burden with such good - will . [The Earl]41-dorincourt , too , looked rather queer , once , as [he]978-the big footman glanced sidewise down at the flushed little face . When [they]997-they entered [the room where [they]997-they were to dine]1001-the room where they were to dine , [Cedric]39-cedric saw [it]1001-the room where they were to dine was a very large and imposing one , and that [the footman who stood behind the chair at the head of the table]1002-the footman who stood behind the chair at the head of the table stared very hard as [they]997-they came in . But [they]997-they reached the chair at last . The hand was removed from [his]39-cedric shoulder , and [the Earl]203-the earl was fairly seated . [Cedric]39-cedric took out [Dick]59-dick 's handkerchief and wiped [his]39-cedric forehead . " It 's a warm night , is n't it ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said . " Perhaps [you]203-the earl need a fire because because of [your]203-the earl foot , but it seems just a little warm to [me]39-cedric . "[39-cedric] [His]39-cedric delicate consideration for [[his]39-cedric noble relative]1004-his noble relative 's feelings was such that [he]39-cedric did not wish to seem to intimate that any of [his]39-cedric surroundings were unnecessary . " [You]203-the earl have been doing some rather hard work , "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl . " Oh , no ! "[50-fauntleroy] said [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , " it was n't exactly hard , but [I]50-fauntleroy got a little warm . [A person]492-a person will get warm in summer time . "[50-fauntleroy] And [he]39-cedric rubbed [his]39-cedric damp curls rather vigorously with the gorgeous handkerchief . [His]39-cedric own chair was placed at the other end of the table , opposite [[his]39-cedric grandfather]335-his grandfather 's . It was a chair with arms , and intended for [a much larger individual than [himself]39-cedric]1007-a much larger individual than himself ; indeed , everything [he]39-cedric had seen so far , [the great rooms]1008-the great rooms , with [their]1008-the great rooms high ceilings , the massive furniture , [the big footman]978-the big footman , the big dog , [the Earl]203-the earl [himself]203-the earl , were all of proportions calculated to make [this little lad]1011-this little lad feel that [he]1011-this little lad was very small , indeed . But that did not trouble [him]203-the earl ; [he]203-the earl had never thought [himself]203-the earl very large or important , and [he]203-the earl was quite willing to accommodate [himself]203-the earl even to circumstances which rather overpowered [him]203-the earl . Perhaps [he]203-the earl had never looked so little [a fellow]511-a fellow as when seated now in [his]203-the earl great chair , at the end of the table . Notwithstanding [his]203-the earl solitary existence , [the Earl]203-the earl chose to live in some state . [He]203-the earl was fond of [his]203-the earl dinner , and [he]203-the earl dined in a formal style . [Cedric]39-cedric looked at [him]203-the earl across a glitter of splendid glass and plate , which to [his]39-cedric unaccustomed eyes seemed quite dazzling . [A stranger looking on]1014-a stranger looking on might well have smiled at the picture , [the great stately room]1015-the great stately room , [the big liveried servants]1016-the big liveried servants , the bright lights , the glittering silver and glass , [the fierce - looking old nobleman at the head of the table]1017-the fierce - looking old nobleman at the head of the table and [the very small boy at the foot]1018-the very small boy at the foot . Dinner was usually a very serious matter with [the Earl]203-the earl and it was a very serious matter with [the cook]1020-the cook , if [[his]203-the earl lordship]207-his lordship was not pleased or had an indifferent appetite . To - day , however , [his]203-the earl appetite seemed a trifle better than usual , perhaps because [he]203-the earl had something to think of beside the flavor of the entrees and the management of the gravies . [[His]203-the earl grandson]538-his grandson gave [him]203-the earl something to think of . [He]538-his grandson kept looking at [him]203-the earl across the table . [He]538-his grandson did not say very much [himself]538-his grandson , but [he]538-his grandson managed to make [the boy]2518-the boy talk . [He]538-his grandson had never imagined that [he]538-his grandson could be entertained by hearing [a child]2490-a child talk , but [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy at once puzzled and amused [him]538-his grandson , and [he]538-his grandson kept remembering how [he]538-his grandson had let the childish shoulder feel [his]538-his grandson weight just for the sake of trying how far [the boy]2518-the boy 's courage and endurance would go , and it pleased [him]538-his grandson to know that [[his]203-the earl grandson]538-his grandson had not quailed and had not seemed to think even for a moment of giving up what [he]203-the earl had undertaken to do . " [You]203-the earl do n't wear [your]203-the earl coronet all the time ? "[50-fauntleroy] remarked [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy respectfully . " No , "[203-the earl] replied [the Earl]203-the earl , with [his]203-the earl grim smile ; " it is not becoming to [me]203-the earl . "[203-the earl] " [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs said [you]203-the earl always wore it , "[39-cedric] said [Cedric]39-cedric ; " but after [he]46-mr. hobbs thought it over , [he]46-mr. hobbs said [he]46-mr. hobbs supposed [you]203-the earl must sometimes take it off to put [your]203-the earl hat on . "[39-cedric] " Yes , "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl , " [I]203-the earl take it off occasionally . "[203-the earl] And [one of [the footmen]1030-the footmen]1029-one of the footmen suddenly turned aside and gave a singular little cough behind [his]1029-one of the footmen hand . [Cedric]39-cedric finished [his]39-cedric dinner first , and then [he]39-cedric leaned back in [his]39-cedric chair and took a survey of [the room]147-the room . " [You]203-the earl must be very proud of [[your]203-the earl house]2869-your house , "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said , " it 's such [a beautiful house]2870-a beautiful house . [I]39-cedric never saw anything so beautiful ; but , of course , as [I]39-cedric 'm only seven , [I]39-cedric have n't seen much . "[39-cedric] " And [you]203-the earl think [I]203-the earl must be proud of it , do [you]203-the earl ? "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl . " [I]203-the earl should think [any one]233-any one would be proud of it , "[203-the earl] replied [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . " [I]50-fauntleroy should be proud of it if [it]2869-your house were [[my]50-fauntleroy house]2695-my house . Everything about [it]2869-your house is beautiful . And [the park]403-the park , and those trees , how beautiful they are , and how the leaves rustle ! "[50-fauntleroy] Then [he]50-fauntleroy paused an instant and looked across the table rather wistfully . " It 's [a very big house for just [two people]2875-two people to live in]2874-a very big house for just two people to live in , is n't [it]2869-your house ? "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy said . " [It]2869-your house is quite large enough for two , "[203-the earl] answered [the Earl]203-the earl . " Do [you]1034-his little lordship find it too large ? "[203-the earl] [[His]50-fauntleroy little lordship]1034-his little lordship hesitated a moment . " [I]50-fauntleroy was only thinking , "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy said , " that if [two people]2875-two people lived in [it]2869-your house who were [not very good companions]2877-not very good companions , [they]2875-two people might feel lonely sometimes . "[50-fauntleroy] " Do [you]1034-his little lordship think [I]203-the earl shall make [a good companion]2878-a good companion ? "[203-the earl] inquired [the Earl]203-the earl . " Yes , "[39-cedric] replied [Cedric]39-cedric , " [I]39-cedric think [you]1034-his little lordship will . [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs and [I]39-cedric were [great friends]2879-great friends . [He]39-cedric was [the best friend [I]39-cedric had]2880-the best friend i had except [Dearest]48-dearest . "[39-cedric] [The Earl]41-dorincourt made a quick movement of [his]41-dorincourt bushy eyebrows . " Who is [Dearest]48-dearest ? "[41-dorincourt] " [She]48-dearest is [[my]50-fauntleroy mother]2881-my mother , "[50-fauntleroy] said [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , in a rather low , quiet little voice . Perhaps [he]50-fauntleroy was a trifle tired , as [his]50-fauntleroy bed - time was nearing , and perhaps after the excitement of the last few days it was natural [he]50-fauntleroy should be tired , so perhaps , too , the feeling of weariness brought to [him]50-fauntleroy a vague sense of loneliness in the remembrance that to - night [he]50-fauntleroy was not to sleep at [home]199-home , watched over by the loving eyes of [that " best friend "[1038-they] of [his]50-fauntleroy]1037-that " best friend " of his . [They]1038-they had always been " [best friends]2882-best friends , "[1038-they] [this boy]2544-this boy and [[his]2544-this boy young mother]1040-his young mother . [He]50-fauntleroy could not help thinking of [her]1040-his young mother , and the more [he]50-fauntleroy thought of [her]1040-his young mother the less was [he]50-fauntleroy inclined to talk , and by the time the dinner was at an end [the Earl]41-dorincourt saw that there was a faint shadow on [his]50-fauntleroy face . But [Cedric]39-cedric bore [himself]39-cedric with excellent courage , and when [they]1038-they went back to [the library]2817-the library , though [the tall footman]1042-the tall footman walked on one side of [[his]1042-the tall footman master]1043-his master , [the Earl]203-the earl 's hand rested on [[his]203-the earl grandson]538-his grandson 's shoulder , though not so heavily as before . When [the footman]805-the footman left [them]1038-they alone , [Cedric]39-cedric sat down upon the hearth - rug near [Dougal]73-dougal . For a few minutes [he]39-cedric stroked the dog 's ears in silence and looked at the fire . [The Earl]41-dorincourt watched [him]39-cedric . [The boy]2518-the boy 's eyes looked wistful and thoughtful , and once or twice [he]2518-the boy gave a little sigh . [The Earl]41-dorincourt sat still , and kept [his]41-dorincourt eyes fixed on [[his]41-dorincourt grandson]538-his grandson . " [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , "[41-dorincourt] [he]41-dorincourt said at last , " what are [you]50-fauntleroy thinking of ? "[41-dorincourt] [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy looked up with a manful effort at a smile . " [I]41-dorincourt was thinking about [Dearest]48-dearest , "[41-dorincourt] [he]41-dorincourt said ; " and and [I]41-dorincourt think [I]41-dorincourt 'd better get up and walk up and down [the room]147-the room . "[41-dorincourt] [He]41-dorincourt rose up , and put [his]41-dorincourt hands in [his]41-dorincourt small pockets , and began to walk to and fro . [His]41-dorincourt eyes were very bright , and [his]41-dorincourt lips were pressed together , but [he]41-dorincourt kept [his]41-dorincourt head up and walked firmly . [Dougal]73-dougal moved lazily and looked at [him]41-dorincourt , and then stood up . [He]73-dougal walked over to [the child]2539-the child , and began to follow [him]2539-the child uneasily . [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy drew one hand from [his]50-fauntleroy pocket and laid it on the dog 's head . " [He]655-the little fellow 's a very nice dog , "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy said . " [He]655-the little fellow 's [[my]50-fauntleroy friend]2884-my friend . [He]655-the little fellow knows how [I]50-fauntleroy feel . "[50-fauntleroy] " How do [you]655-the little fellow feel ? "[203-the earl] asked [the Earl]203-the earl . It disturbed [him]203-the earl to see the struggle [the little fellow]655-the little fellow was having with [his]655-the little fellow first feeling of homesickness , but it pleased [him]203-the earl to see that [he]655-the little fellow was making so brave an effort to bear it well . [He]203-the earl liked this childish courage . " Come here , "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl said . [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy went to [him]655-the little fellow . " [I]2518-the boy never was away from [[my]2518-the boy own house]2885-my own house before , "[2518-the boy] said [the boy]2518-the boy , with a troubled look in [his]2518-the boy brown eyes . " It makes [a person]492-a person feel a strange feeling when [he]492-a person has to stay all night in [[another person]2887-another person 's castle]2888-another person 's castle instead of in [[his]492-a person own house]305-his own house . But [Dearest]48-dearest is not very far away from [me]655-the little fellow . [She]48-dearest told [me]655-the little fellow to remember that and and [I]655-the little fellow 'm seven and [I]655-the little fellow can look at the picture [she]48-dearest gave [me]655-the little fellow . "[655-the little fellow] [He]655-the little fellow put [his]655-the little fellow hand in [his]655-the little fellow pocket , and brought out a small violet velvet - covered case . " This is it , "[655-the little fellow] [he]655-the little fellow said . " [You]41-dorincourt see , [you]41-dorincourt press this spring and it opens , and [she]48-dearest is in there ! "[655-the little fellow] [He]655-the little fellow had come close to the [Earl]41-dorincourt 's chair , and , as [he]655-the little fellow drew forth the little case , [he]655-the little fellow leaned against the arm of it , and against [the old man]960-the old man 's arm , too , as confidingly as if [children]2556-children had always leaned there . " There [she]48-dearest is , "[655-the little fellow] [he]655-the little fellow said , as the case opened ; and [he]655-the little fellow looked up with a smile . [The Earl]203-the earl knitted [his]203-the earl brows ; [he]203-the earl did not wish to see the picture , but [he]203-the earl looked at it in spite of [himself]203-the earl ; and there looked up at [him]655-the little fellow from it such a pretty young face a face so like [the child]2539-the child 's at [his]655-the little fellow side that it quite startled [him]203-the earl . " [I]655-the little fellow suppose [you]50-fauntleroy think [you]50-fauntleroy are very fond of [her]48-dearest , "[655-the little fellow] [he]655-the little fellow said . " Yes , "[655-the little fellow] answered [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , in a gentle tone , and with simple directness ; " [I]655-the little fellow do think so , and [I]655-the little fellow think it 's true . [You]50-fauntleroy see , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs was [[my]655-the little fellow friend]2884-my friend , and [Dick]59-dick and [Bridget]61-bridget and [Mary]42-mary and [Michael]62-michael , [they]2891-they were [[my]655-the little fellow friends]2892-my friends , too ; but Dearest well , [she]48-dearest is [[my]655-the little fellow CLOSE friend]2893-my close friend , and [we]2894-we always tell [each other]2414-each other everything . [[My]655-the little fellow father]2826-my father left [her]48-dearest to [me]655-the little fellow to take care of , and when [I]655-the little fellow am [a man]2454-a man [I]655-the little fellow am going to work and earn money for [her]48-dearest . "[655-the little fellow] " What do [you]335-his grandfather think of doing ? "[335-his grandfather] inquired [[his]1057-his grandfather]335-his grandfather . [He]335-his grandfather seemed to be reflecting seriously , before [he]335-his grandfather answered . " [I]335-his grandfather did think perhaps [I]335-his grandfather might go into business with [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , "[335-his grandfather] [he]335-his grandfather said ; " but [I]335-his grandfather should LIKE to be [a President]453-a president . " Well , "[50-fauntleroy] remarked [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , " if [I]335-his grandfather COULDN'T be [a President]453-a president , and if that is a good business , [I]335-his grandfather should n't mind . The grocery business is dull sometimes . "[335-his grandfather] Perhaps [he]335-his grandfather was weighing the matter in [his]335-his grandfather mind , for [he]335-his grandfather sat very quiet after this , and looked at the fire for some time . [The Earl]203-the earl did not speak again . [He]203-the earl leaned back in [his]203-the earl chair and watched [him]335-his grandfather . A great many strange new thoughts passed through [the old nobleman]897-the old nobleman 's mind . [Dougal]73-dougal had stretched [himself]73-dougal out and gone to sleep with [his]73-dougal head on [his]73-dougal huge paws . There was a long silence . In about half an hour 's time [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham was ushered in . [The great room]1063-the great room was very still when [he]51-mr. havisham entered . [The Earl]41-dorincourt was still leaning back in [his]41-dorincourt chair . [He]41-dorincourt moved as [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham approached , and held up [his]41-dorincourt hand in a gesture of warning it seemed as if [he]41-dorincourt had scarcely intended to make the gesture as if it were almost involuntary . [Dougal]73-dougal was still asleep , and close beside the great dog , sleeping also , with [his]73-dougal curly head upon [his]73-dougal arm , lay [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy .

[VI]76-vi

When [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy wakened in the morning , [he]50-fauntleroy had not wakened at all when [he]50-fauntleroy had been carried to bed the night before , the first sounds [he]50-fauntleroy was conscious of were the crackling of a wood fire and the murmur of voices . " [You]50-fauntleroy will be careful , [Dawson]77-dawson , not to say anything about it , "[307-some one] [he]50-fauntleroy heard [some one]307-some one say . " [He]50-fauntleroy does not know why [she]307-some one is not to be with [him]50-fauntleroy , and the reason is to be kept from [him]50-fauntleroy . "[307-some one] " If [them]2902-them 's [[his]50-fauntleroy lordship]207-his lordship 's orders , [mem]2904-mem , "[307-some one] another voice answered , " [they]2902-them 'll have to be kep ' , [I]39-cedric suppose . But , if [you]2904-mem 'll excuse the liberty , [mem]2904-mem , as it 's between [ourselves]2906-they , [servant]2907-servant or [no servant]2908-no servant , all [I]39-cedric have to say is , it 's a cruel thing , parting [that poor , pretty , young widdered cre'tur ' from [her]307-some one own flesh and blood]2909-that poor , pretty , young widdered cre'tur ' from her own flesh and blood , and [him]50-fauntleroy such [a little beauty]2910-a little beauty and [a nobleman born]2911-a nobleman born . [James]78-james and [Thomas]79-thomas , [mem]2904-mem , last night in [[the servants]2913-the servants ' hall]2914-the servants ' hall , [they]2906-they both of ['em]2915-'em say as [they]2906-they never see anythink in [their]2906-they two lives nor yet [no other gentleman in livery like [that little fellow]2917-that little fellow 's ways]2916-no other gentleman in livery like that little fellow 's ways , as innercent an ' polite an ' interested as if [he]2917-that little fellow 'd been sitting there dining with [[his]2917-that little fellow best friend]2918-his best friend , and the temper of [a ' angel]2919-a ' angel , instead of one if [you]2904-mem 'll excuse [me]39-cedric , [mem]2904-mem , as it 's well known , is enough to curdle [your]2904-mem blood in [your]2904-mem veins at times . And as to looks , [mem]2904-mem , when [we]2906-they was rung for , [James]78-james and [me]39-cedric , to go into [the library]2817-the library and bring [him]2917-that little fellow [upstairs]310-upstairs , and [James]78-james lifted [him]2917-that little fellow up in [his]78-james arms , what with [his]78-james little innercent face all red and rosy , and [his]78-james little head on [James]78-james 's shoulder and [his]78-james hair hanging down , all curly an ' shinin ' , a prettier , takiner sight [you]2904-mem 'd never wish to see . An ' it 's [my]39-cedric opinion , [[my]39-cedric lord]762-my lord was n't blind to it neither , for [he]762-my lord looked at [him]2917-that little fellow , and [he]762-my lord says to [James]78-james , ' See [you]78-james do n't wake [him]2917-that little fellow ! ' [he]762-my lord says . "[39-cedric] [Cedric]39-cedric moved on [his]39-cedric pillow , and turned over , opening [his]39-cedric eyes . There were [two women]1065-two women in [the room]147-the room . Everything was bright and cheerful with gay - flowered chintz . There was a fire on the hearth , and the sunshine was streaming in through the ivy - entwined windows . [Both women]1067-both women came toward [him]39-cedric , and [he]39-cedric saw that [one of [them]1067-both women]1068-one of them was [Mrs. Mellon]72-mrs. mellon , [the housekeeper]2809-the housekeeper , and [the other a comfortable , middle - aged woman]1070-the other a comfortable , middle - aged woman , with a face as kind and good - humored as a face could be . " Good - morning , [[my]72-mrs. mellon lord]762-my lord , "[72-mrs. mellon] said [Mrs. Mellon]72-mrs. mellon . " Did [you]39-cedric sleep well ? " [I]207-his lordship did n't know [I]207-his lordship was [here]2433-here . " This is [[your]39-cedric bedroom]2928-your bedroom , and this is [Dawson]77-dawson , who is to take care of [you]39-cedric . " How do [you]77-dawson do , [ma'am]426-ma'am ? "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy said . " [I]50-fauntleroy 'm much obliged to [you]77-dawson for coming to take care of [me]50-fauntleroy . "[80-dawson] " [I]50-fauntleroy learned to dress [myself]50-fauntleroy many years ago , thank [you]39-cedric , "[50-fauntleroy] answered [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . " [Dawson]80-dawson will do anything [you]39-cedric ask [her]80-dawson to , "[72-mrs. mellon] said [Mrs. Mellon]72-mrs. mellon . " [He]50-fauntleroy shall dress [himself]50-fauntleroy if [he]50-fauntleroy likes , and [I]2809-the housekeeper 'll stand by , ready to help [him]50-fauntleroy if [he]50-fauntleroy wants [me]2809-the housekeeper . "[2809-the housekeeper] " Thank [you]50-fauntleroy , "[50-fauntleroy] responded [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy ; " it 's a little hard sometimes about the buttons , [you]50-fauntleroy know , and then [I]50-fauntleroy have to ask [somebody]2935-somebody . "[50-fauntleroy] [He]50-fauntleroy thought [Dawson]80-dawson [a very kind woman]1077-a very kind woman , and before the bath and the dressing were finished [they]1078-they were [excellent friends]1079-excellent friends , and [he]50-fauntleroy had found out a great deal about [her]80-dawson . [He]50-fauntleroy had discovered that [[her]80-dawson husband]2505-her husband had been [a soldier]482-a soldier and had been killed in a real battle , and that [[her]80-dawson son]1082-her son was [a sailor]1083-a sailor , and was away on a long cruise , and that [he]50-fauntleroy had seen [pirates]624-pirates and [cannibals]1085-cannibals and [Chinese people]1086-chinese people and [Turks]82-turks , and that [he]50-fauntleroy brought home strange shells and pieces of coral which [Dawson]80-dawson was ready to show at any moment , some of them being in [her]80-dawson trunk . All this was very interesting . [He]50-fauntleroy also found out that [she]80-dawson had taken care of [little children]1087-little children all [her]80-dawson life , and that [she]80-dawson had just come from [a great house in [another part of [England]1-england]1089-another part of england , where [she]80-dawson had been taking care of [a beautiful little girl whose name was [Lady Gwyneth Vaughn]83-lady gwyneth vaughn]1090-a beautiful little girl whose name was lady gwyneth vaughn]1088-a great house in another part of england , where she had been taking care of a beautiful little girl whose name was lady gwyneth vaughn . " And [she]1090-a beautiful little girl whose name was lady gwyneth vaughn is a sort of relation of [[your]2936-you lordship]2792-your lordship 's , "[80-dawson] said [Dawson]80-dawson . " And perhaps sometime [you]2936-you may see [her]1090-a beautiful little girl whose name was lady gwyneth vaughn . "[80-dawson] " Do [you]2936-you think [I]50-fauntleroy shall ? "[50-fauntleroy] said [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . " [I]50-fauntleroy should like that . [I]50-fauntleroy never knew [any little girls]2938-any little girls , but [I]50-fauntleroy always like to look at [them]2938-any little girls . [The room]147-the room was a large one , too , as all [the rooms]1100-the rooms seemed to be , and [it]147-the room appeared to [him]1093-he more beautiful than the rest , only in a different way . "[80-dawson] It was a tremendously exciting morning . [He]960-the old man abhorred [churches]1156-churches and [charities]1157-charities , and flew into violent rages when [any of [[his]960-the old man tenantry]1159-his tenantry]1158-any of his tenantry took the liberty of being poor and ill and needing assistance . "[79-thomas] And as [the Reverend Mr. Mordaunt]85-mr. mordaunt walked under the great trees , [he]85-mr. mordaunt remembered that [this questionable little boy]1220-this questionable little boy had arrived at [the Castle]402-the castle only the evening before , and that there were nine chances to one that [[his]85-mr. mordaunt lordship]207-his lordship 's worst fears were realized , and twenty - two chances to one that if [the poor little fellow]1223-the poor little fellow had disappointed [him]85-mr. mordaunt , [the Earl]203-the earl was even now in a tearing rage , and ready to vent all [his]203-the earl rancor on [the first person who called which it appeared probable]1225-the first person who called which it appeared probable would be [[his]203-the earl reverend self]1226-his reverend self . " And write it over again [he]0-i did , making quite an imposing copy , and taking precautions in the matter of spelling by consulting [the Earl]203-the earl [himself]0-i . "[1289-you] " Oh ! "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl . " [You]1289-you have , have [you]1289-you ? Ring the bell . "[203-the earl] As [they]1293-we drove down [the avenue]802-the avenue , under the arching trees , [he]203-the earl was rather silent . But [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy was not . [He]203-the earl talked about the pony . What color was it ? How big was it ? What was its name ? What did it like to eat best ? How old was it ? " [She]48-dearest will be so much obliged to [you]48-dearest for being so kind to [me]203-the earl ! [She]48-dearest knows [I]203-the earl always liked ponies so much , but [we]1293-we never thought [I]203-the earl should have one . There was [a little boy on [Fifth Avenue]21-fifth avenue who had one]3031-a little boy on fifth avenue who had one , and [he]3031-a little boy on fifth avenue who had one used to ride out every morning and [we]1293-we used to take a walk past [[his]3031-a little boy on fifth avenue who had one house]896-his house to see [him]3031-a little boy on fifth avenue who had one . "[203-the earl] [He]203-the earl leaned back against the cushions and regarded [the Earl]203-the earl with rapt interest for a few minutes and in entire silence . " [I]203-the earl think [you]48-dearest must be [the best person in [the world]164-the world]3033-the best person in the world , "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl burst forth at last . " [You]48-dearest are always doing good , are n't [you]48-dearest ? and thinking about [other people]155-other people . [Dearest]48-dearest says that is the best kind of goodness ; not to think about [yourself]48-dearest , but to think about [other people]155-other people . That is just the way [you]48-dearest are , is n't it ? "[203-the earl] [[His]203-the earl lordship]207-his lordship was so dumfounded to find [himself]203-the earl presented in such agreeable colors , that [he]203-the earl did not know exactly what to say . [He]203-the earl felt that [he]203-the earl needed time for reflection . To see each of [his]203-the earl ugly , selfish motives changed into a good and generous one by the simplicity of [a child]2490-a child was a singular experience . [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy went on , still regarding [him]203-the earl with admiring eyes those great , clear , innocent eyes ! " [You]48-dearest make [so many people]3037-so many people happy , "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl said . " There 's [Michael]62-michael and [Bridget]61-bridget and [[their]3038-their ten children]3039-their ten children , and [the apple - woman]284-the apple - woman , and [Dick]59-dick , and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , and [Mr. Higgins]90-higgins and [Mrs. Higgins]94-higgins and [[their]3038-their children]3041-their children , and [Mr. Mordaunt]85-mr. mordaunt , because of course [he]203-the earl was glad , and [Dearest]48-dearest and [me]203-the earl , about the pony and all the other things . "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl . " Why , yes , [you]203-the earl know , "[50-fauntleroy] answered [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . " [You]48-dearest made [them]3042-twenty - seven people you 've been kind to all happy . Do [you]203-the earl know , "[50-fauntleroy] with some delicate hesitation , " that [people]248-people are sometimes mistaken about [earls]298-earls when [they]248-people do n't know [them]298-earls . "[50-fauntleroy] " What was [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs 's opinion of [earls]298-earls ? "[207-his lordship] asked [[his]1299-his lordship]207-his lordship . " Well , [you]48-dearest see , the difficulty was , "[961-his young companion] replied [[his]1299-his young companion]961-his young companion , " that [he]46-mr. hobbs did n't know any , and [he]46-mr. hobbs 'd only read about [them]298-earls in books . "[50-fauntleroy] " Just like [me]207-his lordship ! "[207-his lordship] repeated [[his]50-fauntleroy lordship]207-his lordship , looking at the little kindling face . And a dull red crept up under [his]50-fauntleroy withered skin , and [he]50-fauntleroy suddenly turned [his]50-fauntleroy eyes away and looked out of the carriage window at the great beech - trees , with the sun shining on their glossy , red - brown leaves . " JUST like [you]48-dearest , "[50-fauntleroy] said [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , adding modestly , " if [I]50-fauntleroy can . Perhaps [I]50-fauntleroy 'm not good enough , but [I]50-fauntleroy 'm going to try . "[50-fauntleroy] [The carriage]602-the carriage rolled on down [the stately avenue]1304-the stately avenue under the beautiful , broad - branched trees , through the spaces of green shade and [lanes of golden sunlight]1305-lanes of golden sunlight . [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy saw again [the lovely places where the ferns grew high]1306-the lovely places where the ferns grew high and the bluebells swayed in the breeze ; [he]50-fauntleroy saw the deer , standing or lying in the deep grass , turn [their]1307-their large , startled eyes as [the carriage]602-the carriage passed , and caught glimpses of the brown rabbits as [they]1307-their scurried away . [He]50-fauntleroy heard the whir of the partridges and the calls and songs of the birds , and it all seemed even more beautiful to [him]50-fauntleroy than before . All [his]50-fauntleroy heart was filled with pleasure and happiness in the beauty that was on every side . But [the old Earl]191-the old earl saw and heard very different things , though [he]191-the old earl was apparently looking out too . [He]191-the old earl saw a long life , in which there had been neither generous deeds nor kind thoughts ; [he]191-the old earl saw years in which [a man who had been young and strong and rich and powerful]1310-a man who had been young and strong and rich and powerful had used [his]1310-a man who had been young and strong and rich and powerful youth and strength and wealth and power only to please [himself]1310-a man who had been young and strong and rich and powerful and kill time as the days and years succeeded each other ; [he]191-the old earl saw [this man]1311-this man , when the time had been killed and old age had come , solitary and without [real friends]1312-real friends in the midst of all [his]1310-a man who had been young and strong and rich and powerful splendid wealth ; [he]191-the old earl saw [people who disliked or feared [him]1310-a man who had been young and strong and rich and powerful]1313-people who disliked or feared him , and [people who would flatter and cringe to [him]1310-a man who had been young and strong and rich and powerful]1314-people who would flatter and cringe to him , but [no one who really cared whether [he]1310-a man who had been young and strong and rich and powerful lived or died , unless [they]1316-they had something to gain or lose by it]1315-no one who really cared whether he lived or died , unless they had something to gain or lose by it . [He]191-the old earl looked out on [the broad acres which belonged to [him]191-the old earl]1317-the broad acres which belonged to him , and [he]191-the old earl knew what [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy did not how far [they]1317-the broad acres which belonged to him extended , what wealth [they]1317-the broad acres which belonged to him represented , and how many [people]248-people had homes on [[their]248-people soil]1319-their soil . And [he]191-the old earl knew , too , another thing [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy did not , that in [all those homes]1320-all those homes , humble or well - to - do , there was probably [not one person]1321-not one person , however much [he]191-the old earl envied the wealth and stately name and power , and however willing [he]191-the old earl would have been to possess [them]1317-the broad acres which belonged to him , who would for an instant have thought of calling [the noble owner]1322-the noble owner " good , "[1321-not one person] or wishing , as [this simple - souled little boy]1323-this simple - souled little boy had , to be like [him]191-the old earl . And it was not exactly pleasant to reflect upon , even for [a cynical , worldly old man]1324-a cynical , worldly old man , who had been sufficient unto [himself]1324-a cynical , worldly old man for seventy years and who had never deigned to care what opinion [the world]164-the world held of [him]1324-a cynical , worldly old man so long as it did not interfere with [his]1324-a cynical , worldly old man comfort or entertainment . And the fact was , indeed , that [he]191-the old earl had never before condescended to reflect upon it at all ; and [he]191-the old earl only did so now because [a child]2490-a child had believed [him]191-the old earl better than [he]191-the old earl was , and by wishing to follow in [his]191-the old earl illustrious footsteps and imitate [his]191-the old earl example , had suggested to [him]191-the old earl the curious question whether [he]191-the old earl was exactly [the person to take as a model]1327-the person to take as a model . [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy thought [the Earl]203-the earl 's foot must be hurting [him]191-the old earl , [his]50-fauntleroy brows knitted themselves together so , as [he]50-fauntleroy looked out at [the park]403-the park ; and thinking this , [the considerate little fellow]1330-the considerate little fellow tried not to disturb [him]50-fauntleroy , and enjoyed the trees and the ferns and the deer in silence . But at last [the carriage]602-the carriage , having passed the gates and bowled through [the green lanes]1332-the green lanes for a short distance , stopped . [They]602-the carriage had reached [Court Lodge]16-court lodge ; and [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy was out upon [the ground]830-the ground almost before [the big footman]978-the big footman had time to open the carriage door . [The Earl]41-dorincourt wakened from [his]41-dorincourt reverie with a start . " What ! "[41-dorincourt] [he]41-dorincourt said . " Are [we]602-the carriage here ? "[41-dorincourt] " Yes , "[50-fauntleroy] said [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . " Let [me]50-fauntleroy give [you]41-dorincourt [your]41-dorincourt stick . "[50-fauntleroy] " [I]207-his lordship am not going to get out , "[207-his lordship] replied [[his]41-dorincourt lordship]207-his lordship brusquely . " Not not to see [Dearest]48-dearest ? "[50-fauntleroy] exclaimed [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy with astonished face . " ' Dearest ' will excuse [me]203-the earl , "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl dryly .
