"[50-fauntleroy] " [I]203-the earl am afraid not , "[203-the earl] was the answer . " [The carriage]602-the carriage will call for [you]50-fauntleroy as [we]3052-we come back . Tell [Jeffries]95-jeffries to drive on , [Thomas]79-thomas . "[79-thomas] [Thomas]79-thomas closed the carriage door ; and , after a puzzled look , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy ran up [the drive]1337-the drive . [The Earl]41-dorincourt had the opportunity as [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham once had of seeing a pair of handsome , strong little legs flash over the ground with astonishing rapidity . Evidently [[their]1338-their owner]1339-their owner had no intention of losing any time . [The carriage]602-the carriage rolled slowly away , but [[his]41-dorincourt lordship]207-his lordship did not at once lean back ; [he]41-dorincourt still looked out . Through a space in [the trees]1342-the trees [he]41-dorincourt could see the house door ; it was wide open . [The little figure]1343-the little figure dashed up the steps ; another figure a little figure , too , slender and young , in [its]1343-the little figure black gown ran to meet it . It seemed as if [they]1344-they flew together , as [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy leaped into [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother 's arms , hanging about [her]151-his mother neck and covering [her]151-his mother sweet young face with kisses .

[VII]96-vii

On the following Sunday morning , [Mr. Mordaunt]85-mr. mordaunt had [a large congregation]1346-a large congregation . Indeed , [he]85-mr. mordaunt could scarcely remember any Sunday on which [the church]1347-the church had been so crowded . [People]248-people appeared upon the scene who seldom did [him]85-mr. mordaunt the honor of coming to hear [his]85-mr. mordaunt sermons . There were even people from [Hazelton]22-hazelton , which was [the next parish]1349-the next parish . There were [hearty , sunburned farmers]1350-hearty , sunburned farmers , [stout , comfortable , apple - cheeked wives in [their]1351-stout , comfortable , apple - cheeked wives in their best bonnets and most gorgeous shawls best bonnets and most gorgeous shawls]1351-stout , comfortable , apple - cheeked wives in their best bonnets and most gorgeous shawls , and [half a dozen children or so to each family]1352-half a dozen children or so to each family . [[The doctor]2998-the doctor 's wife]1354-the doctor 's wife was [there]221-there , with [[her]1354-the doctor 's wife four daughters]1356-her four daughters . [Mrs. Kimsey]97-mrs. kimsey and [Mr. Kimsey]98-mr. kimsey , who kept [[the druggist]1357-the druggist 's shop]1358-the druggist 's shop , and made pills , and did up powders for [everybody within ten miles]1359-everybody within ten miles , sat in [their]1360-their pew ; [Mrs. Dibble]87-mrs. dibble in [hers]87-mrs. dibble ; [Miss Smiff]99-miss smiff , [the village dressmaker]1361-the village dressmaker , and [[her]99-miss smiff friend]1362-her friend [Miss Perkins]100-miss perkins , [the milliner]1363-the milliner , sat in [theirs]1360-their ; [the doctor 's young man]1364-the doctor 's young man was present , and [[the druggist]1357-the druggist 's apprentice]1366-the druggist 's apprentice ; in fact , [almost every family on [the county side]1368-the county side]1367-almost every family on the county side was represented , in one way or another . In the course of the preceding week , many wonderful stories had been told of [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . [Mrs. Dibble]87-mrs. dibble had been kept so busy attending to [customers who came in to buy a pennyworth of needles or a ha'porth of tape]1369-customers who came in to buy a pennyworth of needles or a ha'porth of tape and to hear what [she]87-mrs. dibble had to relate , that the little shop bell over the door had nearly tinkled itself to death over the coming and going . [Mrs. Dibble]87-mrs. dibble knew exactly how [[his]50-fauntleroy small lordship 's rooms]1370-his small lordship 's rooms had been furnished for [him]50-fauntleroy , what expensive toys had been bought , how there was a beautiful brown pony awaiting [him]50-fauntleroy , and [a small groom to attend it]1371-a small groom to attend it , and a little dog - cart , with silver - mounted harness . And [she]87-mrs. dibble could tell , too , what all [the servants]2913-the servants had said when [they]2913-the servants had caught glimpses of [the child]2539-the child on the night of [his]50-fauntleroy arrival ; and how [every female below stairs]1374-every female below stairs had said it was a shame , so it was , to part [the poor pretty dear from [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother]1375-the poor pretty dear from his mother ; and had all declared [their]2913-the servants hearts came into [their]2913-the servants mouths when [he]50-fauntleroy went alone into [the library]2817-the library to see [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather , for " there was no knowing how [he]50-fauntleroy 'd be treated , and [[his]50-fauntleroy lordship]207-his lordship 's temper was enough to fluster [them]2913-the servants with old heads on [their]2913-the servants shoulders , let alone [a child]2490-a child . "[87-mrs. dibble] " But if [you]3055-you 'll believe [me]87-mrs. dibble , [Mrs. Jennifer]101-mrs. jennifer , [mum]3056-mum , "[87-mrs. dibble] [Mrs. Dibble]87-mrs. dibble had said , " fear [that child]3057-that child does not know so [Mr. Thomas hisself]79-thomas says ; an ' set an ' smile [he]50-fauntleroy did , an ' talked to [[his]50-fauntleroy lordship]207-his lordship as if [they]3059-they 'd been [friends]378-friends ever since [his]50-fauntleroy first hour . An ' [the Earl]203-the earl so took aback , [Mr. Thomas]79-thomas says , that [he]203-the earl could n't do nothing but listen and stare from under [his]203-the earl eyebrows . An ' it 's [Mr. Thomas]79-thomas 's opinion , [Mrs. Bates]102-mrs. bates , [mum]3056-mum , that bad as [he]50-fauntleroy is , [he]50-fauntleroy was pleased in [his]50-fauntleroy secret soul , an ' proud , too ; for [a handsomer little fellow]3063-a handsomer little fellow , or with better manners , though so old - fashioned , [Mr. Thomas]79-thomas says [he]79-thomas 'd never wish to see . "[87-mrs. dibble] And then there had come the story of [Higgins]94-higgins . [The Reverend Mr. Mordaunt]85-mr. mordaunt had told it at [his]85-mr. mordaunt own dinner table , and [the servants who had heard it]1379-the servants who had heard it had told it in [the kitchen]265-the kitchen , and from there it had spread like wildfire . And on market - day , when [Higgins]94-higgins had appeared in [town]509-town , [he]85-mr. mordaunt had been questioned on every side , and [Newick]91-newick had been questioned too , and in response had shown to [two or three people]1382-two or three people the note signed " [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . "[91-newick] And so [[the farmers]1383-the farmers ' wives]1384-the farmers ' wives had found plenty to talk of over [their]1384-the farmers ' wives tea and [their]1384-the farmers ' wives shopping , and [they]1384-the farmers ' wives had done the subject full justice and made the most of it . And on Sunday [they]1384-the farmers ' wives had either walked to [church]1385-church or had been driven in [their]1384-the farmers ' wives gigs by [[their]1384-the farmers ' wives husbands]1386-their husbands , who were perhaps a trifle curious [themselves]1386-their husbands about [the new little lord who was to be in time [the owner of [the soil]1389-the soil]1388-the owner of the soil]1387-the new little lord who was to be in time the owner of the soil . It was by no means [the Earl]203-the earl 's habit to attend [church]1385-church , but [he]203-the earl chose to appear on this first Sunday it was [his]203-the earl whim to present [himself]203-the earl in the huge family pew , with [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy at [his]203-the earl side . There were [many loiterers]1392-many loiterers in [the churchyard]1393-the churchyard , and [many lingerers]1394-many lingerers in [the lane]1395-the lane that morning . There were [groups at the gates]1396-groups at the gates and in [the porch]1397-the porch , and there had been much discussion as to whether [[my]0-i lord]762-my lord would really appear or not . When this discussion was at its height , [one good woman]1399-one good woman suddenly uttered an exclamation . " Eh , "[1399-one good woman] [she]1399-one good woman said , " that must be [the mother]2567-the mother , [pretty young thing]3065-pretty young thing . "[1399-one good woman] [All who heard]1400-all who heard turned and looked at [the slender figure in black coming up the path]1401-the slender figure in black coming up the path . The veil was thrown back from [her]1399-one good woman face and [they]1400-all who heard could see how fair and sweet it was , and how the bright hair curled as softly as [a child]2490-a child 's under [the little widow]1403-the little widow 's cap . [She]1399-one good woman was not thinking of [the people]644-the people about ; [she]1399-one good woman was thinking of [Cedric]39-cedric , and of [his]39-cedric visits to [her]1399-one good woman , and [his]39-cedric joy over [his]39-cedric new pony , on which [he]39-cedric had actually ridden to [her]1399-one good woman door the day before , sitting very straight and looking very proud and happy . But soon [she]1399-one good woman could not help being attracted by the fact that [she]1399-one good woman was being looked at and that [her]1399-one good woman arrival had created some sort of sensation . [She]1399-one good woman first noticed it because [an old woman in a red cloak]1405-an old woman in a red cloak made a bobbing courtesy to [her]1399-one good woman , and then [another]1406-another did the same thing and said , " God bless [you]1399-one good woman , [[my]1406-another lady]3066-my lady ! "[1406-another] and [one man after another]1407-one man after another took off [his]1407-one man after another hat as [she]1399-one good woman passed . For a moment [she]1399-one good woman did not understand , and then [she]1399-one good woman realized that it was because [she]1399-one good woman was [[little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's mother]2638-little lord fauntleroy 's mother that [they]1409-they did so , and [she]1399-one good woman flushed rather shyly and smiled and bowed too , and said , " Thank [you]1410-the old woman who had blessed her , "[1399-one good woman] in a gentle voice to [the old woman who had blessed [her]1399-one good woman]1410-the old woman who had blessed her . To [a person who had always lived in [a bustling , crowded American city]1412-a bustling , crowded american city]1411-a person who had always lived in a bustling , crowded american city this simple deference was very novel , and at first just a little embarrassing ; but after all , [she]1399-one good woman could not help liking and being touched by the friendly warm - heartedness of which it seemed to speak . [She]1399-one good woman had scarcely passed through [the stone porch]1413-the stone porch into [the church]1347-the church before the great event of the day happened . [The carriage]602-the carriage from [the Castle]402-the castle , with [its]602-the carriage handsome horses and [tall liveried servants]1417-tall liveried servants , bowled around the corner and down [the green lane]1418-the green lane . " Here [they]3067-they come ! "[1419-one looker - on] went from [one looker - on]1419-one looker - on to another . And then [the carriage]602-the carriage drew up , and [Thomas]79-thomas stepped down and opened the door , and [a little boy , dressed in black velvet , and with a splendid mop of bright waving hair]1421-a little boy , dressed in black velvet , and with a splendid mop of bright waving hair , jumped out . [Every man]1422-every man , [woman]2427-woman , and [child]1424-child looked curiously upon [him]1421-a little boy , dressed in black velvet , and with a splendid mop of bright waving hair . " [He]1421-a little boy , dressed in black velvet , and with a splendid mop of bright waving hair 's [the Captain]168-the captain over again ! "[1425-those of the on - lookers who remembered his father] said [those of the on - lookers who remembered [[his]1421-a little boy , dressed in black velvet , and with a splendid mop of bright waving hair father]150-his father]1425-those of the on - lookers who remembered his father . " [He]1421-a little boy , dressed in black velvet , and with a splendid mop of bright waving hair 's [the Captain]168-the captain 's self , to the life ! "[1421-a little boy , dressed in black velvet , and with a splendid mop of bright waving hair] [He]1421-a little boy , dressed in black velvet , and with a splendid mop of bright waving hair stood there in the sunlight looking up at [the Earl]203-the earl , as [Thomas]79-thomas helped [that nobleman]1428-that nobleman out , with the most affectionate interest that could be imagined . The instant [he]79-thomas could help , [he]79-thomas put out [his]79-thomas hand and offered [his]79-thomas shoulder as if [he]79-thomas had been seven feet high . It was plain enough to every one that however it might be with [other people]155-other people , [the Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]2471-the earl of dorincourt struck no terror into the breast of [[his]2471-the earl of dorincourt grandson]538-his grandson . " Just lean on [me]79-thomas , "[79-thomas] [they]1432-they heard [him]79-thomas say . " How glad [the people]644-the people are to see [you]538-his grandson , and how well [they]644-the people all seem to know [you]538-his grandson ! "[79-thomas] " Take off [your]538-his grandson cap , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl . " [They]1432-they are bowing to [you]538-his grandson . "[203-the earl] " To [me]50-fauntleroy ! "[50-fauntleroy] cried [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , whipping off [his]50-fauntleroy cap in a moment , baring [his]50-fauntleroy bright head to [the crowd]633-the crowd and turning shining , puzzled eyes on [them]633-the crowd as [he]50-fauntleroy tried to bow to [every one]184-every one at once . " God bless [[your]50-fauntleroy lordship]2792-your lordship ! "[1436-the courtesying , red - cloaked old woman who had spoken to his mother] said [the courtesying , red - cloaked old woman who had spoken to [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother]1436-the courtesying , red - cloaked old woman who had spoken to his mother ; " long life to [you]50-fauntleroy ! "[1436-the courtesying , red - cloaked old woman who had spoken to his mother] " Thank [you]1436-the courtesying , red - cloaked old woman who had spoken to his mother , [ma'am]426-ma'am , "[50-fauntleroy] said [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . And then [they]1438-they went into [the church]1347-the church , and were looked at there , on [their]1438-they way up [the aisle]1440-the aisle to the square , red - cushioned and curtained pew . When [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy was fairly seated , [he]50-fauntleroy made two discoveries which pleased [him]50-fauntleroy : the first that , across [the church]1347-the church where [he]50-fauntleroy could look at [her]151-his mother , [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother sat and smiled at [him]50-fauntleroy ; the second , that at one end of the pew , against the wall , knelt [two quaint figures carven in stone]1443-two quaint figures carven in stone , facing each other as [they]1443-two quaint figures carven in stone kneeled on either side of a pillar supporting two stone missals , [their]1443-two quaint figures carven in stone pointed hands folded as if in prayer , [their]1443-two quaint figures carven in stone dress very antique and strange . On the tablet by [them]1443-two quaint figures carven in stone was written something of which [he]50-fauntleroy could only read the curious words : " Here lyeth [ye]3073-ye bodye of [Gregorye Arthure Fyrst]103-gregorye arthure fyrst Earle of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt Allsoe of [Alisone Hildegarde hys wyfe]104-alisone hildegarde hys wyfe . "[50-fauntleroy] " May [I]207-his lordship whisper ? "[207-his lordship] inquired [[his]50-fauntleroy lordship]207-his lordship , devoured by curiosity . " What is it ? "[335-his grandfather] " [Some of [[your]50-fauntleroy ancestors]3075-your ancestors]3074-some of your ancestors , "[203-the earl] answered [the Earl]203-the earl , " who lived a few hundred years ago . "[50-fauntleroy] And then [he]50-fauntleroy proceeded to find [his]50-fauntleroy place in [the church]1347-the church service . When the music began , [he]50-fauntleroy stood up and looked across at [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother , smiling . [He]50-fauntleroy was very fond of music , and [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother and [he]50-fauntleroy often sang together , so [he]50-fauntleroy joined in with [the rest]847-the rest , [his]50-fauntleroy pure , sweet , high voice rising as clear as the song of a bird . [He]50-fauntleroy quite forgot [himself]50-fauntleroy in [his]50-fauntleroy pleasure in it . [The Earl]203-the earl forgot [himself]203-the earl a little too , as [he]203-the earl sat in [his]203-the earl curtain - shielded corner of the pew and watched [the boy]2518-the boy . [Cedric]39-cedric stood with the big psalter open in [his]39-cedric hands , singing with all [his]39-cedric childish might , [his]39-cedric face a little uplifted , happily ; and as [he]39-cedric sang , a long ray of sunshine crept in and , slanting through a golden pane of a stained glass window , brightened the falling hair about [his]39-cedric young head . [[His]2518-the boy mother]151-his mother , as [she]151-his mother looked at [him]2518-the boy across [the church]1347-the church , felt a thrill pass through [her]151-his mother heart , and a prayer rose in it too , a prayer that the pure , simple happiness of [his]2518-the boy childish soul might last , and that the strange , great fortune which had fallen to [him]2518-the boy might bring no wrong or evil with it . There were many soft , anxious thoughts in [her]151-his mother tender heart in those new days . " Oh , [Ceddie]64-ceddie ! "[151-his mother] [she]151-his mother had said to [him]2518-the boy the evening before , as [she]151-his mother hung over [him]2518-the boy in saying good - night , before [he]2518-the boy went away ; " oh , [Ceddie]64-ceddie , [dear]3076-dear , [I]151-his mother wish for [your]2518-the boy sake [I]151-his mother was very clever and could say a great many wise things ! But only be good , [dear]3076-dear , only be brave , only be kind and true always , and then [you]2518-the boy will never hurt [any one]233-any one , so long as [you]2518-the boy live , and [you]2518-the boy may help many , and [the big world]3079-the big world may be better because [[my]151-his mother little child]3080-my little child was born . And that is best of all , [Ceddie]64-ceddie , it is better than everything else , that [the world]164-the world should be a little better because [a man]2454-a man has lived even ever so little better , dearest . "[151-his mother] And on [his]2518-the boy return to [the Castle]402-the castle , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy had repeated [her]1456-she words to [[his]2518-the boy grandfather]335-his grandfather . " And [I]2518-the boy thought about [you]335-his grandfather when [she]1456-she said that , "[2518-the boy] [he]2518-the boy ended ; " and [I]2518-the boy told [her]1456-she that was the way [the world]164-the world was because [you]335-his grandfather had lived , and [I]2518-the boy was going to try if [I]2518-the boy could be like [you]335-his grandfather . "[2518-the boy] " And what did [she]1456-she say to that ? "[207-his lordship] asked [[his]2518-the boy lordship]207-his lordship , a trifle uneasily . " [She]1456-she said that was right , and [we]3084-we must always look for good in [people]248-people and try to be like it . "[207-his lordship] Perhaps it was this [the old man]960-the old man remembered as [he]960-the old man glanced through the divided folds of the red curtain of [[his]960-the old man pew]1460-his pew . Many times [he]960-the old man looked over [the people]644-the people 's heads to where [[his]2518-the boy son 's wife]1462-his son 's wife sat alone , and [he]960-the old man saw the fair face [the unforgiven dead]1463-the unforgiven dead had loved , and the eyes which were so like those of [the child at [his]2518-the boy side]1464-the child at his side ; but what [his]960-the old man thoughts were , and whether they were hard and bitter , or softened a little , it would have been hard to discover . As [they]1465-they came out of [church]1385-church , [many of [those who had attended the service]1468-those who had attended the service]1467-many of those who had attended the service stood waiting to see [them]1465-they pass . As [they]1465-they neared the gate , [a man who stood with [his]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand hat in [his]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand hand]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand made a step forward and then hesitated . [He]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand was [a middle - aged farmer]1470-a middle - aged farmer , with a careworn face . " Well , [Higgins]94-higgins , "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl . [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy turned quickly to look at [him]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand . " Oh ! "[2684-the man] Perhaps [he]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand felt some wonder when [he]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand saw what [a little fellow it]1474-a little fellow it was who had innocently done so much for [him]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand , and who stood there looking up just as one of [[his]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand own less fortunate children]1475-his own less fortunate children might have done apparently not realizing [his]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand own importance in the least . Is [Mrs. Higgins]94-higgins well now ? "[50-fauntleroy] [Higgins]94-higgins looked a trifle taken aback . " [[My]50-fauntleroy grandfather]3090-my grandfather was very sorry about [[your]94-higgins children]3095-your children having the scarlet fever , and so was [I.]50-fauntleroy [He]3090-my grandfather has had [children]2556-children [himself]3090-my grandfather . [I]50-fauntleroy 'm [[his]3090-my grandfather son 's little boy]3097-his son 's little boy , [you]94-higgins know . "[50-fauntleroy] [Higgins]94-higgins was on the verge of being panic - stricken . [He]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand felt it would be the safer and more discreet plan not to look at [the Earl]203-the earl , as it had been well known that [his]203-the earl fatherly affection for [[his]203-the earl sons]1479-his sons had been such that [he]203-the earl had seen [them]1479-his sons about twice a year , and that when [they]1479-his sons had been ill , [he]203-the earl had promptly departed for [London]7-london , because [he]203-the earl would not be bored with [doctors]1480-doctors and [nurses]619-nurses . It was a little trying , therefore , to [[his]203-the earl lordship]207-his lordship 's nerves to be told , while [he]203-the earl looked on , [his]203-the earl eyes gleaming from under [his]203-the earl shaggy eyebrows , that [he]203-the earl felt an interest in scarlet fever . " [You]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand see , [Higgins]94-higgins , "[203-the earl] broke in [the Earl]203-the earl with a fine grim smile , " [[you]1469-a man who stood with his hat in his hand people]3098-you people have been mistaken in [me]203-the earl . [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy understands [me]203-the earl . Get into [the carriage]602-the carriage , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . "[203-the earl] And [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy jumped in , and [the carriage]602-the carriage rolled away down [the green lane]1418-the green lane , and even when [it]602-the carriage turned the corner into [the high road]1486-the high road , [the Earl]203-the earl was still grimly smiling .

[VIII

Lord Dorincourt]105-viii lord dorincourt had occasion to wear [his]105-viii lord dorincourt grim smile many a time as the days passed by . Indeed , as [his]105-viii lord dorincourt acquaintance with [[his]105-viii lord dorincourt grandson]538-his grandson progressed , [he]105-viii lord dorincourt wore the smile so often that there were moments when it almost lost its grimness . There is no denying that before [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy had appeared on the scene , [the old man]960-the old man had been growing very tired of [his]960-the old man loneliness and [his]960-the old man gout and [his]960-the old man seventy years . After so long a life of excitement and amusement , it was not agreeable to sit alone even in [the most splendid room]1490-the most splendid room , with one foot on a gout - stool , and with no other diversion than flying into a rage , and shouting at [a frightened footman who hated the sight of [him]960-the old man]1491-a frightened footman who hated the sight of him . [The old Earl]41-dorincourt was [too clever a man not to know perfectly well that [[his]41-dorincourt servants]1211-his servants detested [him]41-dorincourt , and that even if [he]41-dorincourt had [visitors]1494-visitors , [they]1211-his servants did not come for love of [him]41-dorincourt]1492-too clever a man not to know perfectly well that his servants detested him , and that even if he had visitors , they did not come for love of him though [some]620-some found a sort of amusement in [his]41-dorincourt sharp , sarcastic talk , which spared [no one]2413-no one . So long as [he]41-dorincourt had been strong and well , [he]41-dorincourt had gone from [one place]1497-one place to another , pretending to amuse [himself]41-dorincourt , though [he]41-dorincourt had not really enjoyed it ; and when [his]41-dorincourt health began to fail , [he]41-dorincourt felt tired of everything and shut [himself]41-dorincourt up at [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt , with [his]41-dorincourt gout and [his]41-dorincourt newspapers and [his]41-dorincourt books . But [he]41-dorincourt could not read all the time , and [he]41-dorincourt became more and more " bored , "[41-dorincourt] as [he]41-dorincourt called it . [He]41-dorincourt hated the long nights and days , and [he]41-dorincourt grew more and more savage and irritable . And then [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy came ; and when [the Earl]203-the earl saw [him]50-fauntleroy , fortunately for [the little fellow]655-the little fellow , [the secret pride of [the grandfather]1501-the grandfather]1500-the secret pride of the grandfather was gratified at the outset . If [Cedric]39-cedric had been [a less handsome little fellow]1502-a less handsome little fellow , [the old man]960-the old man might have taken so strong a dislike to [him]960-the old man that [he]960-the old man would not have given [himself]960-the old man the chance to see [[his]960-the old man grandson]538-his grandson 's finer qualities . But [he]960-the old man chose to think that [Cedric]39-cedric 's beauty and fearless spirit were the results of [the Dorincourt]41-dorincourt blood and a credit to [the Dorincourt]41-dorincourt rank . And then when [he]960-the old man heard [the lad]545-the lad talk , and saw what [a well - bred little fellow]1506-a well - bred little fellow [he]39-cedric was , notwithstanding [his]960-the old man boyish ignorance of all that [his]960-the old man new position meant , [the old Earl]191-the old earl liked [[his]960-the old man grandson]538-his grandson more , and actually began to find [himself]191-the old earl rather entertained . It had amused [him]191-the old earl to give into those childish hands the power to bestow a benefit on [poor [Higgins]94-higgins]1509-poor higgins . [[My]0-i lord]762-my lord cared nothing for poor [Higgins]94-higgins , but it pleased [him]191-the old earl a little to think that [[his]960-the old man grandson]538-his grandson would be talked about by [the country people]1512-the country people and would begin to be popular with [the tenantry]1268-the tenantry , even in [his]538-his grandson childhood . Then it had gratified [him]191-the old earl to drive to [church]1385-church with [Cedric]39-cedric and to see the excitement and interest caused by the arrival . [He]191-the old earl knew how [the people]644-the people would speak of the beauty of [the little lad]1242-the little lad ; of [his]1242-the little lad fine , strong , straight body ; of [his]1242-the little lad erect bearing , [his]1242-the little lad handsome face , and [his]1242-the little lad bright hair , and how [they]644-the people would say as [the Earl]203-the earl had heard [one woman]1518-one woman exclaim to another that [the boy]2518-the boy was " every inch [a lord]275-a lord . "[644-the people] [[My]0-i lord of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]1520-my lord of dorincourt was [an arrogant old man]1521-an arrogant old man , proud of [his]1520-my lord of dorincourt name , proud of [his]1520-my lord of dorincourt rank , and therefore proud to show [the world]164-the world that at last [the House of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]1523-the house of dorincourt had [an heir who was worthy of the position [he]1520-my lord of dorincourt was to fill]1524-an heir who was worthy of the position he was to fill . The morning the new pony had been tried , [the Earl]203-the earl had been so pleased that [he]203-the earl had almost forgotten [his]203-the earl gout . When [the groom]1526-the groom had brought out the pretty creature , which arched its brown , glossy neck and tossed its fine head in the sun , [the Earl]203-the earl had sat at the open window of [the library]2817-the library and had looked on while [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy took [his]50-fauntleroy first riding lesson . [He]203-the earl wondered if [the boy]2518-the boy would show signs of timidity . It was not a very small pony , and [he]203-the earl had often seen [children]2556-children lose courage in making [their]2556-children first essay at riding . [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy mounted in great delight . [He]50-fauntleroy had never been on [a pony]1288-a pony before , and [he]50-fauntleroy was in the highest spirits . [Wilkins]106-wilkins , [the groom]1526-the groom , led the animal by the bridle up and down before the library window . " [He]2518-the boy 's [a well plucked un]3101-a well plucked un , [he]2518-the boy is , "[106-wilkins] [Wilkins]106-wilkins remarked in [the stable]1285-the stable afterward with many grins . " It were n't no trouble to put [HIM]2518-the boy up . An ' [a old un]3102-a old un would n't [ha]3103-ha ' sat any straighter when [he]2518-the boy WERE up . [He]2518-the boy ses ses [he]2518-the boy to [me]106-wilkins , ' [Wilkins]106-wilkins , ' [he]2518-the boy ses , ' am [I]106-wilkins sitting up straight ? [They]3104-they sit up straight at [the circus]3105-the circus , ' ses [he]2518-the boy . An ' [I]106-wilkins ses , ' As straight as a arrer , [[your]2518-the boy lordship]2792-your lordship ! ' an ' [he]2518-the boy laughs , as pleased as could be , an ' [he]2518-the boy ses , ' That 's right , ' [he]2518-the boy ses , ' [you]106-wilkins tell [me]106-wilkins if [I]106-wilkins do n't sit up straight , [Wilkins]106-wilkins ! ' "[106-wilkins] But sitting up straight and being led at a walk were not altogether and completely satisfactory . After a few minutes , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy spoke to [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather watching [him]50-fauntleroy from the window : " Ca n't [I]335-his grandfather go by [myself]335-his grandfather ? "[335-his grandfather] [he]335-his grandfather asked ; " and ca n't [I]335-his grandfather go faster ? [The boy on [Fifth Avenue]21-fifth avenue]3107-the boy on fifth avenue used to trot and canter ! "[335-his grandfather] " Do [you]203-the earl think [you]203-the earl could trot and canter ? "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl . " [I]50-fauntleroy should like to try , "[50-fauntleroy] answered [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . [[His]335-his grandfather lordship]207-his lordship made a sign to [Wilkins]106-wilkins , who at the signal brought up [his]106-wilkins own horse and mounted [it]1537-it and took [[Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's pony]1538-fauntleroy 's pony by the leading - rein . " Now , "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl , " let [him]1538-fauntleroy 's pony trot . "[203-the earl] The next few minutes were rather exciting to [the small equestrian]1540-the small equestrian . [He]203-the earl found that trotting was not so easy as walking , and the faster the pony trotted , the less easy it was . " It j - jolts a g - goo - good deal do - doesn't it ? "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl said to [Wilkins]106-wilkins . " D - does it j - jolt y - [you]203-the earl ? "[203-the earl] " No , [[my]106-wilkins lord]762-my lord , "[106-wilkins] answered [Wilkins]106-wilkins . " [You]203-the earl 'll get used to it in time . Rise in [your]203-the earl stirrups . "[106-wilkins] " [I]50-fauntleroy 'm ri - rising all the t - time , "[50-fauntleroy] said [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . [He]50-fauntleroy was both rising and falling rather uncomfortably and with many shakes and bounces . [He]50-fauntleroy was out of breath and [his]50-fauntleroy face grew red , but [he]50-fauntleroy held on with all [his]50-fauntleroy might , and sat as straight as [he]50-fauntleroy could . [The Earl]203-the earl could see that from [his]203-the earl window . When [the riders]1542-the riders came back within speaking distance , after [they]1542-the riders had been hidden by the trees a few minutes , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's hat was off , [his]50-fauntleroy cheeks were like poppies , and [his]50-fauntleroy lips were set , but [he]50-fauntleroy was still trotting manfully . " Stop a minute ! "[335-his grandfather] said [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather . " Where 's [your]50-fauntleroy hat ? "[335-his grandfather] [Wilkins]106-wilkins touched [his]50-fauntleroy . " It fell off , [[your]203-the earl lordship]2792-your lordship , "[106-wilkins] [he]106-wilkins said , with evident enjoyment . " Would n't let [me]106-wilkins stop to pick it up , [[my]106-wilkins lord]762-my lord . "[106-wilkins] " Not much afraid , is [he]50-fauntleroy ? "[203-the earl] asked [the Earl]203-the earl dryly . " [Him]50-fauntleroy , [[your]203-the earl lordship]2792-your lordship ! "[106-wilkins] exclaimed [Wilkins]106-wilkins . " [I]106-wilkins should n't say as [he]50-fauntleroy knowed what it meant . [I]106-wilkins 've taught [young gen'lemen]3112-young gen'lemen to ride afore , an ' [I]106-wilkins never see one stick on more determinder . "[106-wilkins] " Tired ? "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl to [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . " Want to get off ? "[203-the earl] " It jolts [you]203-the earl more than [you]203-the earl think it will , "[2570-his young lordship] admitted [[his]106-wilkins young lordship]2570-his young lordship frankly . " And it tires [you]203-the earl a little , too ; but [I]2570-his young lordship do n't want to get off . [I]2570-his young lordship want to learn how . As soon as [I]2570-his young lordship 've got [my]2570-his young lordship breath [I]2570-his young lordship want to go back for the hat . "[2570-his young lordship] [The cleverest person in [the world]164-the world]1547-the cleverest person in the world , if [he]1547-the cleverest person in the world had undertaken to teach [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy how to please [the old man who watched]1549-the old man who watched [him]1547-the cleverest person in the world , could not have taught [him]1547-the cleverest person in the world anything which would have succeeded better . As the pony trotted off again toward [the avenue]802-the avenue , a faint color crept up in the fierce old face , and the eyes , under the shaggy brows , gleamed with a pleasure such as [[his]106-wilkins lordship]207-his lordship had scarcely expected to know again . And [he]106-wilkins sat and watched quite eagerly until the sound of the horses ' hoofs returned . When [they]1552-they did come , which was after some time , [they]1552-they came at a faster pace . [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's hat was still off ; [Wilkins]106-wilkins was carrying it for [him]50-fauntleroy ; [his]50-fauntleroy cheeks were redder than before , and [his]50-fauntleroy hair was flying about [his]50-fauntleroy ears , but [he]50-fauntleroy came at quite a brisk canter . " There ! "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy panted , as [they]1552-they drew up , " [I]50-fauntleroy c - cantered . [I]50-fauntleroy did n't do it as well as [the boy on [Fifth Avenue]21-fifth avenue]3107-the boy on fifth avenue , but [I]50-fauntleroy did it , and [I]50-fauntleroy staid on ! "[50-fauntleroy] [He]50-fauntleroy and [Wilkins]106-wilkins and [the pony]1553-the pony were [close friends]1554-close friends after that . Scarcely a day passed in which [the country people]1512-the country people did not see [them]1552-they out together , cantering gayly on [the highroad]1556-the highroad or through [the green lanes]1332-the green lanes . [The children in [the cottages]1185-the cottages]1558-the children in the cottages would run to the door to look at the proud little brown pony with [the gallant little figure sitting so straight in the saddle]1560-the gallant little figure sitting so straight in the saddle , and [the young lord]1561-the young lord would snatch off [his]1561-the young lord cap and swing it at [them]1558-the children in the cottages , and shout , " Hullo ! Good - morning ! "[1561-the young lord] in a very unlordly manner , though with great heartiness . Sometimes [he]1561-the young lord would stop and talk with [the children]686-the children , and once [Wilkins]106-wilkins came back to [the castle]402-the castle with a story of how [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy had insisted on dismounting near [the village school]1564-the village school , so that [a boy who was lame and tired]1565-a boy who was lame and tired might ride [home]199-home on [his]1565-a boy who was lame and tired pony . " An ' [I]106-wilkins 'm blessed , "[106-wilkins] said [Wilkins]106-wilkins , in telling the story at [the stables]2944-the stables , " [I]106-wilkins 'm blessed if [he]50-fauntleroy 'd hear of anything else ! [He]50-fauntleroy would n't let [me]106-wilkins get down , because [he]50-fauntleroy said [the boy]2518-the boy might n't feel comfortable on a big horse . An ' ses [he]50-fauntleroy , ' [Wilkins]106-wilkins , ' ses [he]50-fauntleroy , ' [that boy]3115-that boy 's lame and [I]106-wilkins 'm not , and [I]106-wilkins want to talk to [him]3115-that boy , too . ' And up [the lad]545-the lad has to get , and [[my]106-wilkins lord]762-my lord trudges alongside of [him]3115-that boy with [his]3115-that boy hands in [his]3115-that boy pockets , and [his]3115-that boy cap on the back of [his]3115-that boy head , a - whistling and talking as easy as [you]3118-you please ! And when [we]3119-we come to [the cottage]3120-the cottage , an ' [[the boy]2518-the boy 's mother]781-the boy 's mother come out all in a taking to see what 's up , [he]3115-that boy whips off [his]3115-that boy cap an ' ses [he]50-fauntleroy , ' [I]106-wilkins 've brought [[your]106-wilkins son]404-your son [home]199-home , [ma'am]426-ma'am , ' ses [he]2518-the boy , ' because [his]2518-the boy leg hurt [him]2518-the boy , and [I]106-wilkins do n't think that stick is enough for [him]2518-the boy to lean on ; and [I]106-wilkins 'm going to ask [[my]106-wilkins grandfather]3090-my grandfather to have a pair of crutches made for [him]2518-the boy . ' An ' [I]106-wilkins 'm blessed if [the woman]816-the woman was n't struck all of a heap , as well [she]816-the woman might be ! [I]106-wilkins thought [I]106-wilkins should ' a ' hex - plodid , [myself]106-wilkins ! "[106-wilkins] When [the Earl]203-the earl heard the story [he]203-the earl was not angry , as [Wilkins]106-wilkins had been half afraid that [he]203-the earl would be ; on the contrary , [he]106-wilkins laughed outright , and called [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy up to [him]203-the earl , and made [him]203-the earl tell all about the matter from beginning to end , and then [he]106-wilkins laughed again . And actually , a few days later , [the Dorincourt carriage]1569-the dorincourt carriage stopped in [the green lane]1418-the green lane before [the cottage where]1571-the cottage where [the lame boy]1572-the lame boy lived , and [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy jumped out and walked up to the door , carrying a pair of strong , light , new crutches shouldered like a gun , and presented them to [Mrs. Hartle]107-mrs. hartle [the lame boy]1572-the lame boy 's name was [Hartle]107-mrs. hartle with these words : " [[My]107-mrs. hartle grandfather]3090-my grandfather 's compliments , and if [you]203-the earl please , these are for [[your]203-the earl boy]3129-your boy , and [we]3130-we hope [he]3129-your boy will get better . "[107-mrs. hartle] " [I]106-wilkins said [your]203-the earl compliments , "[106-wilkins] [he]106-wilkins explained to [the Earl]203-the earl when [he]106-wilkins returned to [the carriage]602-the carriage . " [You]203-the earl did n't tell [me]106-wilkins to , but [I]106-wilkins thought perhaps [you]203-the earl forgot . That was right , was n't it ? "[106-wilkins] And [the Earl]203-the earl laughed again , and did not say it was not . In fact , [the two]1577-the two were becoming more intimate every day , and every day [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's faith in [[his]50-fauntleroy lordship]207-his lordship 's benevolence and virtue increased . [He]50-fauntleroy had no doubt whatever that [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather was [the most amiable and generous of [elderly gentlemen]1581-elderly gentlemen]1580-the most amiable and generous of elderly gentlemen . Certainly , [he]50-fauntleroy [himself]50-fauntleroy found [his]50-fauntleroy wishes gratified almost before they were uttered ; and such gifts and pleasures were lavished upon [him]50-fauntleroy , that [he]50-fauntleroy was sometimes almost bewildered by [his]50-fauntleroy own possessions . Apparently , [he]50-fauntleroy was to have everything [he]50-fauntleroy wanted , and to do everything [he]50-fauntleroy wished to do . And though this would certainly not have been a very wise plan to pursue with [all small boys]1582-all small boys , [[his]50-fauntleroy young lordship]2570-his young lordship bore it amazingly well . Perhaps , notwithstanding [his]50-fauntleroy sweet nature , [he]50-fauntleroy might have been somewhat spoiled by it , if it had not been for the hours [he]50-fauntleroy spent with [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother at [Court Lodge]16-court lodge . [That " best friend "[50-fauntleroy] of [his]50-fauntleroy]1037-that " best friend " of his watched over [him]50-fauntleroy ever closely and tenderly . [The two]1577-the two had many long talks together , and [he]50-fauntleroy never went back to [the Castle]402-the castle with [her]1037-that " best friend " of his kisses on [his]50-fauntleroy cheeks without carrying in [his]50-fauntleroy heart some simple , pure words worth remembering . There was one thing , it is true , which puzzled [the little fellow]655-the little fellow very much . [He]50-fauntleroy thought over the mystery of it much oftener than [any one]233-any one supposed ; even [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother did not know how often [he]50-fauntleroy pondered on it ; [the Earl]203-the earl for a long time never suspected that [he]50-fauntleroy did so at all . But , being quick to observe , [the little boy]153-the little boy could not help wondering why it was that [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother and [grandfather]1594-grandfather never seemed to meet . [He]50-fauntleroy had noticed that [they]1577-the two never did meet . When [the Dorincourt carriage]1569-the dorincourt carriage stopped at [Court Lodge]16-court lodge , [the Earl]203-the earl never alighted , and on the rare occasions of [[his]203-the earl lordship]207-his lordship 's going to [church]1385-church , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy was always left to speak to [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother in [the porch]1397-the porch alone , or perhaps to go [home]199-home with [her]151-his mother . And yet , every day , fruit and flowers were sent to [Court Lodge]16-court lodge from [the hot - houses at [the Castle]402-the castle]1602-the hot - houses at the castle . But the one virtuous action of [the Earl]203-the earl 's which had set [him]203-the earl upon the pinnacle of perfection in [Cedric]39-cedric 's eyes , was what [he]203-the earl had done soon after that first Sunday when [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol had walked [home]199-home from [church]1385-church unattended . About a week later , when [Cedric]39-cedric was going one day to visit [[his]39-cedric mother]151-his mother , [he]39-cedric found at the door , instead of the large carriage and prancing pair , a pretty little brougham and a handsome bay horse . " That is a present from [you]39-cedric to [[your]39-cedric mother]2980-your mother , "[203-the earl] [the Earl]203-the earl said abruptly . " [She]2980-your mother can not go walking about [the country]2425-the country . [She]2980-your mother needs [a carriage]497-a carriage . [The man who drives]3134-the man who drives will take charge of [it]497-a carriage . It is a present from [YOU]39-cedric . "[203-the earl] [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's delight could but feebly express itself . [He]50-fauntleroy could scarcely contain [himself]50-fauntleroy until [he]50-fauntleroy reached [the lodge]2741-the lodge . [[His]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother was gathering roses in [the garden]1611-the garden . [He]50-fauntleroy flung [himself]50-fauntleroy out of the little brougham and flew to [her]151-his mother . " [Dearest]2411-dearest ! "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy cried , " could [you]151-his mother believe it ? This is [yours]151-his mother ! [He]50-fauntleroy says it is a present from [me]50-fauntleroy . It is [[your]151-his mother own carriage]3136-your own carriage to drive everywhere in ! "[50-fauntleroy] [He]50-fauntleroy was so happy that [she]151-his mother did not know what to say . [She]151-his mother could not have borne to spoil [his]50-fauntleroy pleasure by refusing to accept the gift even though it came from [the man who chose to consider [himself]1612-the man who chose to consider himself her enemy [[her]151-his mother enemy]1613-her enemy]1612-the man who chose to consider himself her enemy . [She]151-his mother was obliged to step into [the carriage]602-the carriage , roses and all , and let [herself]151-his mother be taken to drive , while [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy told [her]151-his mother stories of [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather 's goodness and amiability . They were such innocent stories that sometimes [she]151-his mother could not help laughing a little , and then [she]151-his mother would draw [[her]151-his mother little boy]224-her little boy closer to [her]151-his mother side and kiss [him]224-her little boy , feeling glad that [he]224-her little boy could see only good in [the old man , who had so few friends]1617-the old man , who had so few friends . The very next day after that , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy wrote to [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . [He]50-fauntleroy wrote quite a long letter , and after the first copy was written , [he]50-fauntleroy brought it to [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather to be inspected . " Because , "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy said , " it 's so uncertain about the spelling . And if [you]46-mr. hobbs 'll tell [me]50-fauntleroy the mistakes , [I]50-fauntleroy 'll write it out again . "[50-fauntleroy] This was what [he]50-fauntleroy had written : " [[My]50-fauntleroy dear]3137-my dear [mr hobbs]108-mr hobbs [i]50-fauntleroy want to tell [you]46-mr. hobbs about [[my]50-fauntleroy granfarther]3138-my granfarther [he]3138-my granfarther is the best earl [you]46-mr. hobbs ever new it is a mistake about [earls being tirents]3139-earls being tirents [he]3138-my granfarther is not any question but [he]3138-my granfarther has never plaid base ball [he]3138-my granfarther has given [me]50-fauntleroy a pony and a cart and [[my]50-fauntleroy mamma]353-my mamma a bewtifle cariage "[50-fauntleroy] p s [no one]2413-no one is in [the dungon]1621-the dungon [[my]0-i granfarfher]1622-my granfarfher never had [any one langwishin]1623-any one langwishin in [there]221-there . " p s [he]203-the earl is such [a good earl]3165-a good earl [he]203-the earl reminds [me]1622-my granfarfher of [you]1619-your [he]203-the earl is a unerversle favrit "[1622-my granfarfher] " Do [you]203-the earl miss [[your]203-the earl mother]2980-your mother very much ? "[203-the earl] asked [the Earl]203-the earl when [he]203-the earl had finished reading this . " Yes , "[50-fauntleroy] said [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , " [I]50-fauntleroy miss [her]2980-your mother all the time . "[50-fauntleroy] [He]50-fauntleroy went and stood before [the Earl]203-the earl and put [his]50-fauntleroy hand on [his]50-fauntleroy knee , looking up at [him]203-the earl . " [YOU]203-the earl do n't miss [her]2980-your mother , do [you]203-the earl ? "[50-fauntleroy] [he]50-fauntleroy said . " [I]50-fauntleroy do n't know [her]2980-your mother , "[50-fauntleroy] answered [[his]50-fauntleroy lordship]207-his lordship rather crustily . " [I]50-fauntleroy know that , "[50-fauntleroy] said [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , " and that 's what makes [me]50-fauntleroy wonder . [She]2980-your mother told [me]50-fauntleroy not to ask [you]203-the earl any questions , and and [I]50-fauntleroy wo n't , but sometimes [I]50-fauntleroy ca n't help thinking , [you]203-the earl know , and it makes [me]50-fauntleroy all puzzled . But [I]50-fauntleroy 'm not going to ask any questions . And when [I]50-fauntleroy miss [her]2980-your mother very much , [I]50-fauntleroy go and look out of [my]50-fauntleroy window to where [I]50-fauntleroy see [her]2980-your mother light shine for [me]50-fauntleroy every night through an open place in the trees . It is a long way off , but [she]2980-your mother puts it in [her]2980-your mother window as soon as it is dark , and [I]50-fauntleroy can see it twinkle far away , and [I]50-fauntleroy know what it says . "[50-fauntleroy] " What does it say ? "[762-my lord] asked [[my]0-i lord]762-my lord . " It says , ' Good - night , [God]110-god keep [you]203-the earl all the night ! ' just what [she]2980-your mother used to say when [we]3167-we were together . Every night [she]2980-your mother used to say that to [me]762-my lord , and every morning [she]2980-your mother said , ' [God]110-god bless [you]203-the earl all the day ! ' So [you]203-the earl see [I]762-my lord am quite safe all the time "[762-my lord] " Quite , [I]207-his lordship have no doubt , "[207-his lordship] said [[his]762-my lord lordship]207-his lordship dryly . And [he]207-his lordship drew down [his]207-his lordship beetling eyebrows and looked at [the little boy]153-the little boy so fixedly and so long that [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy wondered what [he]207-his lordship could be thinking of .

[IX

The]111-ix the fact was , [[his]762-my lord lordship [the Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]2471-the earl of dorincourt]1631-his lordship the earl of dorincourt thought in those days , of many things of which [he]1631-his lordship the earl of dorincourt had never thought before , and all [his]1631-his lordship the earl of dorincourt thoughts were in one way or another connected with [[his]1631-his lordship the earl of dorincourt grandson]538-his grandson . [His]762-my lord pride was the strongest part of [his]762-my lord nature , and [the boy]2518-the boy gratified it at every point . Through this pride [he]2518-the boy began to find a new interest in life . [He]2518-the boy began to take pleasure in showing [[his]2518-the boy heir]189-his heir to [the world]164-the world . [The world]164-the world had known of [his]2518-the boy disappointment in [[his]2518-the boy sons]1479-his sons ; so there was an agreeable touch of triumph in exhibiting [this new Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , who could disappoint [no one]2413-no one . [He]2518-the boy wished [the child]2539-the child to appreciate [his]2539-the child own power and to understand the splendor of [his]2539-the child position ; [he]2518-the boy wished that [others]436-others should realize it too . [He]2518-the boy made plans for [his]2518-the boy future . Sometimes in secret [he]2518-the boy actually found [himself]2518-the boy wishing that [his]2518-the boy own past life had been a better one , and that there had been less in it that this pure , childish heart would shrink from if it knew the truth . It was not agreeable to think how the beautiful , innocent face would look if [its owner]1642-its owner should be made by any chance to understand that [[his]2518-the boy grandfather]335-his grandfather had been called for many a year " [the wicked Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]3168-the wicked earl of dorincourt . "[2518-the boy] The thought even made [him]2518-the boy feel a trifle nervous . [He]2518-the boy did not wish [the boy]2518-the boy to find it out . Sometimes in this new interest [he]2518-the boy forgot [his]2518-the boy gout , and after a while [[his]2518-the boy doctor]1645-his doctor was surprised to find [[his]2518-the boy noble patient]1646-his noble patient 's health growing better than [he]2518-the boy had expected it ever would be again . Perhaps [the Earl]203-the earl grew better because the time did not pass so slowly for [him]203-the earl , and [he]203-the earl had something to think of beside [his]203-the earl pains and infirmities . One fine morning , [people]248-people were amazed to see [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy riding [his]50-fauntleroy pony with another companion than [Wilkins]106-wilkins . [This new companion]1649-this new companion rode [a tall , powerful gray horse]1650-a tall , powerful gray horse , and was no other than [the Earl]203-the earl [himself]203-the earl . It was , in fact , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy who had suggested this plan . As [he]50-fauntleroy had been on the point of mounting [his]50-fauntleroy pony , [he]50-fauntleroy had said rather wistfully to [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather : " [I]50-fauntleroy wish [you]335-his grandfather were going with [me]50-fauntleroy . When [I]50-fauntleroy go away [I]50-fauntleroy feel lonely because [you]335-his grandfather are left all by [yourself]335-his grandfather in such [a big castle]3169-a big castle . [I]50-fauntleroy wish [you]335-his grandfather could ride too . "[50-fauntleroy] And the greatest excitement had been aroused in [the stables]2944-the stables a few minutes later by the arrival of an order that [Selim]112-selim was to be saddled for [the Earl]203-the earl . After that , [Selim]112-selim was saddled almost every day ; and [the people]644-the people became accustomed to the sight of the tall gray horse carrying [the tall gray old man]1656-the tall gray old man , with [his]1656-the tall gray old man handsome , fierce , eagle face , by the side of the brown pony which bore [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . And in [their]1657-their rides together through [the green lanes]1332-the green lanes and [pretty country roads]1659-pretty country roads , [the two riders]1660-the two riders became more intimate than ever . And gradually [the old man]960-the old man heard a great deal about " [Dearest]48-dearest "[960-the old man] and [her]1662-her life . As [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy trotted by the big horse [he]50-fauntleroy chatted gayly . There could not well have been [a brighter little comrade]1663-a brighter little comrade , [his]960-the old man nature was so happy . It was [he]960-the old man who talked the most . [The Earl]41-dorincourt often was silent , listening and watching the joyous , glowing face . Sometimes [he]41-dorincourt would tell [[his]41-dorincourt young companion]961-his young companion to set [the pony]1553-the pony off at a gallop , and when [the little fellow]655-the little fellow dashed off , sitting so straight and fearless , [he]41-dorincourt would watch [him]655-the little fellow with a gleam of pride and pleasure in [his]41-dorincourt eyes ; and when , after such a dash , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy came back waving [his]50-fauntleroy cap with a laughing shout , [he]50-fauntleroy always felt that [he]50-fauntleroy and [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather were [very good friends]1668-very good friends indeed . One thing that [the Earl]203-the earl discovered was that [[his]41-dorincourt son 's wife]1462-his son 's wife did not lead an idle life . It was not long before [he]41-dorincourt learned that [the poor people]1671-the poor people knew [her]1462-his son 's wife very well indeed . When there was sickness or sorrow or poverty in [any house]1672-any house , [the little brougham]1673-the little brougham often stood before the door . " Do [you]203-the earl know , "[50-fauntleroy] said [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy once , " [they]1671-the poor people all say , ' God bless [you]203-the earl ! ' when [they]1671-the poor people see [her]1462-his son 's wife , and [the children]686-the children are glad . There are [some who go to [[her]1462-his son 's wife house]3172-her house]3171-some who go to her house to be taught to sew . [She]1462-his son 's wife says [she]1462-his son 's wife feels so rich now that [she]1462-his son 's wife wants to help [the poor ones]3173-the poor ones . "[50-fauntleroy] It had not displeased [the Earl]203-the earl to find that [the mother of [[his]203-the earl heir]189-his heir had a beautiful young face and looked as much like [a lady]2463-a lady as if [she]2463-a lady had been [a duchess]1678-a duchess]1675-the mother of his heir had a beautiful young face and looked as much like a lady as if she had been a duchess ; and in one way it did not displease [him]203-the earl to know that [she]2463-a lady was popular and beloved by [the poor]1679-the poor . [The old man]960-the old man would have desired to stand first [himself]960-the old man and have [no rival]1684-no rival . "[203-the earl] [Little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy sat very still in [his]50-fauntleroy saddle for a few moments . Then [he]50-fauntleroy gave a queer little sigh . " What are [you]50-fauntleroy thinking of ? "[203-the earl] asked [the Earl]203-the earl . "[203-the earl] " What was it ? "[203-the earl] inquired [the Earl]203-the earl . " [She]48-dearest said that perhaps it was not so easy to be very rich ; that if [any one]233-any one had so many things always , [one]2449-one might sometimes forget that [every one else]3180-every one else was not so fortunate , and that [one who is rich]3181-one who is rich should always be careful and try to remember . [I]203-the earl was talking to [her]48-dearest about how good [you]50-fauntleroy were , and [she]48-dearest said that was such a good thing , because [an earl]322-an earl had so much power , and if [he]322-an earl cared only about [his]322-an earl own pleasure and never thought about [the people who lived on [[his]322-an earl lands]3184-his lands]3183-the people who lived on his lands , [they]3183-the people who lived on his lands might have trouble that [he]322-an earl could help and there were [so many people]3037-so many people , and it would be such a hard thing . And [I]203-the earl was just looking at all [those houses]3186-those houses , and thinking how [I]203-the earl should have to find out about [the people]644-the people , when [I]203-the earl was [an earl]322-an earl . "[203-the earl] As [[his]1699-he lordship]207-his lordship 's knowledge of [[his]1699-he tenantry]1159-his tenantry consisted in finding out which of [them]1159-his tenantry paid [their]1159-his tenantry rent promptly , and in turning out [those who did not]1702-those who did not , this was rather a hard question . " [Newick]91-newick finds out for [me]1699-he , "[1699-he] [he]1699-he said , and [he]1699-he pulled [his]1699-he great gray mustache , and looked at [[his]1699-he small questioner]1703-his small questioner rather uneasily . "[1699-he] [He]1699-he was very silent as [they]1704-we rode [home]199-home . [He]1699-he felt it to be almost incredible that [he]1699-he who had never really loved [any one in [his]1699-he life]1706-any one in his life , should find [himself]1699-he growing so fond of [this little fellow]1707-this little fellow , as without doubt [he]1699-he was . At first [he]1699-he had only been pleased and proud of [Cedric]39-cedric 's beauty and bravery , but there was something more than pride in [his]1699-he feeling now . [He]1699-he laughed a grim , dry laugh all to [himself]1699-he sometimes , when [he]1699-he thought how [he]1699-he liked to have [the boy]2518-the boy near [him]1699-he , how [he]1699-he liked to hear [his]2518-the boy voice , and how in secret [he]1699-he really wished to be liked and thought well of by [[his]1699-he small grandson]1709-his small grandson . " [I]1699-he 'm [an old fellow in [my]1699-he dotage]3193-an old fellow in my dotage , and [I]1699-he have nothing else to think of , "[1699-he] [he]1699-he would say to [himself]1699-he ; and yet [he]1699-he knew it was not that altogether . And if [he]1699-he had allowed [himself]1699-he to admit the truth , [he]1699-he would perhaps have found [himself]1699-he obliged to own that the very things which attracted [him]1699-he , in spite of [himself]1699-he , were the qualities [he]1699-he had never possessed the frank , true , kindly nature , the affectionate trustfulness which could never think evil . It was only about a week after that ride when , after a visit to [[his]1699-he mother]151-his mother , [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy came into [the library]2817-the library with a troubled , thoughtful face . [He]1699-he sat down in that high - backed chair in which [he]1699-he had sat on the evening of [his]1699-he arrival , and for a while [he]1699-he looked at the embers on the hearth . [The Earl]203-the earl watched [him]1699-he in silence , wondering what was coming . It was evident that [Cedric]39-cedric had something on [his]39-cedric mind . At last [he]1699-he looked up . " Does [Newick]91-newick know all about [the people]644-the people ? "[1699-he] [he]1699-he asked . " It is [his]91-newick business to know about [them]644-the people , "[207-his lordship] said [[his]1699-he lordship]207-his lordship . " Been neglecting it has [he]91-newick ? "[207-his lordship] Contradictory as it may seem , there was nothing which entertained and edified [him]1699-he more than [the little fellow]655-the little fellow 's interest in [[his]1699-he tenantry]1159-his tenantry . [He]1699-he had never taken any interest in [them]1159-his tenantry [himself]1699-he , but it pleased [him]1699-he well enough that , with all [his]1699-he childish habits of thought and in the midst of all [his]1699-he childish amusements and high spirits , there should be such a quaint seriousness working in the curly head . " There is a place , "[50-fauntleroy] said [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , looking up at [him]1699-he with wide - open , horror - stricken eye " [Dearest]48-dearest has seen [it]3195-it ; [it]3195-it is at [the other end of [the village]1168-the village]3196-the other end of the village . [The houses]3198-the houses are close together , and almost falling down ; [you]48-dearest can scarcely breathe ; and [the people]644-the people are so poor , and everything is dreadful ! Often [they]644-the people have fever , and [the children]686-the children die ; and it makes [them]644-the people wicked to live like that , and be so poor and miserable ! It is worse than [Michael]62-michael and [Bridget]61-bridget ! The rain comes in at the roof ! [Dearest]48-dearest went to see [a poor woman who lived [there]221-there]3201-a poor woman who lived there . [Newick]91-newick had not forgotten to tell [him]41-dorincourt ; in fact , [Newick]91-newick had spoken to [him]41-dorincourt more than once of the desperate condition of [the end of [the village]1168-the village known as [[Earl]41-dorincourt 's Court]1719-earl 's court]1717-the end of the village known as earl 's court . [He]91-newick knew all about the tumble - down , [miserable cottages]1720-miserable cottages , and the bad drainage , and the damp walls and broken windows and leaking roofs , and all about the poverty , the fever , and the misery . [Mr. Mordaunt]85-mr. mordaunt had painted it all to [him]91-newick in the strongest words [he]85-mr. mordaunt could use , and [[his]85-mr. mordaunt lordship]207-his lordship had used violent language in response ; and , when [his]85-mr. mordaunt gout had been at the worst , [he]85-mr. mordaunt said that the sooner [the people of [Earl 's Court]24-earl 's court]1722-the people of earl 's court died and were buried by [the parish]1152-the parish the better it would be , and there was an end of the matter . And yet , as [he]91-newick looked at the small hand on [his]91-newick knee , and from the small hand to the honest , earnest , frank - eyed face , [he]91-newick was actually a little ashamed both of [[Earl]41-dorincourt 's Court]1719-earl 's court and [himself]91-newick . " What ! [X

The]113-x the truth was that [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol had found a great many sad things in the course of [her]43-mrs. errol work among [the poor of [the little village]1731-the little village that appeared so picturesque when it was seen from [the moor - sides]1732-the moor - sides]1730-the poor of the little village that appeared so picturesque when it was seen from the moor - sides . Everything was not as picturesque , when seen near by , as it looked from a distance . [She]43-mrs. errol had found idleness and poverty and ignorance where there should have been comfort and industry . And [she]43-mrs. errol had discovered , after a while , that [Erleboro]25-erleboro was considered to be [the worst village in [that part of the country]1734-that part of the country]1733-the worst village in that part of the country . [Mr. Mordaunt]85-mr. mordaunt had told [her]43-mrs. errol a great many of [his]85-mr. mordaunt difficulties and discouragements , and [she]43-mrs. errol had found out a great deal by [herself]43-mrs. errol . [The agents who had managed [the property]1736-the property]1735-the agents who had managed the property had always been chosen to please [the Earl]203-the earl , and had cared nothing for the degradation and wretchedness of [the poor tenants]1738-the poor tenants . Many things , therefore , had been neglected which should have been attended to , and matters had gone from bad to worse . As to [[Earl]41-dorincourt 's Court]1719-earl 's court , [it]1719-earl 's court was a disgrace , with [[its]1719-earl 's court dilapidated houses]1740-its dilapidated houses and [miserable , careless , sickly people]1741-miserable , careless , sickly people . When [first Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol went to [the place]2988-the place , it made [her]43-mrs. errol shudder . Such ugliness and slovenliness and want seemed worse in [a country place]1743-a country place than in [a city]1744-a city . It seemed as if there it might be helped . And as [she]43-mrs. errol looked at [the squalid , uncared - for children growing up in the midst of vice and brutal indifference]1745-the squalid , uncared - for children growing up in the midst of vice and brutal indifference , [she]43-mrs. errol thought of [[her]43-mrs. errol own little boy]1746-her own little boy spending [his]1746-her own little boy days in [the great , splendid castle]1747-the great , splendid castle , guarded and served like [a young prince]1748-a young prince , having no wish ungratified , and knowing nothing but luxury and ease and beauty . And a bold thought came in [[her]43-mrs. errol wise little mother]1749-her wise little mother - heart . Gradually [she]43-mrs. errol had begun to see , as had [others]436-others , that it had been [[her]43-mrs. errol boy]1751-her boy 's good fortune to please [the Earl]203-the earl very much , and that [he]1751-her boy would scarcely be likely to be denied anything for which [he]1751-her boy expressed a desire . " [The Earl]41-dorincourt would give [him]1751-her boy anything , "[43-mrs. errol] [she]43-mrs. errol said to [Mr. Mordaunt]85-mr. mordaunt . " [He]1751-her boy would indulge [his]1751-her boy every whim . Why should not that indulgence be used for the good of [others]436-others ? It is for [me]43-mrs. errol to see that this shall come to pass . "[43-mrs. errol] [She]43-mrs. errol knew [she]43-mrs. errol could trust the kind , childish heart ; so [she]43-mrs. errol told [the little fellow]655-the little fellow the story of [[Earl]41-dorincourt 's Court]1719-earl 's court , feeling sure that [he]655-the little fellow would speak of it to [[his]655-the little fellow grandfather]335-his grandfather , and hoping that some good results would follow . And strange as it appeared to [every one]184-every one , good results did follow . The fact was that the strongest power to influence [the Earl]203-the earl was [[his]335-his grandfather grandson]538-his grandson 's perfect confidence in [him]655-the little fellow the fact that [Cedric]39-cedric always believed that [[his]39-cedric grandfather]335-his grandfather was going to do what was right and generous . [He]39-cedric could not quite make up [his]39-cedric mind to let [him]39-cedric discover that [he]39-cedric had no inclination to be generous at all , and that [he]39-cedric wanted [his]39-cedric own way on all occasions , whether it was right or wrong . It was such a novelty to be regarded with admiration as [a benefactor of [the entire human race]1761-the entire human race]1760-a benefactor of the entire human race , and the soul of [nobility]1762-nobility , that [he]39-cedric did not enjoy the idea of looking into the affectionate brown eyes , and saying : " [I]39-cedric am [a violent , selfish old rascal]3211-a violent , selfish old rascal ; [I]39-cedric never did a generous thing in [my]39-cedric life , and [I]39-cedric do n't care about [[Earl]41-dorincourt 's Court]1719-earl 's court or [the poor people]1671-the poor people "[39-cedric] or something which would amount to the same thing . [He]39-cedric actually had learned to be fond enough of [that small boy with the mop of yellow love - locks]1763-that small boy with the mop of yellow love - locks , to feel that [he]39-cedric [himself]39-cedric would prefer to be guilty of an amiable action now and then . And so though [he]39-cedric laughed at [himself]39-cedric after some reflection , [he]39-cedric sent for [Newick]91-newick , and had quite a long interview with [him]91-newick on the subject of [the Court]1764-the court , and it was decided that the wretched hovels should be pulled down and [new houses]1765-new houses should be built . " It is [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy who insists on it , "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said dryly ; " [he]50-fauntleroy thinks it will improve [the property]1736-the property . [You]3215-you can tell [the tenants]3216-the tenants that it 's [his]50-fauntleroy idea . "[39-cedric] And [he]39-cedric looked down at [his]39-cedric small lordship , who was lying on the hearth - rug playing with [Dougal]73-dougal . The great dog was [[the lad]545-the lad 's constant companion]1767-the lad 's constant companion , and followed [him]545-the lad about everywhere , stalking solemnly after [him]545-the lad when [he]545-the lad walked , and trotting majestically behind when [he]545-the lad rode or drove . Of course , both [the country people]1512-the country people and [the town people]1769-the town people heard of the proposed improvement . At first , [many of [them]1512-the country people]1770-many of them would not believe it ; but when [a small army of [workmen]1772-workmen]1771-a small army of workmen arrived and commenced pulling down [the crazy , squalid cottages]1773-the crazy , squalid cottages , [people]248-people began to understand that [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy had done [them]248-people a good turn again , and that through [his]50-fauntleroy innocent interference the scandal of [[Earl]41-dorincourt 's Court]24-earl 's court had at last been removed . If [he]545-the lad had only known how [they]248-people talked about [him]545-the lad and praised [him]545-the lad everywhere , and prophesied great things for [him]545-the lad when [he]545-the lad grew up , how astonished [he]545-the lad would have been ! But [he]545-the lad never suspected it . [He]545-the lad lived [his]545-the lad simple , happy , child life , frolicking about in [the park]403-the park ; chasing the rabbits to [their]1776-their burrows ; lying under the trees on the grass , or on the rug in [the library]2817-the library , reading wonderful books and talking to [the Earl]203-the earl about [them]248-people , and then telling the stories again to [[his]545-the lad mother]151-his mother ; writing long letters to [Dick]59-dick and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , who responded in characteristic fashion ; riding out at [[his]545-the lad grandfather]335-his grandfather 's side , or with [Wilkins]106-wilkins as [escort]1781-escort . As [they]1782-they rode through [the market town]1783-the market town , [he]545-the lad used to see [the people]644-the people turn and look , and [he]545-the lad noticed that as [they]644-the people lifted [their]644-the people hats [their]644-the people faces often brightened very much ; but [he]545-the lad thought it was all because [[his]545-the lad grandfather]335-his grandfather was with [him]545-the lad . " [They]644-the people are so fond of [you]207-his lordship , "[545-the lad] [he]545-the lad once said , looking up at [[his]545-the lad lordship]207-his lordship with a bright smile . " Do [you]207-his lordship see how glad [they]644-the people are when [they]644-the people see [you]207-his lordship ? [I]545-the lad hope [they]644-the people will some day be as fond of [me]545-the lad . It must be nice to have [[EVERYbody]452-everybody like [you]207-his lordship]3218-everybody like you . "[545-the lad] And [he]545-the lad felt quite proud to be [the grandson of so greatly admired and beloved [an individual]1788-an individual]1787-the grandson of so greatly admired and beloved an individual . When [the cottages]1185-the cottages were being built , [the lad]545-the lad and [[his]545-the lad grandfather]335-his grandfather used to ride over to [[Earl]41-dorincourt 's Court]1719-earl 's court together to look at [them]1185-the cottages , and [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy was full of interest . [He]545-the lad would dismount from [his]545-the lad pony and go and make acquaintance with [the workmen]1793-the workmen , asking [them]1793-the workmen questions about building and bricklaying , and telling [them]1793-the workmen things about [America]2-america . After two or three such conversations , [he]545-the lad was able to enlighten [the Earl]41-dorincourt on the subject of brick - making , as [they]1794-they rode [home]199-home . " [I]545-the lad always like to know about things like those , "[545-the lad] [he]545-the lad said , " because [you]1793-the workmen never know what [you]1793-the workmen are coming to . "[545-the lad] When [he]545-the lad left [them]1793-the workmen , [the workmen]1793-the workmen used to talk [him]545-the lad over among [themselves]1793-the workmen , and laugh at [his]545-the lad odd , innocent speeches ; but [they]1793-the workmen liked [him]545-the lad , and liked to see [him]545-the lad stand among [them]1793-the workmen , talking away , with [his]545-the lad hands in [his]545-the lad pockets , [his]545-the lad hat pushed back on [his]545-the lad curls , and [his]545-the lad small face full of eagerness . " [He]545-the lad 's [a rare un]3219-a rare un , "[1793-the workmen] [they]1793-the workmen used to say . " An ' [a noice little outspoken chap]3220-a noice little outspoken chap , too . Not much o ' th ' bad stock in [him]545-the lad . "[1793-the workmen] And [they]1793-the workmen would go [home]199-home and tell [[their]1793-the workmen wives]1798-their wives about [him]545-the lad , and [the women]3157-the women would tell [each other]2414-each other , and so it came about that almost [every one]184-every one talked of , or knew some story of , [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy ; and gradually almost [every one]184-every one knew that [the " wicked Earl]3221-the " wicked earl "[184-every one] had found something [he]545-the lad cared for at last something which had touched and even warmed [his]545-the lad hard , bitter old heart . But [no one]2413-no one knew quite how much it had been warmed , and how day by day [the old man]960-the old man found [himself]960-the old man caring more and more for [the child]2539-the child , who was the only creature that had ever trusted [him]960-the old man . [He]960-the old man found [himself]960-the old man looking forward to the time when [Cedric]39-cedric would be [a young man]1806-a young man , strong and beautiful , with life all before [him]39-cedric , but having still that kind heart and the power to make [friends]378-friends everywhere , and [the Earl]203-the earl wondered what [the lad]545-the lad would do , and how [he]545-the lad would use [his]545-the lad gifts . Often as [he]960-the old man watched [the little fellow lying upon the hearth , conning some big book , the light shining on the bright young head]1810-the little fellow lying upon the hearth , conning some big book , the light shining on the bright young head , [his]39-cedric old eyes would gleam and [his]39-cedric cheek would flush . " [The boy]2518-the boy can do anything , "[960-the old man] [he]960-the old man would say to [himself]960-the old man , " anything ! "[960-the old man] [He]960-the old man never spoke to any one else of [his]960-the old man feeling for [Cedric]39-cedric ; when [he]960-the old man spoke of [him]39-cedric to [others]436-others it was always with the same grim smile . But [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy soon knew that [[his]50-fauntleroy grandfather]335-his grandfather loved [him]39-cedric and always liked [him]39-cedric to be near near to [his]335-his grandfather chair if [they]1813-we were in [the library]2817-the library , opposite to [him]335-his grandfather at table , or by [his]335-his grandfather side when [he]335-his grandfather rode or drove or took [his]335-his grandfather evening walk on [the broad terrace]1815-the broad terrace . " Do [you]50-fauntleroy remember , "[39-cedric] [Cedric]39-cedric said once , looking up from [his]39-cedric book as [he]39-cedric lay on the rug , " do [you]50-fauntleroy remember what [I]39-cedric said to [you]50-fauntleroy that first night about [our]1813-we being [good companions]3223-good companions ?
