"[203-the earl] The jealous pang that came when [the boy]2518-the boy spoke so of [[his]2518-the boy mother]151-his mother seemed even stronger than it had been before ; it was stronger because of [this old man]1830-this old man 's increasing affection for [the boy]2518-the boy . But it was not long before [he]1830-this old man had other pangs , so much harder to face that [he]1830-this old man almost forgot , for the time , [he]1830-this old man had ever hated [[[his]1830-this old man son]198-his son 's wife]1462-his son 's wife at all . And in a strange and startling way it happened . One evening , just before [[the Earl]203-the earl 's Court cottages]1835-the earl 's court cottages were completed , there was a grand dinner party at [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt . There had not been such a party at [the Castle]402-the castle for a long time . A few days before it took place , [Sir Harry Lorridaile]115-sir harry and [Lady Lorridaile]116-lady lorridaile , who was [[the Earl]203-the earl 's only sister]1838-the earl 's only sister , actually came for a visit a thing which caused the greatest excitement in [the village]1168-the village and set [Mrs. Dibble]87-mrs. dibble 's shop - bell tinkling madly again , because it was well known that [Lady Lorridaile]116-lady lorridaile had only been to [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt once since [her]116-lady lorridaile marriage , thirty - five years before . [She]116-lady lorridaile was [a handsome old lady with white curls and dimpled , peachy cheeks]1840-a handsome old lady with white curls and dimpled , peachy cheeks , and [she]116-lady lorridaile was as good as gold , but [she]116-lady lorridaile had never approved of [[her]116-lady lorridaile brother]1841-her brother any more than did [the rest of [the world]164-the world]1842-the rest of the world , and having a strong will of [her]116-lady lorridaile own and not being at all afraid to speak [her]116-lady lorridaile mind frankly , [she]116-lady lorridaile had , after several lively quarrels with [[his]203-the earl lordship]207-his lordship , seen very little of [him]203-the earl since [her]116-lady lorridaile young days . [She]116-lady lorridaile had heard a great deal of [him]203-the earl that was not pleasant through the years in which [they]1845-they had been separated . [She]116-lady lorridaile had heard about [his]203-the earl neglect of [[his]203-the earl wife]2989-his wife , and of [the poor lady]1847-the poor lady 's death ; and of [his]203-the earl indifference to [[his]203-the earl children]2710-his children ; and of [the two weak , vicious , unprepossessing elder boys who had been no credit to [him]203-the earl or to [any one else]1850-any one else]1849-the two weak , vicious , unprepossessing elder boys who had been no credit to him or to any one else . [Those two elder sons]1851-those two elder sons , [Bevis]117-bevis and [Maurice]118-maurice , [she]116-lady lorridaile had never seen ; but once there had come to [Lorridaile Park]26-lorridaile park [a tall , stalwart , beautiful young fellow about eighteen years old]1852-a tall , stalwart , beautiful young fellow about eighteen years old , who had told [her]116-lady lorridaile that [he]1852-a tall , stalwart , beautiful young fellow about eighteen years old was [[her]116-lady lorridaile nephew]1853-her nephew [Cedric Errol]39-cedric , and that [he]1852-a tall , stalwart , beautiful young fellow about eighteen years old had come to see [her]116-lady lorridaile because [he]1852-a tall , stalwart , beautiful young fellow about eighteen years old was passing near [the place]2988-the place and wished to look at [[his]1852-a tall , stalwart , beautiful young fellow about eighteen years old Aunt Constantia of whom [he]1852-a tall , stalwart , beautiful young fellow about eighteen years old had heard [[his]1852-a tall , stalwart , beautiful young fellow about eighteen years old mother]151-his mother speak]1855-his aunt constantia of whom he had heard his mother speak . [Lady Lorridaile]116-lady lorridaile 's kind heart had warmed through and through at the sight of [the young man]1857-the young man , and [she]116-lady lorridaile had made [him]1857-the young man stay with [her]116-lady lorridaile a week , and petted [him]1857-the young man , and made much of [him]1857-the young man and admired [him]1857-the young man immensely . [He]1857-the young man was so sweet - tempered , light - hearted , spirited [a lad]756-a lad , that when [he]1857-the young man went away , [she]116-lady lorridaile had hoped to see [him]1857-the young man often again ; but [she]116-lady lorridaile never did , because [the Earl]203-the earl had been in a bad humor when [he]1857-the young man went back to [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt , and had forbidden [him]1857-the young man ever to go to [Lorridaile Park]26-lorridaile park again . But [Lady Lorridaile]116-lady lorridaile had always remembered [him]1857-the young man tenderly , and though [she]116-lady lorridaile feared [he]1857-the young man had made a rash marriage in [America]2-america , [she]116-lady lorridaile had been very angry when [she]116-lady lorridaile heard how [he]1857-the young man had been cast off by [[his]1857-the young man father]150-his father and that [no one]2413-no one really knew where or how [he]1857-the young man lived . At last there came a rumor of [his]1857-the young man death , and then [Bevis]117-bevis had been thrown from [his]1857-the young man horse and killed , and [Maurice]118-maurice had died in [Rome]8-rome of the fever ; and soon after came the story of [the American child who was to be found and brought [home]199-home as [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy]1862-the american child who was to be found and brought home as lord fauntleroy . " Probably to be ruined as [the others]3231-the others were , "[116-lady lorridaile] [she]116-lady lorridaile said to [[her]116-lady lorridaile husband]2505-her husband , " unless [[his]39-cedric mother]151-his mother is good enough and has a will of [her]151-his mother own to help [her]151-his mother to take care of [him]39-cedric . "[203-the earl] And so by [degrees Lady Lorridaile]116-lady lorridaile , too , heard of [the child]2539-the child ; [she]1887-she heard about [Higgins]94-higgins and [the lame boy]1572-the lame boy , and [the cottages at [Earl]41-dorincourt 's Court]1889-the cottages at earl 's court , and a score of other things , and [she]1887-she began to wish to see [the little fellow]655-the little fellow . " And [he]50-fauntleroy is [a changed man]3269-a changed man in a measure , and , incredible as it may seem , [Harry]115-sir harry , it is [my]1909-her ladyship opinion that [he]50-fauntleroy is being made into [a human being]3270-a human being , through nothing more nor less than [his]50-fauntleroy affection for [that innocent , affectionate little fellow]3271-that innocent , affectionate little fellow . [[His]50-fauntleroy own children]3273-his own children would as soon have thought of nestling up to a tiger . "[1909-her ladyship] The very next day [she]1908-she went to call upon [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol . When [she]1908-she returned , [she]1908-she said to [[her]1908-she brother]1841-her brother : " [Molyneux]53-molyneux , [she]43-mrs. errol is [the loveliest little woman [I]1908-she ever saw]3274-the loveliest little woman i ever saw ! [She]43-mrs. errol has a voice like a silver bell , and [you]53-molyneux may thank [her]43-mrs. errol for making [the boy]2518-the boy what [he]2518-the boy is . [She]43-mrs. errol has given [him]2518-the boy more than [her]43-mrs. errol beauty , and [you]53-molyneux make a great mistake in not persuading [her]43-mrs. errol to come and take charge of [you]53-molyneux . [I]1908-she shall invite [her]43-mrs. errol to [Lorridaile]115-sir harry . "[1908-she] " [She]43-mrs. errol 'll not leave [the boy]2518-the boy , "[203-the earl] replied [the Earl]203-the earl . " [I]116-lady lorridaile must have [the boy]2518-the boy too , "[116-lady lorridaile] said [Lady Lorridaile]116-lady lorridaile , laughing . [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham had been expected to arrive in the afternoon , but , strange to say , [he]51-mr. havisham was late . Such a thing had really never been known to happen before during all the years in which [he]51-mr. havisham had been [a visitor at [Dorincourt Castle]11-dorincourt castle]3308-a visitor at dorincourt castle . [He]51-mr. havisham was so late that [the guests]3309-the guests were on the point of rising to go in to dinner when [he]51-mr. havisham arrived . When [he]51-mr. havisham approached [[his]51-mr. havisham host]3310-his host , [the Earl]203-the earl regarded [him]51-mr. havisham with amazement . [He]51-mr. havisham looked as if [he]51-mr. havisham had been hurried or agitated ; [his]51-mr. havisham dry , keen old face was actually pale . "[59-dick] [I]0-i was detained , " [he]0-i said , in a low voice to [the Earl]203-the earl , "[0-i] by an extraordinary event . " It was as unlike [the methodic old lawyer]3313-the methodic old lawyer to be agitated by anything as it was to be late , but it was evident that [he]51-mr. havisham had been disturbed . At dinner [he]51-mr. havisham ate scarcely anything , and two or three times , when [he]51-mr. havisham was spoken to , [he]51-mr. havisham started as if [his]51-mr. havisham thoughts were far away . At dessert , when [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy came in , [he]50-fauntleroy looked at [him]51-mr. havisham more than once , nervously and uneasily . [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy noted the look and wondered at it . [He]50-fauntleroy and [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham were on friendly terms , and [they]3314-they usually exchanged smiles . [The lawyer]2506-the lawyer seemed to have forgotten to smile that evening . The fact was , [he]51-mr. havisham forgot everything but the strange and painful news [he]51-mr. havisham knew [he]51-mr. havisham must tell [the Earl]203-the earl before the night was over the strange news which [he]51-mr. havisham knew would be so terrible a shock , and which would change the face of everything . What a blow it was that [he]51-mr. havisham must deal [them]3319-the people gathered together ! [He]51-mr. havisham did not exactly know how the long , superb dinner ended . " There was a movement of the curly head on the yellow satin cushion . " Suddenly [he]0-i sprang up from [his]0-i chair and began to walk up and down [the room]147-the room . Fierce and terrible words poured forth from [his]0-i lips . [His]0-i violence was something dreadful to see , and yet [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham noticed that at the very worst of [his]0-i wrath [he]0-i never seemed to forget [the little sleeping figure on the yellow satin cushion]3348-the little sleeping figure on the yellow satin cushion , and that [he]0-i never once spoke loud enough to awaken it . [I]0-i hated [them]1976-they both ; and [they]1976-they hated [me]0-i ! [Bevis]117-bevis was the worse of [the two]1577-the two . [I]0-i will not believe this yet , though ! [I]0-i will contend against it to the last . But it is like [Bevis]117-bevis it is like [him]117-bevis ! " And then [he]0-i raged again and asked questions about [the woman]816-the woman , about [her]816-the woman proofs , and pacing [the room]147-the room , turned first white and then purple in [his]0-i repressed fury . When at last [he]0-i had learned all there was to be told , and knew the worst , [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham looked at [him]0-i with a feeling of anxiety . [He]0-i looked broken and haggard and changed . [His]0-i rages had always been bad for [him]0-i , but this one had been worse than the rest because there had been something more than rage in it . [He]0-i came slowly back to the sofa , at last , and stood near it . "[117-bevis] If [any one]233-any one had told [me]0-i [I]0-i could be fond of [a child]2490-a child , " [he]0-i said , [his]0-i harsh voice low and unsteady , "[233-any one] [I]0-i should not have believed [them]233-any one . [I]0-i always detested [children]2556-children [my]0-i own more than [the rest]847-the rest . [I]0-i am fond of [this one]1982-this one ; [he]1982-this one is fond of [me]0-i " with a bitter smile . "[1982-this one] [I]0-i am not popular ; [I]0-i never was . But [he]1982-this one is fond of [me]0-i . [He]1982-this one never was afraid of [me]0-i [he]1982-this one always trusted [me]0-i . [He]1982-this one would have filled [my]0-i place better than [I]0-i have filled [it]1983-it . [I]0-i know that . [He]1982-this one would have been an honor to the name . " [He]0-i bent down and stood a minute or so looking at the happy , sleeping face . [His]0-i shaggy eyebrows were knitted fiercely , and yet somehow [he]0-i did not seem fierce at all . [He]0-i put up [his]0-i hand , pushed the bright hair back from the forehead , and then turned away and rang the bell . When [the largest footman]3351-the largest footman appeared , [he]0-i pointed to the sofa . "[1982-this one] Take " [he]0-i said , and then [his]0-i voice changed a little "[1982-this one] take [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy to [[his]50-fauntleroy room]1121-his room . "[50-fauntleroy]

XI

When [[Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs 's young friend]1985-mr. hobbs 's young friend left [him]46-mr. hobbs to go to [Dorincourt Castle]11-dorincourt castle and become [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , and [the grocery - man]1986-the grocery - man had time to realize that [the Atlantic Ocean]1987-the atlantic ocean lay between [himself]46-mr. hobbs and [the small companion who had spent so many agreeable hours in [his]46-mr. hobbs society]1988-the small companion who had spent so many agreeable hours in his society , [he]46-mr. hobbs really began to feel very lonely indeed . The fact was , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs was not [a clever man]1989-a clever man nor even [a bright one]1990-a bright one ; [he]46-mr. hobbs was , indeed , rather [a slow and heavy person]1991-a slow and heavy person , and [he]46-mr. hobbs had never made many acquaintances . [He]46-mr. hobbs was not mentally energetic enough to know how to amuse [himself]46-mr. hobbs , and in truth [he]46-mr. hobbs never did anything of an entertaining nature but read the newspapers and add up [his]46-mr. hobbs accounts . It was not very easy for [him]46-mr. hobbs to add up [his]46-mr. hobbs accounts , and sometimes it took [him]46-mr. hobbs a long time to bring them out right ; and in the old days , [little Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , who had learned how to add up quite nicely with [his]50-fauntleroy fingers and a slate and pencil , had sometimes even gone to the length of trying to help [him]46-mr. hobbs ; and , then too , [he]50-fauntleroy had been so good [a listener]1992-a listener and had taken such an interest in what the newspaper said , and [he]50-fauntleroy and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs had held such long conversations about the Revolution and [the British]47-the british and the elections and [the Republican party]1993-the republican party , that it was no wonder [his]46-mr. hobbs going left a blank in [the grocery store]1994-the grocery store . At first it seemed to [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs that [Cedric]39-cedric was not really far away , and would come back again ; that some day [he]46-mr. hobbs would look up from [his]46-mr. hobbs paper and see [the little lad standing in the door - way]1995-the little lad standing in the door - way , in [his]1995-the little lad standing in the door - way white suit and red stockings , and with [his]1995-the little lad standing in the door - way straw hat on the back of [his]1995-the little lad standing in the door - way head , and would hear [him]1995-the little lad standing in the door - way say in [his]1995-the little lad standing in the door - way cheerful little voice : " Hello , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs ! This is a hot day is n't it ? "[1995-the little lad standing in the door - way] But as the days passed on and this did not happen , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs felt very dull and uneasy . [He]46-mr. hobbs did not even enjoy [his]46-mr. hobbs newspaper as much as [he]46-mr. hobbs used to . [He]46-mr. hobbs would put the paper down on [his]46-mr. hobbs knee after reading it , and sit and stare at the high stool for a long time . There were some marks on the long legs which made [him]46-mr. hobbs feel quite dejected and melancholy . They were marks made by the heels of [the next Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]2746-the next earl of dorincourt , when [he]2746-the next earl of dorincourt kicked and talked at the same time . It seems that even [youthful earls]1997-youthful earls kick the legs of things [they]1997-youthful earls sit on ; noble blood and lofty lineage do not prevent it . After looking at those marks , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs would take out [his]46-mr. hobbs gold watch and open it and stare at the inscription : " From [[his]46-mr. hobbs oldest friend]2685-his oldest friend , [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , to [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . When this [you]46-mr. hobbs see , remember [me]46-mr. hobbs . "[46-mr. hobbs] And after staring at it awhile , [he]46-mr. hobbs would shut it up with a loud snap , and sigh and get up and go and stand in the door - way between the box of potatoes and the barrel of apples and look up [the street]235-the street . At night , when [the store]302-the store was closed , [he]46-mr. hobbs would light [his]46-mr. hobbs pipe and walk slowly along [the pavement]2000-the pavement until [he]46-mr. hobbs reached [the house where [Cedric]39-cedric had lived , on which there was a sign that read , " [This House to Let]3354-this house to let "]3353-the house where cedric had lived , on which there was a sign that read , " this house to let "[46-mr. hobbs] ; and [he]46-mr. hobbs would stop near [it]2001-it and look up and shake [his]46-mr. hobbs head , and puff at [his]46-mr. hobbs pipe very hard , and after a while walk mournfully back again . This went on for two or three weeks before any new idea came to [him]46-mr. hobbs . Being slow and ponderous , it always took [him]46-mr. hobbs a long time to reach a new idea . As a rule , [he]46-mr. hobbs did not like new ideas , but preferred old ones . After two or three weeks , however , during which , instead of getting better , matters really grew worse , a novel plan slowly and deliberately dawned upon [him]46-mr. hobbs . [He]46-mr. hobbs would go to see [Dick]59-dick . [He]46-mr. hobbs smoked a great many pipes before [he]46-mr. hobbs arrived at the conclusion , but finally [he]46-mr. hobbs did arrive at it . [He]46-mr. hobbs would go to see [Dick]59-dick . [He]46-mr. hobbs knew all about [Dick]59-dick . [Cedric]39-cedric had told [him]46-mr. hobbs , and [his]39-cedric idea was that perhaps [Dick]59-dick might be some comfort to [him]46-mr. hobbs in the way of talking things over . So one day when [Dick]59-dick was very hard at work blacking [a customer]2002-a customer 's boots , [a short , stout man with a heavy face and a bald head]2003-a short , stout man with a heavy face and a bald head stopped on the pavement and stared for two or three minutes at the bootblack 's sign , which read : " [PROFESSOR DICK TIPTON]59-dick CAN'T BE BEAT . "[2003-a short , stout man with a heavy face and a bald head] [He]2003-a short , stout man with a heavy face and a bald head stared at it so long that [Dick]59-dick began to take a lively interest in [him]2003-a short , stout man with a heavy face and a bald head , and when [he]46-mr. hobbs had put the finishing touch to [[his]46-mr. hobbs customer]2004-his customer 's boots , [he]46-mr. hobbs said : " Want a shine , [sir]2681-sir ? "[46-mr. hobbs] [The stout man]2005-the stout man came forward deliberately and put [his]2005-the stout man foot on the rest . " Yes , "[2005-the stout man] [he]2005-the stout man said . Then when [Dick]59-dick fell to work , [the stout man]2005-the stout man looked from [Dick]59-dick to the sign and from the sign to [Dick]59-dick . " Where did [you]59-dick get that ? "[2005-the stout man] [he]2005-the stout man asked . " From [a friend o ' mine]3356-a friend o ' mine , "[59-dick] said [Dick]59-dick , " [a little feller]3357-a little feller . [He]3357-a little feller guv ' [me]59-dick the whole outfit . [He]3357-a little feller was [the best little feller [ye]2681-sir ever saw]3358-the best little feller ye ever saw . [He]3357-a little feller 's in [England]1-england now . Gone to be [one o ' them lords]3359-one o ' them lords . "[59-dick] " [Lord Lord]3360-lord lord "[46-mr. hobbs] asked [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , with ponderous slowness , " [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy Goin' to be [Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]359-earl of dorincourt ? "[46-mr. hobbs] [Dick]59-dick almost dropped [his]59-dick brush . " Why , [boss]515-boss ! "[59-dick] [he]59-dick exclaimed , " d ' [ye]515-boss know [him]3357-a little feller yerself ? "[59-dick] " [I]46-mr. hobbs 've known [him]3357-a little feller , "[46-mr. hobbs] answered [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , wiping [his]46-mr. hobbs warm forehead , " ever since [he]3357-a little feller was born . [We]3363-we was [lifetime acquaintances]3364-lifetime acquaintances that 's what [WE]3363-we was . "[46-mr. hobbs] It really made [him]46-mr. hobbs feel quite agitated to speak of it . [He]3357-a little feller was a companion as [ANY man]3365-any man would remember . "[46-mr. hobbs] " [He]3357-a little feller was [the nicest little feller [I]59-dick ever see]3366-the nicest little feller i ever see , "[59-dick] said [Dick]59-dick . " An ' as to sand [I]46-mr. hobbs never seen so much sand to [a little feller]3357-a little feller . "[46-mr. hobbs] " That 's so , "[46-mr. hobbs] said [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . " It was a pity to make a earl out of [HIM]3357-a little feller . "[46-mr. hobbs] And [he]46-mr. hobbs shook [his]46-mr. hobbs head with deeper regret than ever . It proved that [they]2007-they had so much to say to [each other]2414-each other that it was not possible to say it all at one time , and so it was agreed that the next night [Dick]59-dick should make a visit to [the store]302-the store and keep [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs company . The plan pleased [Dick]59-dick well enough . [He]59-dick had been [a street waif]2010-a street waif nearly all [his]59-dick life , but [he]59-dick had never been [a bad boy]2011-a bad boy , and [he]59-dick had always had a private yearning for a more respectable kind of existence . Since [he]59-dick had been in business for [himself]59-dick , [he]59-dick had made enough money to enable [him]59-dick to sleep under a roof instead of out in [the streets]2012-the streets , and [he]59-dick had begun to hope [he]59-dick might reach even a higher plane , in time . So , to be invited to call on [a stout , respectable man who owned [a corner store]2014-a corner store]2013-a stout , respectable man who owned a corner store , and even had [a horse and wagon]281-a horse and wagon , seemed to [him]59-dick quite an event . " Do [you]59-dick know anything about [earls]298-earls and [castles]339-castles ? "[46-mr. hobbs] [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs inquired . " [I]46-mr. hobbs 'd like to know more of [the particklars]28-the particklars . " [I]46-mr. hobbs s'pose there is very little call for 'em , "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said , and that ended the matter . This was the beginning of quite a substantial friendship . When [Dick]59-dick went up to [the store]302-the store , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs received [him]59-dick with great hospitality . "[46-mr. hobbs] Then [he]46-mr. hobbs looked at the story papers , and after that [they]2018-they read and discussed [the British aristocracy]2019-the british aristocracy ; and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs smoked [his]46-mr. hobbs pipe very hard and shook [his]46-mr. hobbs head a great deal . [He]46-mr. hobbs shook it most when [he]46-mr. hobbs pointed out the high stool with the marks on its legs . " There 's [his]46-mr. hobbs very kicks , "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said impressively ; " [his]46-mr. hobbs very kicks . [I]46-mr. hobbs sit and look at 'em by the hour . This is a world of ups an ' it 's [a world of downs]3387-a world of downs . Sometimes [I]46-mr. hobbs says to [myself]46-mr. hobbs , says [I]46-mr. hobbs , ' Well , [I]46-mr. hobbs 'll be jiggered ! ' "[46-mr. hobbs] [He]46-mr. hobbs seemed to derive a great deal of comfort from [his]46-mr. hobbs reflections and [Dick]59-dick 's visit . Before [Dick]59-dick went [home]199-home , [they]2021-they had a supper in [the small back - room]2022-the small back - room ; [they]2021-they had crackers and cheese and sardines , and other canned things out of [the store]302-the store , and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs solemnly opened two bottles of ginger ale , and pouring out two glasses , proposed a toast . " Here 's to [HIM]46-mr. hobbs ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said , lifting [his]46-mr. hobbs glass , " an ' may [he]46-mr. hobbs teach ['em]46-mr. hobbs a lesson earls an ' markises an ' dooks an ' all ! "[46-mr. hobbs] After that night , [the two]1577-the two saw [each other]2414-each other often , and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs was much more comfortable and less desolate . [They]1577-the two read the Penny Story Gazette , and many other interesting things , and gained a knowledge of the habits of [the nobility]2441-the nobility and [gentry]2027-gentry which would have surprised [those despised classes]2028-those despised classes if [they]2028-those despised classes had realized it . One day [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs made a pilgrimage to [a book store down [town]509-town]2029-a book store down town , for the express purpose of adding to [[their]2021-they library]2031-their library . [He]46-mr. hobbs went to [the clerk]2032-the clerk and leaned over the counter to speak to [him]2032-the clerk . " [I]46-mr. hobbs want , "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said , " a book about [earls]298-earls . "[46-mr. hobbs] " What ! "[2032-the clerk] exclaimed [the clerk]2032-the clerk . " A book , "[1986-the grocery - man] repeated [the grocery - man]1986-the grocery - man , " about earls . "[2032-the clerk] " Have n't ? "[46-mr. hobbs] said [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , anxiously . " Well , say markises then or dooks . "[46-mr. hobbs] [He]46-mr. hobbs was just going out of [the store]302-the store , when [the clerk]2032-the clerk called [him]46-mr. hobbs back and asked [him]46-mr. hobbs if a story in which [the nobility]2441-the nobility were [chief characters]2041-chief characters would do . So [the clerk]2032-the clerk sold [him]46-mr. hobbs a book called " [The Tower of [London]7-london]3397-the tower of london , "[2032-the clerk] written by [Mr. Harrison Ainsworth]124-mr. harrison , and [he]46-mr. hobbs carried it [home]199-home . When [Dick]59-dick came [they]2045-they began to read it . It was a very wonderful and exciting book , and the scene was laid in the reign of [the famous English queen who is called by [some people]2047-some people [Bloody Mary]42-mary]2046-the famous english queen who is called by some people bloody mary . And as [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs heard of [Queen Mary]125-minna 's deeds and the habit [she]125-minna had of chopping [people]248-people 's heads off , putting [them]248-people to the torture , and burning [them]248-people alive , [he]46-mr. hobbs became very much excited . [He]46-mr. hobbs took [his]46-mr. hobbs pipe out of [his]46-mr. hobbs mouth and stared at [Dick]59-dick , and at last [he]46-mr. hobbs was obliged to mop the perspiration from [his]46-mr. hobbs brow with [his]46-mr. hobbs red pocket handkerchief . " Why , [he]46-mr. hobbs ai n't safe ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said . " [He]46-mr. hobbs ai n't safe ! [He]46-mr. hobbs 's no more safe than nothing ! Just let [a woman like that]3399-a woman like that get mad , an ' [no one]2413-no one 's safe ! "[46-mr. hobbs] " Well , "[59-dick] said [Dick]59-dick , though [he]59-dick looked rather anxious [himself]59-dick ; " [ye]59-dick see this ' ere un is n't the one that 's bossin ' things now . "[59-dick] " So it is , "[46-mr. hobbs] said [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , still mopping [his]46-mr. hobbs forehead ; ' so it is . An ' the newspapers are not sayin ' anything about any racks , thumb - screws , or stake - burnin 's , but still it does n't seem as if ' t was safe for [him]59-dick over there with [those queer folks]2049-those queer folks . Why , [they]2049-those queer folks tell [me]0-i [they]2049-those queer folks do n't keep the Fourth o ' July ! " [He]46-mr. hobbs was privately uneasy for several days ; and it was not until [he]46-mr. hobbs received [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy 's letter and had read it several times , both to [himself]46-mr. hobbs and to [Dick]59-dick , and had also read the letter [Dick]59-dick got about the same time , that [he]46-mr. hobbs became composed again . But [they]3401-they both found great pleasure in [their]3401-they letters . [They]3401-they read and re - read them , and talked [them]2049-those queer folks over and enjoyed every word of [them]2049-those queer folks . And [they]3401-they spent days over the answers [they]3401-they sent and read [them]2049-those queer folks over almost as often as the letters [they]3401-they had received . It was rather a labor for [Dick]59-dick to write [his]59-dick . All [his]59-dick knowledge of reading and writing [he]59-dick had gained during a few months , when [he]59-dick had lived with [[his]59-dick elder brother]3402-his elder brother , and had gone to [a night - school]3403-a night - school ; but , being [a sharp boy]3404-a sharp boy , [he]59-dick had made the most of that brief education , and had spelled out things in newspapers since then , and practiced writing with bits of chalk on pavements or walls or fences . [He]59-dick told [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs all about [his]59-dick life and about [[his]59-dick elder brother]3402-his elder brother , who had been rather good to [him]59-dick after [[their]3401-they mother]814-their mother died , when [Dick]59-dick was quite [a little fellow]263-a little fellow . [[Their]3401-they father]188-their father had died some time before . [The brother]3409-the brother 's name was [Ben]127-ben , and [he]3409-the brother had taken care of [Dick]59-dick as well as [he]3409-the brother could , until [the boy]2518-the boy was old enough to sell newspapers and run errands . [They]3401-they had lived together , and as [he]2518-the boy grew older [Ben]127-ben had managed to get along until [he]2518-the boy had quite a decent place in [a store]562-a store . "[2049-those queer folks] And then , " exclaimed [Dick]59-dick with disgust , "[2049-those queer folks] blest if [he]2050-he did n't go an ' marry [a gal]2051-a gal ! Just went and got spoony an ' had n't any more sense left ! Married [her]2051-a gal , an ' set up housekeepin ' in [two back rooms]2052-two back rooms . An ' a hefty un [she]2051-a gal was , a regular tiger - cat . [She]2051-a gal 'd tear things to pieces when [she]2051-a gal got mad , and [she]2051-a gal was mad ALL the time . Had [a baby just like [her]2051-a gal]2053-a baby just like her , yell day ' n ' night ! An ' if [I]0-i did n't have to ' tend it ! an ' when it screamed , [she]2051-a gal 'd fire things at [me]0-i . [She]2051-a gal fired a plate at [me]0-i one day , an ' hit [the baby]2054-the baby cut its chin . [Doctor]2055-doctor said [he]2050-he 'd carry the mark till [he]2050-he died . [A nice mother]2056-a nice mother [she]2051-a gal was ! [Crackey]128-crackey ! but did n't [we]2057-we have a time [Ben]127-ben ' n ' mehself ' n ' [the young un]2058-the young un . [She]2051-a gal was mad at [Ben]127-ben because [he]127-ben did n't make money faster ; ' n ' at last [he]127-ben went out [West]2059-west with [a man]2454-a man to set up [a cattle ranch]2061-a cattle ranch . An ' had n't been gone a week ' fore one night , [I]0-i got [home]199-home from sellin ' [my]0-i papers , ' n ' [the rooms]1100-the rooms wus locked up ' n ' empty , ' n ' [the woman o ' [the house]167-the house]2064-the woman o ' the house , [she]2051-a gal told [me]0-i [Minna]125-minna 'd gone shown a clean pair o ' heels . [Some un else]2066-some un else said [she]2051-a gal 'd gone across [the water]2067-the water to be nuss to [a lady]2463-a lady as had [a little baby]2069-a little baby , too . Never heard a word of [her]2051-a gal since [nuther]129-nuther has [Ben]127-ben . If [I]0-i 'd ha ' bin [him]127-ben , [I]0-i would n't [ha]2070-ha ' fretted a bit ' n ' [I]0-i guess [he]127-ben did n't . But [he]127-ben thought [a heap o ']2071-a heap o ' [her]2051-a gal at the start . Tell [you]2072-you , [he]127-ben was spoons on [her]2051-a gal . [She]2051-a gal was [a daisy - lookin ' gal]2073-a daisy - lookin ' gal , too , when [she]2051-a gal was dressed up ' n ' not mad . [She]2051-a gal 'd big black eyes ' n ' black hair down to [her]2051-a gal knees ; [she]2051-a gal 'd make it into a rope as big as [your]2072-you arm , and twist it ' round ' n ' ' round [her]2051-a gal head ; ' n ' [I]0-i tell [you]2072-you [her]2051-a gal eyes 'd snap ! [Folks]2074-folks used to say [she]2051-a gal was [part Itali - un]2075-part itali - un said [[her]2051-a gal mother]2076-her mother or [father]2077-father 'd come from [there]221-there , ' n ' it made [her]2051-a gal queer . [I]0-i tell [ye]2072-you , [she]2051-a gal was one of 'em [she]2051-a gal was ! " [He]0-i often told [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs stories of [her]2051-a gal and of [[his]0-i brother [Ben]127-ben , who , since [his]0-i going out West]3412-his brother ben , who , since his going out west , had written once or twice to [Dick]59-dick . [Ben]127-ben 's luck had not been good , and [he]127-ben had wandered from place to place ; but at last [he]127-ben had settled on [a ranch in [California]29-california , where [he]127-ben was at work at the time when [Dick]59-dick became acquainted with [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs]3413-a ranch in california , where he was at work at the time when dick became acquainted with mr. hobbs . "[2079-that gal] [That gal]2079-that gal , " said [Dick]59-dick one day , ' [she]2079-that gal took all the grit out o ' [him]127-ben . [I]2079-that gal could n't help feelin ' sorry for [him]127-ben sometimes . "[2079-that gal] [They]2080-they were sitting in [the store]302-the store door - way together , and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs was filling [his]46-mr. hobbs pipe . " [He]127-ben ought n't to ' ve married , "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said solemnly , as [he]46-mr. hobbs rose to get a match . " [Women]2521-women [I]46-mr. hobbs never could see any use in 'em [myself]46-mr. hobbs . "[46-mr. hobbs] As [he]46-mr. hobbs took the match from its box , [he]46-mr. hobbs stopped and looked down on the counter . " Why ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said , " if here is n't a letter ! [I]46-mr. hobbs did n't see it before . [The postman]3415-the postman must have laid it down when [I]46-mr. hobbs was n't noticin ' , or the newspaper slipped over it . "[46-mr. hobbs] [He]46-mr. hobbs picked it up and looked at it carefully . " It 's from [HIM]46-mr. hobbs ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs exclaimed . " That 's the very one it 's from ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [He]46-mr. hobbs forgot [his]46-mr. hobbs pipe altogether . [He]46-mr. hobbs went back to [his]46-mr. hobbs chair quite excited and took [his]46-mr. hobbs pocket - knife and opened the envelope . " [I]46-mr. hobbs wonder what news there is this time , "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said . And then [he]46-mr. hobbs unfolded the letter and read as follows : " [DORINCOURT CASTLE]11-dorincourt castle "[46-mr. hobbs] [[My]0-i dear]3137-my dear [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs " [I]46-mr. hobbs write this in a great hury becaus [i]46-mr. hobbs have something curous to tell [you]3137-my dear [i]46-mr. hobbs know [you]3137-my dear will be very mutch suprised [[my]46-mr. hobbs dear]3137-my dear frend when [i]46-mr. hobbs tel [you]3137-my dear . hobbs uncle]3420-my uncle bevis who is dead and [she]3419-a lady whitch has [a little boy]2452-a little boy and [he]2452-a little boy is lord fauntleroy becaus that is the way it is in [England]1-england [the earls eldest sons]3422-the earls eldest sons [little boy]3423-little boy is [the earl]203-the earl if every body else is dead [i]46-mr. hobbs mean if [his]3423-little boy farther and grandfarther are dead [my]46-mr. hobbs grandfarther is not dead but [[my]46-mr. hobbs uncle]3420-my uncle bevis is and so [[his]3420-my uncle boy]3426-his boy is [lord shall not be [an earl]322-an earl [i]46-mr. hobbs would like to be [an earl]322-an earl now better than [i]46-mr. hobbs thout [i]46-mr. hobbs would at first becaus this is [a beautifle castle]3435-a been asking [Wilkins]106-wilkins about grooming horses preaps [i]46-mr. hobbs might be [a groom]3439-a groom or [a coachman]3440-a coachman . [The lady]3432-the lady brought [[her]3432-the lady little boy]224-her little boy to [the castle]402-the castle and [[my]46-mr. hobbs grandfarther]3430-my grandfarther and [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham talked to [her]3432-the lady [i]46-mr. hobbs think [she]3432-the lady was angry [she]3432-the lady talked loud and [[my]46-mr. hobbs grandfarther]3430-my grandfarther was angry too [i]46-mr. hobbs never saw [him]3430-my grandfarther angry before [i]46-mr. hobbs wish it did not make [them]3446-them all mad [i]46-mr. hobbs thort [i]46-mr. hobbs would tell [you]2083-you and [Dick]59-dick right away becaus [you]2083-you would be intrusted so no more at present with love from "[46-mr. hobbs] [your]2083-you old frend " [CEDRIC ERROL]39-cedric Not [lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy . "[46-mr. hobbs] [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs fell back in [his]46-mr. hobbs chair , the letter dropped on [his]46-mr. hobbs knee , [his]46-mr. hobbs pen - knife slipped to the floor , and so did the envelope . " Well ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs ejaculated , " [I]46-mr. hobbs am jiggered ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [He]46-mr. hobbs was so dumfounded that [he]46-mr. hobbs actually changed [his]46-mr. hobbs exclamation . It had always been [his]46-mr. hobbs habit to say , " [I]46-mr. hobbs WILL be jiggered , "[46-mr. hobbs] but this time [he]46-mr. hobbs said , " [I]46-mr. hobbs AM jiggered . "[46-mr. hobbs] Perhaps [he]46-mr. hobbs really WAS jiggered . There is no knowing . " Well , "[59-dick] said [Dick]59-dick , " the whole thing 's bust up , has n't it ? "[59-dick] " Bust ! "[46-mr. hobbs] said [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . " [It]3447-it 's [my]46-mr. hobbs opinion it 's a put - up job o ' [the British ristycrats]3448-the british ristycrats to rob [him]46-mr. hobbs of [his]46-mr. hobbs rights because [he]46-mr. hobbs 's [an American]2860-an american . [They]3448-the british ristycrats 've had a spite agin [us]3450-us ever since the Revolution , an ' [they]3448-the british ristycrats 're takin ' it out on [him]46-mr. hobbs . [I]46-mr. hobbs told [you]2456-his young friend [he]46-mr. hobbs was n't safe , an ' see what 's happened ! Like as not , [the whole gover'ment]3451-the whole gover'ment 's got together to rob [him]46-mr. hobbs of [his]46-mr. hobbs lawful ownin 's . "[46-mr. hobbs] [He]46-mr. hobbs was very much agitated . [He]46-mr. hobbs had not approved of the change in [[his]46-mr. hobbs young friend]2456-his young friend 's circumstances at first , but lately [he]46-mr. hobbs had become more reconciled to it , and after the receipt of [Cedric]39-cedric 's letter [he]46-mr. hobbs had perhaps even felt some secret pride in [[his]46-mr. hobbs young friend]2456-his young friend 's magnificence . [He]46-mr. hobbs might not have a good opinion of [earls]298-earls , but [he]46-mr. hobbs knew that even in [America]2-america money was considered rather an agreeable thing , and if all the wealth and grandeur were to go with the title , it must be rather hard to lose it . " [They]298-earls 're trying to rob [him]2087-that young man ! "[46-mr. hobbs] [he]46-mr. hobbs said , " that 's what [they]298-earls 're doing , and [folks that have money]3452-folks that have money ought to look after [him]2087-that young man . "[46-mr. hobbs] And [he]46-mr. hobbs kept [Dick]59-dick with [him]46-mr. hobbs until quite a late hour to talk it over , and when [that young man]2087-that young man left , [he]2087-that young man went with [him]2087-that young man to the corner of [the street]235-the street ; and on [his]46-mr. hobbs way back [he]46-mr. hobbs stopped opposite [the empty house]2089-the empty house for some time , staring at the " To Let , "[46-mr. hobbs] and smoking [his]46-mr. hobbs pipe , in much disturbance of mind .

XII

A very few days after the dinner party at [the Castle]402-the castle , [almost everybody in [England]1-england]2091-almost everybody in england [who read the newspapers at all]2092-who read the newspapers at all knew the romantic story of what had happened at [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt . It made a very interesting story when it was told with all the details . There was [the little American boy who had been brought to [England]1-england to be [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , and who was said to be so fine and handsome [a little fellow]263-a little fellow , and to have already made [people]248-people fond of [him]2093-the little american boy who had been brought to england to be lord fauntleroy , and who was said to be so fine and handsome a little fellow , and to have already made people fond of him]2093-the little american boy who had been brought to england to be lord fauntleroy , and who was said to be so fine and handsome a little fellow , and to have already made people fond of him ; there was [the old Earl]191-the old earl , [[his]2093-the little american boy who had been brought to england to be lord fauntleroy , and who was said to be so fine and handsome a little fellow , and to have already made people fond of him grandfather]335-his grandfather , who was so proud of [[his]191-the old earl heir]189-his heir ; there was [the pretty young mother]2099-the pretty young mother who had never been forgiven for marrying [Captain Errol]39-cedric ; and there was the strange marriage of [Bevis]117-bevis , [the dead Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , and [the strange wife]2100-the strange wife , of whom [no one]2413-no one knew anything , suddenly appearing with [[her]2100-the strange wife son]1082-her son , and saying that [he]1082-her son was [the real Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy and must have [his]1082-her son rights . All these things were talked about and written about , and caused a tremendous sensation . And then there came the rumor that [the Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]2471-the earl of dorincourt was not satisfied with the turn affairs had taken , and would perhaps contest the claim by law , and the matter might end with a wonderful trial . There never had been such excitement before in [the county in which [Erleboro]25-erleboro was situated]2104-the county in which erleboro was situated . On market - days , [people]248-people stood in groups and talked and wondered what would be done ; [[the farmers]1383-the farmers ' wives]1384-the farmers ' wives invited [one another]2108-one another to tea that [they]1384-the farmers ' wives might tell [one another]2108-one another all [they]1384-the farmers ' wives had heard and all [they]1384-the farmers ' wives thought and all [they]1384-the farmers ' wives thought [other people]155-other people thought . [They]1384-the farmers ' wives related wonderful anecdotes about [the Earl]203-the earl 's rage and [his]203-the earl determination not to acknowledge [the new Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , and [his]203-the earl hatred of [the woman who was [[the claimant]2113-the claimant 's mother]2114-the claimant 's mother]2112-the woman who was the claimant 's mother . But , of course , it was [Mrs. Dibble]87-mrs. dibble who could tell the most , and who was more in demand than ever . " An ' a bad lookout it is , "[87-mrs. dibble] [she]87-mrs. dibble said . " An ' if [you]3453-you were to ask [me]87-mrs. dibble , [ma'am]426-ma'am , [I]87-mrs. dibble should say as it was a judgment on [him]203-the earl for the way [he]203-the earl 's treated [that sweet young cre'tur]3455-that sweet young cre'tur ' as [he]203-the earl parted from [[her]87-mrs. dibble child]2736-her child , for [he]203-the earl 's got that fond of [him]203-the earl an ' that set on [him]203-the earl an ' that proud of [him]203-the earl as [he]203-the earl 's a'most drove mad by what 's happened . An ' what 's more , [this new one]3457-this new one 's [no lady]3458-no lady , as [[his]203-the earl little lordship]1034-his little lordship 's ma is . [She]3457-this new one 's [a bold - faced , black - eyed thing]3460-a bold - faced , black - eyed thing , as [Mr. Thomas]79-thomas says [no gentleman in livery ' u'd bemean hisself to be gave orders by]3461-no gentleman in livery ' u'd bemean hisself to be gave orders by ; and let [her]3457-this new one come into [the house]167-the house , [he]79-thomas says , an ' [he]79-thomas goes out of it . An ' [the boy]2518-the boy do n't no more compare with [the other one]3464-the other one than nothin' [you]3465-you could mention . An ' mercy knows what 's goin' to come of it all , an ' where it 's to end , an ' [you]3465-you might have knocked [me]87-mrs. dibble down with a feather when [Jane]101-mrs. jennifer brought the news . "[87-mrs. dibble] In fact there was excitement everywhere at [the Castle]402-the castle : in [the library]2817-the library , where [the Earl]203-the earl and [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham sat and talked ; in [[the servants]2913-the servants ' hall]2914-the servants ' hall , where [Mr. Thomas]79-thomas and [the butler]1217-the butler and [the other men]2121-the other men and [women servants]2122-women servants gossiped and exclaimed at all times of the day ; and in [the stables]2944-the stables , where [Wilkins]106-wilkins went about [his]106-wilkins work in a quite depressed state of mind , and groomed the brown pony more beautifully than ever , and said mournfully to [the coachman]2124-the coachman that [he]106-wilkins " never taught [a young gen'leman]3466-a young gen'leman to ride as took to it more nat'ral , or was a better - plucked one than [he]3466-a young gen'leman was . [He]3466-a young gen'leman was [a one]3467-a one as it were some pleasure to ride behind . "[2125-that person] But in the midst of all the disturbance there was one person who was quite calm and untroubled . [That person]2125-that person was [the little Lord Fauntleroy who was said not to be [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy at all]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all . When first the state of affairs had been explained to [him]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all , [he]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all had felt some little anxiousness and perplexity , it is true , but its foundation was not in baffled ambition . While [the Earl]203-the earl told [him]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all what had happened , [he]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all had sat on a stool holding on to [his]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all knee , as [he]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all so often did when [he]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all was listening to anything interesting ; and by the time the story was finished [he]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all looked quite sober . " It makes [me]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all feel very queer , "[2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all] [he]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all said ; " it makes [me]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all feel queer ! "[2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all] [The Earl]41-dorincourt looked at [the boy]2518-the boy in silence . It made [him]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all feel queer , too queerer than [he]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all had ever felt in [his]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all whole life . And [he]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all felt more queer still when [he]2126-the little lord fauntleroy who was said not to be lord fauntleroy at all saw that there was a troubled expression on the small face which was usually so happy . " Will [they]3468-they take [[Dearest]48-dearest 's house]3469-dearest 's house from [her]48-dearest and [[her]48-dearest carriage]3470-her carriage ? "[39-cedric] [Cedric]39-cedric asked in a rather unsteady , anxious little voice . " NO ! "[203-the earl] said [the Earl]203-the earl decidedly in quite a loud voice , in fact . " [They]3468-they can take nothing from [her]48-dearest . "[203-the earl] " Ah ! "[39-cedric] said [Cedric]39-cedric , with evident relief . " Ca n't [they]3468-they ? "[39-cedric] Then [he]39-cedric looked up at [[his]39-cedric grandfather]335-his grandfather , and there was a wistful shade in [his]39-cedric eyes , and they looked very big and soft . " [That other boy]3471-that other boy , "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said rather tremulously " [he]3471-that other boy will have to to be [[your]335-his grandfather boy]3129-your boy now as [I]39-cedric was wo n't [he]3471-that other boy ? "[39-cedric] " NO ! "[203-the earl] answered [the Earl]203-the earl and [he]203-the earl said it so fiercely and loudly that [Cedric]39-cedric quite jumped . " No ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric exclaimed , in wonderment . " Wo n't [he]3471-that other boy ? [I]39-cedric thought "[39-cedric] [He]39-cedric stood up from [his]39-cedric stool quite suddenly . " Shall [I]39-cedric be [[your]335-his grandfather boy]3129-your boy , even if [I]39-cedric 'm not going to be [an earl]322-an earl ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said . " Shall [I]39-cedric be [[your]335-his grandfather boy]3129-your boy , just as [I]39-cedric was before ? "[39-cedric] And [his]39-cedric flushed little face was all alight with eagerness . How [the old Earl]191-the old earl did look at [him]39-cedric from head to foot , to be sure ! How [his]191-the old earl great shaggy brows did draw themselves together , and how queerly [his]191-the old earl deep eyes shone under them how very queerly ! " [[My]191-the old earl boy]3476-my boy ! "[191-the old earl] [he]191-the old earl said and , if [you]2133-you 'll believe it , [his]191-the old earl very voice was queer , almost shaky and a little broken and hoarse , not at all what [you]2133-you would expect [an Earl]322-an earl 's voice to be , though [he]191-the old earl spoke more decidedly and peremptorily even than before , " Yes , [you]3476-my boy 'll be [[my]191-the old earl boy]3476-my boy as long as [I]191-the old earl live ; and , by [George]58-george washington , sometimes [I]191-the old earl feel as if [you]3476-my boy were [the only boy [I]191-the old earl had ever had]3478-the only boy i had ever had . "[191-the old earl] [Cedric]39-cedric 's face turned red to the roots of [his]39-cedric hair ; it turned red with relief and pleasure . [He]39-cedric put both [his]39-cedric hands deep into [his]39-cedric pockets and looked squarely into [[his]39-cedric noble relative]1004-his noble relative 's eyes . " Do [you]1004-his noble relative ? "[39-cedric] [he]39-cedric said . " Well , then , [I]39-cedric do n't care about [the earl]203-the earl part at all . [I]39-cedric do n't care whether [I]39-cedric 'm [an earl]322-an earl or not . That was what made [me]39-cedric feel so queer . "[39-cedric] [The Earl]41-dorincourt put [his]41-dorincourt hand on [his]39-cedric shoulder and drew [him]39-cedric nearer . " [They]3483-they shall take nothing from [you]39-cedric that [I]41-dorincourt can hold for [you]39-cedric , "[41-dorincourt] [he]41-dorincourt said , drawing [his]41-dorincourt breath hard . " [I]41-dorincourt wo n't believe yet that [they]3483-they can take anything from [you]39-cedric . "[41-dorincourt] It scarcely seemed as if [he]41-dorincourt were speaking to [a child]2490-a child , there was such determination in [his]41-dorincourt face and voice ; it was more as if [he]41-dorincourt were making a promise to [himself]41-dorincourt and perhaps [he]41-dorincourt was . [He]41-dorincourt had never before known how deep a hold upon [him]41-dorincourt [his]41-dorincourt fondness for [the boy]2518-the boy and [his]41-dorincourt pride in [him]2518-the boy had taken . [He]41-dorincourt had never seen [his]41-dorincourt strength and good qualities and beauty as [he]41-dorincourt seemed to see them now . And [he]41-dorincourt had determined that [he]41-dorincourt would not give it up without a fierce struggle . " [I]2171-he used to hate [you]43-mrs. errol ; [I]2171-he have been jealous of [you]43-mrs. errol . This wretched , disgraceful business has changed that . Treat [me]2171-he as well as [you]43-mrs. errol can , for [the boy]2518-the boy 's sake . "[2171-he] [He]2171-he said it all in [his]2171-he harsh voice , and almost roughly , but somehow [he]2171-he seemed so broken down for the time that [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol was touched to the heart . " [You]2171-he have been so much troubled that [you]2171-he are very tired , and [you]2171-he need all [your]2171-he strength . "[43-mrs. errol] It was just as new to [him]2171-he to be spoken to and cared for in that gentle , simple way as it was to be contradicted . [He]2171-he was reminded of " [the boy]2518-the boy "[43-mrs. errol] again , and [he]2171-he actually did as [she]43-mrs. errol asked [him]2171-he . Perhaps [his]2171-he disappointment and wretchedness were good discipline for [him]2171-he ; if [he]2171-he had not been wretched [he]2171-he might have continued to hate [her]43-mrs. errol , but just at present [he]2171-he found [her]43-mrs. errol a little soothing . Almost anything would have seemed pleasant by contrast with [Lady Fauntleroy]130-lady fauntleroy ; and [this one]1982-this one had so sweet a face and voice , and a pretty dignity when [she]43-mrs. errol spoke or moved . Very soon , through the quiet magic of these influences , [he]2171-he began to feel less gloomy , and then [he]2171-he talked still more . " Whatever happens , "[2171-he] [he]2171-he said , " [the boy]2518-the boy shall be provided for . [He]2518-the boy shall be taken care of , now and in the future . "[2171-he] Before [he]2171-he went away , [he]2171-he glanced around [the room]147-the room . " Do [you]43-mrs. errol like [the house]167-the house ? "[2171-he] [he]2171-he demanded . " Very much , "[43-mrs. errol] [she]43-mrs. errol answered . " This is [a cheerful room]3544-a cheerful room , "[2171-he] [he]2171-he said . And then [he]2171-he went out to [[his]2171-he carriage]234-his carriage and drove away , [Thomas]79-thomas and [Henry]115-sir harry almost stricken dumb upon the box at the turn affairs had taken .

[XIII]133-xiii

OF course , as soon as the story of [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy and the difficulties of [the Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]2471-the earl of dorincourt were discussed in the English newspapers , they were discussed in the American newspapers . The story was too interesting to be passed over lightly , and it was talked of a great deal . There were so many versions of it that it would have been an edifying thing to buy all the papers and compare them . [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs read so much about it that [he]46-mr. hobbs became quite bewildered . One paper described [[his]2171-he young friend]2456-his young friend [Cedric]39-cedric as [an infant in arms]2177-an infant in arms , another as [a young man at [Oxford]30-oxford]2178-a young man at oxford , winning all the honors , and distinguishing [himself]2171-he by writing Greek poems ; one said [he]2171-he was engaged to [a young lady of great beauty]2179-a young lady of great beauty , who was [the daughter of [a duke]2181-a duke]2180-the daughter of a duke ; another said [he]2171-he had just been married ; the only thing , in fact , which was NOT said was that [he]2171-he was [a little boy between seven and eight , with handsome legs and curly hair]2182-a little boy between seven and eight , with handsome legs and curly hair . [One]2449-one said [he]2171-he was no relation to [the Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]2471-the earl of dorincourt at all , but was [a small impostor who had sold newspapers and slept in [the streets of [New York]4-new york]2186-the streets of new york before [[his]2171-he mother]151-his mother imposed upon [the family]3533-the family lawyer , who came to [America]2-america to look for [[the Earl]203-the earl 's heir]2190-the earl 's heir]2185-a small impostor who had sold newspapers and slept in the streets of new york before his mother imposed upon the family lawyer , who came to america to look for the earl 's heir . Then came the descriptions of [the new Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy and [[his]2171-he mother]151-his mother . Sometimes [she]151-his mother was [a gypsy]2192-a gypsy , sometimes [an actress]2193-an actress , sometimes [a beautiful Spaniard]2194-a beautiful spaniard ; but it was always agreed that [the Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]2471-the earl of dorincourt was [[her]151-his mother deadly enemy]2196-her deadly enemy , and would not acknowledge [[her]151-his mother son]1082-her son as [[his]2471-the earl of dorincourt heir]189-his heir if [he]2471-the earl of dorincourt could help it , and as there seemed to be some slight flaw in the papers [she]151-his mother had produced , it was expected that there would be a long trial , which would be far more interesting than anything ever carried into court before . [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs used to read the papers until [his]46-mr. hobbs head was in a whirl , and in the evening [he]46-mr. hobbs and [Dick]59-dick would talk it all over . [They]2199-they found out what [an important personage]2200-an important personage [an Earl of]2201-an earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt was , and what a magnificent income [he]2471-the earl of dorincourt possessed , and how many estates [he]2471-the earl of dorincourt owned , and how stately and beautiful was [the Castle in which [he]2471-the earl of dorincourt lived]2202-the castle in which he lived ; and the more [they]2199-they learned , the more excited [they]2199-they became . " Seems like somethin' orter be done , "[46-mr. hobbs] said [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs . " Things like [them]3547-them orter be held on to [earls]298-earls or [no earls]3549-no earls . "[46-mr. hobbs] But there really was nothing [they]2199-they could do but [each]2203-each write a letter to [Cedric]39-cedric , containing assurances of [their]2199-they friendship and sympathy . [They]2199-they wrote those letters as soon as [they]2199-they could after receiving the news ; and after having written them , [they]2199-they handed them over to [each other]2414-each other to be read . This is what [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs read in [Dick]59-dick 's letter : " DERE FREND : [i]46-mr. hobbs got ure letter an [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs got [his]46-mr. hobbs an [we]2199-they are sory [u]2199-they are down on ure luck an [we]2199-they say hold on as longs [u]2199-they kin an do nt let [no one]2413-no one git ahed of u. " [Professor Dick Tipton]59-dick had always been [a sharp boy]3404-a sharp boy , and earning [his]59-dick living in [the streets of [a big city]3567-a big city]3566-the streets of a big city had made [him]59-dick still sharper . [He]46-mr. hobbs began to write a letter to [Ben]127-ben , and [he]46-mr. hobbs cut out the picture and inclosed it to [him]127-ben , and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs wrote a letter to [Cedric]39-cedric and one to [the Earl]203-the earl . " And leaving [the store]302-the store in the care of [a substitute]3572-a substitute , [he]46-mr. hobbs struggled into [his]46-mr. hobbs coat and marched [down - town]3573-down - town with [Dick]59-dick , and [the two]1577-the two presented [themselves]1577-the two with [their]1577-the two romantic story in [[Mr. Harrison]124-mr. harrison 's office]3575-mr. harrison 's office , much to [that young man]2087-that young man 's astonishment . "[2236-lawyers] And , " said [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs , ' say what [your]59-dick time 's worth a ' hour and look into this thing thorough , and [I'LL]46-mr. hobbs pay the damage , [Silas Hobbs]136-silas hobbs , corner of [Blank street]35-blank street , [Vegetables]36-vegetables and [Fancy Groceries]37-fancy groceries . "[2236-lawyers] " Well , "[124-mr. harrison] said [Mr. Harrison]124-mr. harrison , " it will be a big thing if it turns out all right , and it will be almost as big a thing for [me]124-mr. harrison as for [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy ; and , at any rate , no harm can be done by investigating . "[124-mr. harrison] And actually , before the sun went down , two letters had been written and sent in two different directions one speeding out of [New York]4-new york harbor on [a mail steamer]2238-a mail steamer on [its]2238-a mail steamer way to [England]1-england , and the other on [a train]2239-a train carrying letters and passengers bound for [California]29-california . And after [the store]302-the store was closed that evening , [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs and [Dick]59-dick sat in [the back - room]2241-the back - room and talked together until midnight .

XIV

It is astonishing how short a time it takes for very wonderful things to happen . It had taken only a few minutes , apparently , to change all the fortunes of [the little boy dangling [his]2242-the little boy dangling his red legs from the high stool in mr. hobbs 's store red legs from the high stool in [[Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs 's store]2243-mr. hobbs 's store]2242-the little boy dangling his red legs from the high stool in mr. hobbs 's store , and to transform [him]2242-the little boy dangling his red legs from the high stool in mr. hobbs 's store from [a small boy]2244-a small boy , living the simplest life in [a quiet street]219-a quiet street , into [an English nobleman]2246-an english nobleman , [the heir to an earldom and magnificent wealth]2247-the heir to an earldom and magnificent wealth . It had taken only a few minutes , apparently , to change [him]2242-the little boy dangling his red legs from the high stool in mr. hobbs 's store from [an English nobleman]2246-an english nobleman into [a penniless little impostor , with no right to any of the splendors [he]2242-the little boy dangling his red legs from the high stool in mr. hobbs 's store had been enjoying]2249-a penniless little impostor , with no right to any of the splendors he had been enjoying . And , surprising as it may appear , it did not take nearly so long a time as [one]2449-one might have expected , to alter the face of everything again and to give back to [him]2242-the little boy dangling his red legs from the high stool in mr. hobbs 's store all that [he]2242-the little boy dangling his red legs from the high stool in mr. hobbs 's store had been in danger of losing . It took the less time because , after all , [the woman who had called [herself]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy [Lady Fauntleroy]130-lady fauntleroy]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy was not nearly so clever as [she]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy was wicked ; and when [she]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy had been closely pressed by [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham 's questions about [her]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy marriage and [[her]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy boy]1751-her boy , [she]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy had made one or two blunders which had caused suspicion to be awakened ; and then [she]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy had lost [her]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy presence of mind and [her]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy temper , and in [her]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy excitement and anger had betrayed [herself]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy still further . All the mistakes [she]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy made were about [[her]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy child]2736-her child . There seemed no doubt that [she]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy had been married to [Bevis]117-bevis , [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , and had quarreled with [him]117-bevis and had been paid to keep away from [him]117-bevis ; but [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham found out that [her]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy story of [the boy]2518-the boy 's being born in [a certain part of [London]7-london]2255-a certain part of london was false ; and just when [they]2256-they all were in the midst of the commotion caused by this discovery , there came the letter from [the young lawyer in [New York]4-new york]2257-the young lawyer in new york , and [Mr. Hobbs]46-mr. hobbs 's letters also . What an evening it was when those letters arrived , and when [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham and [the Earl]203-the earl sat and talked [their]2256-they plans over in [the library]2817-the library ! " After [my]51-mr. havisham first three meetings with [her]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy , "[51-mr. havisham] said [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham , " [I]51-mr. havisham began to suspect [her]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy strongly . It appeared to [me]51-mr. havisham that [the child]2539-the child was older than [she]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy said [he]2539-the child was , and [she]2251-the woman who had called herself lady fauntleroy made a slip in speaking of the date of [his]2539-the child birth and then tried to patch the matter up . The story these letters bring fits in with several of [my]51-mr. havisham suspicions . [Our]2256-they best plan will be to cable at once for [these two Tiptons]3584-these two tiptons , say nothing about [them]3584-these two tiptons to [her]2260-her , and suddenly confront [her]2260-her with [them]3584-these two tiptons when [she]2260-her is not expecting it . [She]2260-her is only [a very clumsy plotter]3585-a very clumsy plotter , after all . [My]51-mr. havisham opinion is that [she]2260-her will be frightened out of [her]2260-her wits , and will betray [herself]2260-her on the spot . "[51-mr. havisham] And that was what actually happened . [She]2260-her was told nothing , and [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham kept [her]2260-her from suspecting anything by continuing to have interviews with [her]2260-her , in which [he]51-mr. havisham assured [her]2260-her [he]51-mr. havisham was investigating [her]2260-her statements ; and [she]2260-her really began to feel so secure that [her]2260-her spirits rose immensely and [she]2260-her began to be as insolent as might have been expected . But one fine morning , as [she]2260-her sat in [[her]2260-her sitting - room at [the inn]2261-the inn called " [The Dorincourt Arms]38-the dorincourt arms]3586-her sitting - room at the inn called " the dorincourt arms , "[51-mr. havisham] making some very fine plans for [herself]2260-her , [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham was announced ; and when [he]51-mr. havisham entered , [he]51-mr. havisham was followed by [no less than three persons one]2262-no less than three persons one was [a sharp - faced boy]2263-a sharp - faced boy and one was [a big young man]2264-a big young man and [the third]2265-the third was [the Earl of [Dorincourt]41-dorincourt]2471-the earl of dorincourt . [She]2260-her sprang to [her]2260-her feet and actually uttered a cry of terror . It broke from [her]2260-her before [she]2260-her had time to check it . [She]2260-her had thought of [these new - comers]2267-these new - comers as being thousands of miles away , when [she]2260-her had ever thought of [them]2267-these new - comers at all , which [she]2260-her had scarcely done for years . [She]2260-her had never expected to see [them]2267-these new - comers again . It must be confessed that [Dick]59-dick grinned a little when [he]59-dick saw [her]2260-her . " Hello , [Minna]125-minna ! "[59-dick] [he]59-dick said . [The big young man who was [Ben]138-ben]2268-the big young man who was ben stood still a minute and looked at [her]2260-her . " Do [you]2268-the big young man who was ben know [her]2260-her ? "[138-ben] [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham asked , glancing from one to [the other]2269-the other . " Yes , "[138-ben] said [Ben]138-ben . " [I]2268-the big young man who was ben know [her]2260-her and [she]2260-her knows [me]2268-the big young man who was ben . "[2268-the big young man who was ben] And [he]2268-the big young man who was ben turned [his]2268-the big young man who was ben back on [her]2260-her and went and stood looking out of the window , as if the sight of [her]2260-her was hateful to [him]2268-the big young man who was ben , as indeed it was . Then [the woman]816-the woman , seeing [herself]816-the woman so baffled and exposed , lost all control over [herself]816-the woman and flew into such a rage as [Ben]138-ben and [Dick]59-dick had often seen [her]816-the woman in before . [Dick]59-dick grinned a trifle more as [he]59-dick watched [her]816-the woman and heard the names [she]816-the woman called [them]2271-them all and the violent threats [she]816-the woman made , but [Ben]138-ben did not turn to look at [her]816-the woman . " [I]138-ben can swear to [her]2260-her in any court , "[138-ben] [he]138-ben said to [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham , " and [I]138-ben can bring [a dozen others]3587-a dozen others who will . [[Her]2260-her father]3588-her father is [a respectable sort of man]3589-a respectable sort of man , though [he]3588-her father 's low down in [the world]164-the world . [[Her]2260-her mother]2076-her mother was just like [herself]2076-her mother . [She]2076-her mother 's dead , but [he]3588-her father 's alive , and [he]3588-her father 's honest enough to be ashamed of [her]2076-her mother . [He]3588-her father 'll tell [you]51-mr. havisham who [she]2076-her mother is , and whether [she]2076-her mother married [me]138-ben or not . "[138-ben] Then [he]51-mr. havisham clenched [his]51-mr. havisham hand suddenly and turned on [her]2272-her . " Where 's [the child]2539-the child ? "[51-mr. havisham] [he]51-mr. havisham demanded . " [He]3588-her father 's going with [me]51-mr. havisham ! [He]3588-her father is done with [you]2272-her , and so am [I]51-mr. havisham ! "[51-mr. havisham] And just as [he]51-mr. havisham finished saying the words , the door leading into [the bedroom]2273-the bedroom opened a little , and [the boy , probably attracted by the sound of the loud voices]2274-the boy , probably attracted by the sound of the loud voices , looked in . [He]51-mr. havisham was not [a handsome boy]765-a handsome boy , but [he]51-mr. havisham had rather a nice face , and [he]51-mr. havisham was quite like [Ben]138-ben , [[his]51-mr. havisham father]150-his father , as [any one]233-any one could see , and there was the three - cornered scar on [his]51-mr. havisham chin . [Ben]138-ben walked up to [him]51-mr. havisham and took [his]51-mr. havisham hand , and [his]138-ben own was trembling . " Yes , "[138-ben] [he]138-ben said , " [I]138-ben could swear to [him]51-mr. havisham , too . [Tom]79-thomas , "[138-ben] [he]138-ben said to [the little fellow]655-the little fellow , " [I]138-ben 'm [[your]79-thomas father]2828-your father ; [I]138-ben 've come to take [you]79-thomas away . Where 's [your]79-thomas hat ? "[138-ben] [The boy]2518-the boy pointed to where it lay on a chair . It evidently rather pleased [him]2518-the boy to hear that [he]138-ben was going away . [He]138-ben had been so accustomed to queer experiences that it did not surprise [him]138-ben to be told by [a stranger]2280-a stranger that [he]138-ben was [[his]138-ben father]150-his father . [He]138-ben objected so much to [the woman who had come a few months before to [the place where [he]138-ben had lived since [his]138-ben babyhood]2283-the place where he had lived since his babyhood , and who had suddenly announced that [she]2282-the woman who had come a few months before to the place where he had lived since his babyhood , and who had suddenly announced that she was his mother was [[his]138-ben mother]151-his mother]2282-the woman who had come a few months before to the place where he had lived since his babyhood , and who had suddenly announced that she was his mother , that [he]138-ben was quite ready for a change . [Ben]138-ben took up the hat and marched to the door . " If [you]51-mr. havisham want [me]138-ben again , "[138-ben] [he]138-ben said to [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham , " [you]51-mr. havisham know where to find [me]138-ben . "[138-ben] [He]138-ben walked out of [the room]147-the room , holding [the child]2539-the child 's hand and not looking at [the woman]816-the woman once . [She]816-the woman was fairly raving with fury , and [the Earl]203-the earl was calmly gazing at [her]816-the woman through [his]203-the earl eyeglasses , which [he]203-the earl had quietly placed upon [his]203-the earl aristocratic , eagle nose . " Come , come , [[my]51-mr. havisham young woman]3594-my young woman , "[51-mr. havisham] said [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham . " This wo n't do at all . If [you]3594-my young woman do n't want to be locked up , [you]3594-my young woman really must behave [yourself]3594-my young woman . "[51-mr. havisham] And there was something so very business - like in [his]51-mr. havisham tones that , probably feeling that the safest thing [she]816-the woman could do would be to get out of the way , [she]816-the woman gave [him]51-mr. havisham one savage look and dashed past [him]51-mr. havisham into [the next room]1094-the next room and slammed the door . " [We]3595-we shall have no more trouble with [her]816-the woman , "[51-mr. havisham] said [Mr. Havisham]51-mr. havisham . And [he]51-mr. havisham was right ; for that very night [she]816-the woman left [the Dorincourt Arms]38-the dorincourt arms and took [the train]2290-the train to [London]7-london , and was seen no more . When [the Earl]203-the earl left [the room]147-the room after the interview , [he]203-the earl went at once to [[his]203-the earl carriage]234-his carriage . " To [Court Lodge]16-court lodge , "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl said to [Thomas]79-thomas . " To [Court Lodge]16-court lodge , "[79-thomas] said [Thomas]79-thomas to [the coachman]2124-the coachman as [he]79-thomas mounted the box ; " an ' [you]203-the earl may depend on it , things are taking a uniggspected turn . "[79-thomas] When [the carriage]602-the carriage stopped at [Court Lodge]16-court lodge , [Cedric]39-cedric was in [the drawing - room]1895-the drawing - room with [[his]39-cedric mother]151-his mother . [The Earl]203-the earl came in without being announced . [He]203-the earl looked an inch or so taller , and a great many years younger . [His]203-the earl deep eyes flashed . " Where , "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl said , " is [Lord Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy ? "[203-the earl] [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol came forward , a flush rising to [her]43-mrs. errol cheek . "[203-the earl] Then [he]203-the earl put [his]203-the earl other hand on [Cedric]39-cedric 's shoulder . " [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy , "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl said in [his]203-the earl unceremonious , authoritative way , " ask [[your]50-fauntleroy mother]2980-your mother when [she]2980-your mother will come to [us]3597-us at [the Castle]402-the castle . "[203-the earl] [Fauntleroy]50-fauntleroy flung [his]50-fauntleroy arms around [[his]50-fauntleroy mother]151-his mother 's neck . " To live with [us]3597-us ! "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl cried . " To live with [us]3597-us always ! "[203-the earl] [The Earl]203-the earl looked at [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol , and [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol looked at [the Earl]203-the earl . [[His]203-the earl lordship]207-his lordship was entirely in earnest . [He]203-the earl had made up [his]203-the earl mind to waste no time in arranging this matter . " Are [you]203-the earl quite sure [you]203-the earl want [me]43-mrs. errol ? "[43-mrs. errol] said [Mrs. Errol]43-mrs. errol , with [her]43-mrs. errol soft , pretty smile . " Quite sure , "[203-the earl] [he]203-the earl said bluntly . " [We]3599-we have always wanted [you]43-mrs. errol , but [we]3599-we were not exactly aware of it .
